        "solution": "<p>Show that  \\( \\cos ^{2}\\theta +\\cos ^{2}(60+\\theta )+\\cos ^{2}(60-\\theta )={\\frac  {3}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>LHS =\n \\( \\cos ^{2}\\theta +\\cos ^{2}(60+\\theta )+\\cos ^{2}(60-\\theta )=\\cos ^{2}\\theta +[\\cos 60\\cos \\theta -\\sin 60\\sin \\theta ]^{2}+[\\cos 60\\cos \\theta +\\sin 60\\sin \\theta ]^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\cos ^{2}\\theta +2[(\\cos 60\\cos \\theta )^{2}+(\\sin 60\\sin \\theta )^{2}]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\cos ^{2}\\theta +2{\\frac  {\\cos ^{2}\\theta }{4}}+2{\\frac  {3}{4}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\cos ^{2}\\theta +{\\frac  {\\cos ^{2}\\theta }{2}}+{\\frac  {3\\sin ^{2}\\theta }{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {3\\cos ^{2}\\theta }{2}}+{\\frac  {\\sin ^{2}\\theta }{2}}={\\frac  {3}{2}}[\\cos ^{2}\\theta +\\sin ^{2}\\theta ]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {3}{2}}(1)={\\frac  {3}{2}}\\, \\) =RHS\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( f(x)=x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {f(x+\\Delta x)-f(x)}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {x+\\Delta x-x}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\Delta x}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}1=1 \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince the limit exists, we have shown that the derivative of  \\( x\\, \\)  is 1.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( f(x)=2x^{3}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {f(x+\\Delta x)-f(x)}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {2(x+\\Delta x)^{3}-2x^{3}}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( =\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {2(x^{3}+3x^{2}\\Delta x+3x\\Delta x^{2}+\\Delta x^{3})-2x^{3}}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( =\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {6x^{2}\\Delta x+6x\\Delta x^{2}+2\\Delta x^{3}}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( =\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}6x^{2}+6x\\Delta x+2\\Delta x^{2}=6x^{2} \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince the limit exists, we have shown that the derivative of  \\( 2x^{3} \\)  is  \\( 6x^{2} \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( f(x)={\\sqrt  {x}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {f(x+\\Delta x)-f(x)}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {x+\\Delta x}}-{\\sqrt  {x}}}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nHere, we will multiply both the numerator and the denominator of the fraction by  \\( {\\sqrt  {x+\\Delta x}}+{\\sqrt  {x}} \\)  to cancel out the square roots in the numerator.  The result is\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {x+\\Delta x-x}{\\Delta x({\\sqrt  {x+\\Delta x}}+{\\sqrt  {x}})}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\Delta x}{\\Delta x({\\sqrt  {x+\\Delta x}}+{\\sqrt  {x}})}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {x+\\Delta x}}+{\\sqrt  {x}}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nAt this point, plugging in 0 for  \\( \\Delta x \\)  presents no problems.  Doing so gives\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)={\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {x}}+{\\sqrt  {x}}}}={\\frac  {1}{2{\\sqrt  {x}}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the derivative of  \\( {\\sqrt  {x}} \\)  is  \\( {\\frac  {1}{2{\\sqrt  {x}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( f(x)=\\sin x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {f(x+\\Delta x)-f(x)}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\sin(x+\\Delta x)-\\sin x}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( =\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\sin x\\cos \\Delta x+\\cos x\\sin \\Delta x-\\sin x}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( =\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\sin x(\\cos \\Delta x-1)}{\\Delta x}}+\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\cos x\\sin \\Delta x}{\\Delta x}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nTo do these limits, we must recall simple limits given to us in most calculus texts.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\sin x}{x}}=1 \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {1-\\cos x}{x}}=0 \\) \n<br /><br />\nRegrouping what we have so far, we can use these limits we already know to finish this problem.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=\\sin x\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\cos \\Delta x-1}{\\Delta x}}+\\cos x\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {\\sin \\Delta x}{\\Delta x}}=(\\sin x)(0)+(\\cos x)(1)=\\cos x \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, we have shown the derivative of  \\( \\sin x \\)  is  \\( \\cos x \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Let  \\( f(x)=a(x)\\cdot b(x) \\) <br /><br />\nThen  \\( f(x+\\Delta x)=a(x+\\Delta x)\\cdot b(x+\\Delta x) \\) <br /><br />\nSo  \\( {\\frac  {f(x+\\Delta x)-f(x)}{\\Delta x}}={\\frac  {a(x+\\Delta x)b(x+\\Delta x)-a(x)b(x)}{\\Delta x}}={\\frac  {a(x+\\Delta x)b(x+\\Delta x)+a(x+\\Delta x)b(x)-a(x+\\Delta x)b(x)-a(x)b(x)}{\\Delta x}} \\) <br /><br />\n \\( ={\\frac  {a(x+\\Delta x)b(x+\\Delta x)+a(x+\\Delta x)b(x)}{\\Delta x}}-{\\frac  {a(x+\\Delta x)b(x)-a(x)b(x)}{\\Delta x}} \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =a(x+\\Delta x)\\cdot {\\frac  {b(x+\\Delta x)+b(x)}{\\Delta x}}-{\\frac  {a(x+\\Delta x)+a(x)}{\\Delta x}}\\cdot b(x) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Taking the limit:  \\( \\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}{\\frac  {f(x+\\Delta x)-f(x)}{\\Delta x}}=\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}\\left[a(x+\\Delta x)\\cdot {\\frac  {b(x+\\Delta x)+b(x)}{\\Delta x}}\\right]-\\lim _{{\\Delta x\\to 0}}\\left[{\\frac  {a(x+\\Delta x)+a(x)}{\\Delta x}}\\cdot b(x)\\right] \\)  <br /><br />\n</p><p>Hence  \\( f&#39;(x)=a(x)\\cdot b&#39;(x)+a&#39;(x)\\cdot b(x) \\) <br /><br /><br />\n</p><p>Note: It can be shown that  \\( \\lim _{{y\\to c}}g(y)\\cdot h(y)=g(c)h(c)\\, \\)   if   \\( \\lim _{{y\\to c}}g(y)=g(c) \\)  and   \\( \\lim _{{y\\to c}}h(y)=h(c) \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.056 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.171 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 31/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 204/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33063-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030542 and revision id 38377\n -->\n",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Quotient Rule,Quotient,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Derive the Quotient Rule formula.<br /><br />\n</p><p>Recall the Product Rule:  \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}(ab)=ab^{\\prime }+a^{\\prime }b\\, \\) \n</p><p>The Product Rule can be applied to a quotient by noting that  \\( {\\frac  {a}{b}}=ab^{{-1}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Also note that the Power Rule and Chain Rule must be applied when taking  \\( (b^{{-1}})^{\\prime }\\, \\) .  Therefore,\n</p>\n<center>\n<table>\n\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\left({\\frac  {a}{b}}\\right)\\, \\)  </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\left(ab^{{-1}}\\right)\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =a(b^{{-1}})^{\\prime }+a^{\\prime }b^{{-1}}\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =a(-b^{{-2}}b^{\\prime })+a^{\\prime }b^{{-1}}\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}+{\\frac  {a^{\\prime }}{b}}\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}+{\\frac  {a^{\\prime }}{b}}\\cdot {\\frac  {b}{b}}\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}+{\\frac  {ba^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {ba^{\\prime }-ab^{\\prime }}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n</center>\n<p>which is the correct Quotient Rule formula.\n</p><p>In practice, it is usually easier to memorize just the Product Rule and apply it in both cases as here, rather than memorize two formulas.<br /><br />\n</p>",

We have a function to a power.  As with the power rule, bring down the power and subtract one from the exponent.     }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Chain Rule,Chain,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\left(f(g(x))\\right)&#39;=f&#39;(g(x))g&#39;(x) \\) <br /><br />\n \\( \\Rightarrow \\left|{\\frac  {f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))-f(g(x))}{\\delta _{{fg}}}}-f&#39;(g(x))g&#39;(x)\\right|&lt;\\varepsilon _{{fg}}\\, \\) , where subscripts denote dependence. (Note all  \\( \\delta \\, \\)  and  \\( \\varepsilon \\, \\)  are positive )<br /><br />\n</p><p>We need to show the above follows from the differentiability of f and g: <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\left|{\\frac  {g(x+\\delta _{{g}})-g(x)}{\\delta _{{g}}}}-g&#39;(x)\\right|&lt;\\varepsilon _{{g}}\\, \\)  and  \\( \\left|{\\frac  {f(x+\\delta _{{f}})-f(x)}{\\delta _{{f}}}}-f&#39;(x)\\right|&lt;\\varepsilon _{{f}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>On rearranging we get: <br />\n</p><p> \\( |g(x+\\delta _{g})|&lt;\\;\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{g}-\\delta _{g}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-|g(x)| \\)  <br /><br />\n \\( |f(x+\\delta _{f})|&lt;\\;\\varepsilon _{f}\\delta _{f}-\\delta _{f}\\,|f&#39;(x)|-|f(x)| \\)  <br /><br />\n</p><p>Consider  \\( |f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))|\\, \\) . <br /><br /> By definition of g, and then f:  \n \\( |f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))|&lt;\\left|f\\left(\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}}-\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-|g(x)|\\right)\\right|=\\left|f\\left(|g(x)|+\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}}\\right)\\right| \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( &lt;\\varepsilon _{f}(\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}})-(\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}})|f&#39;(g(x))|-|f(g(x))| \\)  , where we are taking  \\( \\delta _{f}=\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}}\\left(*\\right) \\) <br /><br /><br />\n</p><p>Thus:  \\( |f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))|\\;+\\;|f(g(x))|&lt;\\varepsilon _{f}(\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}})-(\\delta _{{fg}}\\,|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g}\\delta _{{fg}})|f&#39;(g(x))| \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\Rightarrow \\left|{\\frac  {f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))-f(g(x))}{\\delta _{{fg}}}}\\right|&lt;\\varepsilon _{f}(|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g})-(|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g})|f&#39;(g(x))| \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\Rightarrow \\left|{\\frac  {f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))-f(g(x))}{\\delta _{{fg}}}}\\right|+|f&#39;(g(x))||g&#39;(x)|&lt;\\varepsilon _{f}(|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g})+\\varepsilon _{g}|f&#39;(g(x))| \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\Rightarrow \\left|{\\frac  {f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))-f(g(x))}{\\delta _{{fg}}}}-f&#39;(g(x))g&#39;(x)\\right|&lt;\\varepsilon _{f}(|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g})+\\varepsilon _{g}|f&#39;(g(x))| \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Take  \\( \\varepsilon _{{fg}}=\\varepsilon _{f}(|g&#39;(x)|-\\varepsilon _{g})+\\varepsilon _{g}|f&#39;(g(x))| \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>From  \\( (*)\\, \\)  we see that as  \\( \\delta _{{fg}}\\to 0,\\delta _{f}\\to 0\\Rightarrow \\varepsilon _{f}\\to 0 \\) <br />\nWe also have  \\( \\delta _{g}\\to 0\\Rightarrow \\varepsilon _{g}\\to 0 \\) <br />\nHence  \\( \\varepsilon _{{fg}}\\to 0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Therefore  \\( \\left|{\\frac  {f(g(x+\\delta _{{fg}}))-f(g(x))}{\\delta _{{fg}}}}-f&#39;(g(x))g&#39;(x)\\right|&lt;\\varepsilon _{{fg}}\\, \\)  with  \\( \\varepsilon _{{fg}}\\to 0 \\)  as  \\( \\delta _{g}\\to 0 \\) , which is what we set out to prove\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.104 seconds\nReal time Remember that  \\( y\\, \\)  is a function of  \\( x\\, \\)  so its derivative is  \\( y&#39;(x)\\, \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe derivative of the right side comes from the formula we find, in the section for logarithmic differentiation, for the derivative of  \\( g(x)^{{h(x)}}\\, \\) <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calc2.2\" title=\"Calc2.2\">Calc2.2</a> which is  \\( g^{h}(h&#39;\\ln g+{\\frac  {h}{g}}g&#39;)\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( y&#39;x+y=x^{y}(y&#39;\\ln x+{\\frac  {y}{x}})\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow the first step in solving for the derivative,  \\( y&#39;\\, \\) , is to get all terms involving  \\( y&#39;\\, \\)  on one side and all other terms on the other side\n<br /><br />\n \\( y&#39;(x-x^{y}\\ln x)=x^{y}{\\frac  {y}{x}}-y\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow divide to solve for  \\( y&#39;\\, \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( y&#39;={\\frac  {y(x^{{y-1}}-1)}{x-x^{y}\\ln x}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the derivative of  \\( f(x)\\, \\)  with respect to  \\( x\\, \\) :\n \\( f(x)=\\int _{{0}}^{{x}}e^{t}\\,dt\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nHere we have an integral as our function. It says that the derivative of an integral from a constant to  \\( x\\, \\)  of a function  \\( f(t)\\, \\)  is simply  \\( f(x)\\, \\) .         "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Second Fundamental Theorem of Calculus,Second,Fundamental,Theorem,Calculus,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Suppose  \\( F(y)=\\int _{a}^{y}f(t)\\,dt \\) <br />\nWe know that there exist real numbers  \\( x\\, \\)  and  \\( x+\\delta \\, \\)  in  \\( [a,b]\\, \\) , where a and b are non-equal real numbers. <br /><br />\n \\( F(x+\\delta )-F(x)=\\int _{a}^{{x+\\delta }}f(t)\\,dt-\\int _{a}^{{x}}f(t)\\,dt \\) <br /><br />\nIt can be shown that  \\( \\int _{a}^{{x+\\delta }}f(t)\\,dt-\\int _{a}^{{x}}f(t)\\,dt=\\int _{x}^{{x+\\delta }}f(t)\\,dt \\) <br /><br />\nBy the mean value theorem:  \\( \\int _{x}^{{x+\\delta }}f(t)\\,dt=f(c)\\delta  \\)  for some c in  \\( [x,x+\\delta ]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Hence  \\( F(x+\\delta )-F(x)=f(c)\\delta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\Rightarrow {\\frac  {F(x+\\delta )-F(x)}{\\delta }}=f(c) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\Rightarrow \\lim _{{\\delta \\to 0}}{\\frac  {F(x+\\delta )-F(x)}{\\delta }}=\\lim _{{\\delta \\to 0}}f(c) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>But as  \\( \\delta \\to 0,\\,c\\to x \\)  by the Sandwich Theorem <br /><br />\n</p><p>Hence  \\( \\lim _{{\\delta \\to 0}}{\\frac  {F(x+\\delta )-F(x)}{\\delta }}=f(x) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Therefore, relabelling y as x:  \\( \\,{\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\int _{a}^{x}f(t)\\,dt=f(x) \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.072 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.220 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 43/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 284/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33065-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030612 and revision id 38384\n -->\n",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Slope of the Tangent Line,Slope,Tangent,Applications of Derivatives,Applications,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the slope of the tangent line to the graph  \\( f(x)=6x \\)  when  \\( x=3 \\) .\n<br /><br />\nRemember, if the derivative exists at a point, it gives us the instantaneous rate of change for a graph that point.  Another way to think about that is that it gives us the slope, or constant rate of change, of the line which is tangent to the graph at that point.  To find the answer to this problem, find the derivative of  \\( f(x) \\)  and plug in  \\( x=3 \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=6\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe derivative of this function is constant, it is always 6.  This is because this is a straight line.  Its rate of change is constant.  If we were to find the slope of the line, we would also get 6.  This equation of the line is in the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php?title=Slope-intercept_form&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Slope-intercept form (page does not exist)\">slope-intercept form</a> and we can tell just by looking at the equation that the slope is 6.  So,\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(3)=6\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis tells us that if we were to draw the line tangent to this graph at the point  \\( (3,18) \\) , the slope of that line would be  \\( 6 \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc2.39",

After taking the derivative, it is okay to plug in the point.  We have two options.  We can solve for  \\( y&#39; \\)  and then plug in our point or we can plug our point and then solve for  \\( y&#39; \\) .  Usually, it is simpler to simply plug in the point.         "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the absolute minimum and maximum on  \\( [-1,5] \\)  of the function  \\( f(x)=(1-x)e^{x} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIt is known that the only place an absolute minimum or maximum can occur on an interval is at one of the endpoints of the interval or at a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php?title=Critical_point&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Critical point (page does not exist)\">critical point</a> inside the interval.  A critical point is a point where the function is defined and its derivative is either 0 or undefined.  So start by finding the derivative.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=-e^{x}+(1-x)e^{x}=-xe^{x}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis derivative is defined everywhere so the only possible critical numbers will be where the derivative is equal to 0.\n<br /><br />\n \\( -xe^{x}=0 \\)  can only be true if  \\( x=0 \\)  or  \\( e^{x}=0 \\)  but  \\( e^{x} \\)  is always positive so it is never equal to  \\( 0 \\) .  Thus the only critical point comes when  \\( x=0 \\) .  As stated before, the absolute max and min can only occur at an endpoint or at a critical number.  So our only choices for  \\( x \\)  here are  \\( -1 \\) ,  \\( 0 \\) , or  \\( 5 \\) .  If these are our only choices, our easiest plan is to just plug in the three values and see which gives the highest value and which gives the lowest value.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f(-1)={\\frac  {2}{e}}\\,&lt;1 \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f(0)=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f(5)=-4e^{5}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the absolute minimum comes at the point  \\( (5,-4e^{5}) \\)  and the absolute maximum comes at the point  \\( (0,1) \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the absolute minimum and maximum on  \\( \\left[-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}\\right] \\)  of the function  \\( f(x)=\\sin(x^{2}) \\) .\n<br /><br />\nAgain, any absolute minimum or maximum of this function on the indicated interval can only occur at a critical point of the function or at one of the endpoints of the interval.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=(2x)\\cos(x^{2})\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis derivative is never undefined.  It is equal to 0 at infinitely many values of  \\( x \\)  since the  \\( \\cos u \\)  function is periodic but on our given interval, it is equal to  \\( 0 \\)  only at a finite number of points.  This derivative is equal to  \\( 0 \\)  either when  \\( x=0 \\)  or when  \\( \\cos(x^{2})=0 \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe cosine function is equal to  \\( 0 \\)  at any point in the set  \\( \\{...,-{\\frac  {3\\pi }{2}},-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac  {3\\pi }{2}},...\\} \\) .  So, the derivative will be equal to  \\( 0 \\)  whenever  \\( x^{2} \\)  is equal to one of these values.  The only values of  \\( x \\)  inside of our interval for which this is true are  \\( -{\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}} \\)  and  \\( {\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}} \\) .  Thus, we have five values as candidates for our absolute max and the same five are candidates for our absolute min.  Plug in all five values into the original function.  The highest will be our absolute max and the lowest will be our absolute min.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f(-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}})=\\sin {\\frac  {\\pi ^{2}}{4}}\\approx 0.624\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f(-{\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}})=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f(0)=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f({\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}})=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f({\\frac  {\\pi }{2}})=\\sin {\\frac  {\\pi ^{2}}{4}}\\approx 0.624\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, we have an absolute minimum on the interval at the point  \\( (0,0) \\)  and an absolute maximum on the interval at two points, both of which have the same height,  \\( \\left(-{\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}},1\\right) \\)  and  \\( \\left({\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}},1\\right) \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc2.47", 
        "problem": "Find the absolute minimum and maximum on  \\( \\left[-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}},{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}\\right] \\)  of the function  \\( f(x)=\\sin(x^{2}) \\) ."

    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Extrema (Maxima and Minima),Extrema,(Maxima,Minima),Applications of Derivatives,Applications,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find all local minimums and maximums of the function  \\( f(x)=x^{2} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nLocal minimums and maximums may occur never, once, or many times depending on the function.  However, they occur only at critical points, that is only at points where the function is defined and the derivative is 0 or undefined.  The derivative of our function is\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)=2x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis derivative is always defined and is equal to  \\( 0 \\)  only when  \\( x=0 \\) .  So our only critical point is  \\( x=0 \\) .  To decide if this is a local maximum or minimum let us look at the behavior of the derivative to the left and to the right of it.  Since this is the only point where the derivative is ever equal to  \\( 0 \\)  it must be true that to the left of  \\( x=0 \\)  the derivative is always negative or always positive and the same can be said to the right of  \\( x=0 \\) .  If the derivative is positive that tells us that the function is increasing in that region and if the derivative is negative that tells us that the function is decreasing in that region.  This information will tell us if the critical point is a local max, a local min, or neither.\n<br /><br />\nSince the behavior is the same for any point left of  \\( x=0 \\)  and also always the same for any point right of  \\( x=0 \\) , just pick one point on each side and find the value of the derivative at that x-value.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(-1)=-2\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(1)=2\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince the derivative to the left of  \\( x=0 \\)  is negative, that tells us that the function is decreasing up to that point and since the derivative is positive to the right, we know the function is increasing on the interval  \\( (0,\\infty ) \\) .  If the function goes from decreasing to increasing, this must be a local minimum at the point  \\( (0,0) \\)  which is easily verified by looking at a graph.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc2.48", 
        "problem": "Find all local minima and maxima of the function  \\( f(x)=x^{2} \\) ."
    },

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find all local minimums and maximums of the function  \\( f(x)={\\frac  {x^{2}-1}{x}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nAll local minimums and maximums will be at critical points.  A critical point is a point where the function is defined and the derivative is either  \\( 0 \\)  or undefined.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)={\\frac  {x(2x)-1(x^{2}-1)}{x^{2}}}={\\frac  {x^{2}+1}{x^{2}}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nA fraction is equal to  \\( 0 \\)  only when the numerator is equal to  \\( 0 \\) .  However,  \\( x^{2}+1 \\)  is always positive so the derivative is never equal to  \\( 0 \\) .  It is undefined when  \\( x=0 \\)  but so is the original function.  Therefore there are no critical points and no local minimums or maximums.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Extrema (Maxima and Minima),Extrema,(Maxima,Minima),Applications of Derivatives,Applications,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>If a farmer wants to make a rectangular pen along a river, so that only 3 sides need to be fenced in, what is the largest area he can fence with 100 feet of fence?\n<br /><br />\nThis problem is equivalent to asking us to find the absolute max of the area on an interval, though the interval is not given explicitly.  We know that an absolute max can only occur at a critical point or at the endpoint of an interval.  The information in this problem gives us one equation relating the length and width of this rectangle.  The total length of fence must be 100 feet.  Since we have three sides, two of which are equal, we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( 100=2x+y\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nIf the total fence to be used is 100 feet, it makes sense that  \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 50 \\) .  Thus, our interval for the problem is  \\( [0,50] \\) .  Now, the problem asks us to maximize the area.  The derivative of a function can help us find the maximum, if one exists, so we need an equation for the area of this rectangle.  That is simply\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=xy\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis is all the information we need to solve this problem.  Take the first equation and solve it for  \\( y \\) .  We can then plug this into our second equation so that the area is in terms of only one variable.\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=x(100-2x)=100x-2x^{2}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nRemember, a critical point is a point where the original function is defined and the derivate is  \\( 0 \\)  or undefined.  \n<br /><br />\n \\( A&#39;=100-4x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis derivative is always defined so no critical points will be found that way.  The derivative is equal to  \\( 0 \\)  when  \\( x=25 \\)  so we have one critical point.  Thus are absolute maximum area will be found at  \\( x=0 \\) ,  \\( x=25 \\) , or  \\( x=50 \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( A(0)=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( A(25)=1250\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( A(50)=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the greatest area the fence can enclose in the prescribed manner is 1250 square feet when the side adjacent to the river is 50 feet long and the side perpendicular is 25 feet long.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc2.50", 
        "problem": "If a farmer wants to put up a fence along a river, so that only 3 sides need to be fenced in, what is the largest area he can fence with 100 feet of fence?"
    },

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Extrema (Maxima and Minima),Extrema,(Maxima,Minima),Applications of Derivatives,Applications,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the local minimums and maximums of the function  \\( f(x)={\\sqrt  {x}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nTo find the local minimums and maximums of a function, find the critical points by finding the derivative and finding the points where it is equal to 0 or undefined.  If the original function is defined at these points, then these are critical points.\n<br /><br />\n \\( f&#39;(x)={\\frac  {1}{2{\\sqrt  {x}}}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis function is never equal to 0 as the numerator is never equal to 0.  It is undefined at  \\( x=0 \\) .  This is our only critical point.  However, the square root function is only defined for nonnegative real numbers so  \\( f(x) \\)  is not defined to the left of  \\( x=0 \\) .  Thus, it can not have a local minimum or maximum at  \\( x=0 \\) .   \\( x=0 \\)  does give us the lowest point on the entire square root function as it starts at  \\( 0 \\)  and increases thereafter.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc2.52", 
        "problem": "Find the local minima and maxima of the function  \\( f(x)={\\sqrt  {x}} \\) ."
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Related Rates,Related,Rates,Applications of Derivatives,Applications,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>A clock face has a 12 inch diameter, a 5.5-inch second hand, a 5 inch minute hand and a 3 inch hour hand. When it is exactly 3:30, calculate the rate at which the distance between the tip of any one of these hands and the 9 o'clock position is changing.<br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\nFirst consider the distance between the tip of the second hand and the 9 o'clock position; let us call this  \\( r \\) . Further, let  \\( \\theta  \\)  be the angle between the 9 o'clock position and the second hand, and let  \\( t \\)  be the time, in seconds. Then we have  \\( {\\frac  {d\\theta }{dt}}={\\frac  {2\\pi \\ {{\\rm {radians}}}}{60\\ {{\\rm {seconds}}}}}={\\frac  {\\pi }{30}}{{\\rm {rad/sec}}} \\) . If we use the Law of Cosines, we can get a formula for  \\( r \\)  in terms of  \\( \\theta  \\) . That is,  \\( r^{2}=6^{2}+5.5^{2}-2\\cdot 6\\cdot 5.5\\cos \\theta  \\) . (Draw a picture to help visualize this if you need to. The two smaller legs of the triangle will always be 6 and 5.5 inches, for the 9 o'clock position and second-hand tip, respectively. As  \\( \\theta  \\)  changes, so does  \\( r \\) .) Using implicit differentiation, we get  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{d\\theta }}={\\frac  {6\\cdot 5.5\\sin \\theta }{r}} \\) . Thus, the desired related rate is calculated using the chain rule:  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{dt}}={\\frac  {dr}{d\\theta }}\\cdot {\\frac  {d\\theta }{dt}}={\\frac  {11\\pi \\sin \\theta }{10r}} \\) . At 3:30, we have  \\( \\theta ={\\frac  {\\pi }{2}} \\)  and  \\( r={\\sqrt  {6^{2}+5.5^{2}}}\\approx 8.1394 \\) . Then  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{dt}}\\approx 1.39\\,{{\\rm {in/sec}}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>The desired rate for the minute and hour hands is calculated in a nearly identical fashion. For the minute hand, we have  \\( {\\frac  {d\\theta }{dt}}={\\frac  {2\\pi \\ {{\\rm {radians}}}}{3600\\ {{\\rm {seconds}}}}}={\\frac  {\\pi }{1800}}{{\\rm {rad/sec}}} \\)  and  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{d\\theta }}={\\frac  {6\\cdot 5\\sin \\theta }{r}} \\) , so  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{dt}}={\\frac  {\\pi \\sin \\theta }{60r}} \\) . At 3:30,  \\( \\theta =-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}} \\)  and  \\( r={\\sqrt  {6^{2}+5^{2}}}\\approx 7.8102 \\) , so  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{dt}}\\approx -0.0067\\,{{\\rm {in/sec}}} \\) , or  \\( \\approx -0.4022\\,{{\\rm {in/min}}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>For the hour hand, we get  \\( {\\frac  {d\\theta }{dt}}={\\frac  {\\pi }{21600}}{{\\rm {rad/sec}}} \\)  and  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{d\\theta }}={\\frac  {6\\cdot 3\\sin \\theta }{r}} \\) . Then  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{dt}}={\\frac  {\\pi \\sin \\theta }{1200r}} \\) . At 3:30, if we assume that  \\( \\theta =\\pi  \\) , we see that this rate is 0. This is rather intuitional, as we may think of this as the peak in midair when we throw a ball up into the air; at this peak, the ball's velocity is 0. We can get a bit fancier though, as at 3:30 we could assume that the hour hand is halfway between the 3 and 4 o'clock positions. That is, at 3:30,  \\( \\theta =-{\\frac  {11\\pi }{12}} \\) , so  \\( r={\\sqrt  {6^{2}+3^{2}-2\\cdot 6\\cdot 3\\cos(-11\\pi /12)}}\\approx 8.9316 \\) . Then,  \\( {\\frac  {dr}{dt}}\\approx -7.5864e-4\\,{{\\rm {in/sec}}} \\) , or  \\( \\approx -0.0046\\,{{\\rm {in/min}}} \\) , or  \\( \\approx -0.2731\\,{{\\rm {in/hr}}} \\) .\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.136 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.449 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 91/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 604/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31304-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030630 and revision id 33991\n -->\n",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Related Rates,Related,Rates,Applications of Derivatives,Applications,Derivatives", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>A spherical container of  \\( r \\)  meters is being filled with a liquid at a rate of  \\( \\rho \\,{{\\rm {m}}}^{3}/{{\\rm {min}}} \\) . At what rate is the height of the liquid in the container changing with respect to time?<br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( V \\)  be the volume already in the container,  \\( h \\)  be the height of the liquid in the container and  \\( t \\)  be the time since some initial starting point. We are given that  \\( {\\frac  {dV}{dt}}=\\rho \\,{{\\rm {m}}}^{3}/{{\\rm {min}}} \\)  and we are asked for the related rate  \\( {\\frac  {dh}{dt}} \\) . The other rate needed for this problem is the rate at which the height is changing with respect to the volume, namely  \\( {\\frac  {dh}{dV}} \\) . In order to calculate this, we need a relation between the height and the volume of the liquid at any particular point in time.<br />\n</p><p>We will use a trick from integral calculus to get the volume in terms of the height. Let a silhouette of our container be described by the implicit equation  \\( x^{2}+(y-r)^{2}=r^{2} \\) , a circle of radius  \\( r \\)  whose bottom is on the  \\( x \\) -axis. Using the slicing method for finding a volume of revolution, we get that  \\( V=\\int _{0}^{h}\\pi x^{2}\\,dy=\\int _{0}^{h}\\pi (r^{2}-(y-r)^{2})\\,dy=\\left.\\pi \\left(r^{2}y-{\\frac  {1}{3}}(y-r)^{3}\\right)\\right|_{{y=0}}^{h} \\) . This simplifies into the formula  \\( V=\\pi \\left(r^{2}h-{\\frac  {1}{3}}(h-r)^{3}-{\\frac  {1}{3}}r^{3}\\right) \\) . Then  \\( {\\frac  {dV}{dh}}=\\pi \\left(r^{2}-(h-r)^{2}\\right)=\\pi h(2r-h) \\) , so  \\( {\\frac  {dh}{dV}}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi h(2r-h)}} \\) .<br />\n</p><p>Then we get the general forumla for the desired rate:  \\( {\\frac  {dh}{dt}}={\\frac  {dh}{dV}}\\cdot {\\frac  {dV}{dt}}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi h(2r-h)}}\\cdot \\rho ={\\frac  {\\rho }{\\pi h(2r-h)}}\\,{{\\rm {m/min}}} \\) . This is a general formula which will give us the rate at which the height is changing at any given height (assumed to be between 0 and 2r).\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.076 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.234 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 49/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 324/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31308-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030632 and revision id 34000\n -->\n",

Plug  \\( x^{2}+1\\, \\)  back in wherever there is a  \\( u\\, \\) .  Also, note the absolute value bars can be dropped because  \\( x^{2}+1\\, \\)  is always positive.  So our answer is\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\ln(x^{2}+1)+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

First, start out by finding a suitable  \\( u\\, \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( u=x^{2}+x+7\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( du=(2x+1)dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nHere is where you need to be careful.         "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>errodom\n \\( \\int \\ln {x}dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\nIn order to compute this integral, one must do integration by parts.<br />\nRecall that the formula for this method is  \\( \\int u\\,dv=uv-\\int v\\,du\\, \\) .<br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( u\\, \\)  be  \\( \\ln x\\, \\)  and let  \\( dv\\, \\)  be  \\( dx\\, \\) .<br />\n \\( du\\, \\)  is then  \\( {\\frac  {1}{x}}dx\\, \\) , and  \\( v\\, \\)  is  \\( x\\, \\) .<br /><br />\nSubstituting all of this into the integration by parts formula, we arrive at this expression<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int {\\ln {x}\\,dx}\\ =x\\ln x-\\int {(x)\\left({\\frac  {1}{x}}\\right)\\,dx} \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =x\\ln x-x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =x(\\ln x-1)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Note that this technique works for many integrals in a similar form. <br /><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Calculus</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.2", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( \\int \\ln x\\,dx\\, \\) "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Integration by Parts,Integration,Parts,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int x\\sin(x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int u\\,dv=uv-\\int v\\,du\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integration_by_parts\">Integrate by parts</a>. Integration by parts is a method to move derivatives from one part of the integrand to the other. To evaluate the integral, move a derivative on to the  \\( x \\)  term.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u=x,dv=\\sin(x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( du=dx,v=-\\cos(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( uv-\\int v\\,du=-x\\cos(x)+\\int \\cos(x)\\,dx=-x\\cos(x)+\\sin(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Calculus</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.3", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( \\int x\\sin(x)\\,dx\\, \\) "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Integration by Parts,Integration,Parts,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int \\arctan(2x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Make a substitution  \\( s=2x,ds=2\\,dx\\, \\) . Then the problem becomes<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int \\arctan(s)ds\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Integration_by_parts\">Integrate by parts</a>. Let <br /><br />\n \\( u=\\arctan(s),\\,\\,\\,\\,dv=ds\\, \\) <br />\n \\( du={\\frac  {1}{s^{2}+1}}ds,\\,\\,\\,\\,v=s\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left[\\int u\\,dv\\right]={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left[uv-\\int v\\,du\\right]={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left[s\\cdot \\arctan(s)-\\int {\\frac  {s}{s^{2}+1}}\\,ds\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left[s\\cdot \\arctan(s)-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln(s^{2}+1)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left[2x\\cdot \\arctan(2x)-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln((2x)^{2}+1)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Calculus</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.4", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( \\int \\arctan(2x)\\,dx\\, \\) "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Integration by Parts,Integration,Parts,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nTo do this integral, we will use the method of <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integration_by_parts\" title=\"Integration by parts\">integration by parts</a> which tells us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int u\\,dv=uv-\\int v\\,du\\, \\) .\n<br /><br />\nFor this specific integral, the technique is to create an equation by using <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integration_by_parts\" title=\"Integration by parts\">integration by parts</a> twice and then solve for the value of the integral.  The exact same integral will pop up after we do our second <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integration_by_parts\" title=\"Integration by parts\">integration by parts</a> at which time we can move it to the other side of the equation.\n<br /><br />\n \\( u=\\sin x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( du=\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dv=e^{x}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( v=e^{x}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo, our integral becomes\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx=e^{x}\\sin x-\\int e^{x}\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nDo integration by parts again with this new integral.  Technically,  \\( u\\, \\) ,  \\( du\\, \\) ,  \\( v\\, \\) , and  \\( dv\\, \\)  all are already assigned values but it is common practice to use these same variables again for this new integral.  However, keep in mind that they have nothing to do with the previous  \\( u\\, \\) ,  \\( du\\, \\) ,  \\( v\\, \\) , and  \\( dv\\, \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( u=\\cos x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( du=-\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dv=e^{x}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( v=e^{x}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx=e^{x}\\sin x-\\left[e^{x}\\cos x+\\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\right]\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSimplifying the equation gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx=e^{x}\\sin x-e^{x}\\cos x-\\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, we can add  \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\)  to both sides of the equation and divide by  \\( 2\\, \\)  to get the value of the integral.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx={\\frac  {e^{x}}{2}}(\\sin x-\\cos x)+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.57", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( \\int e^{x}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) "
    },

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Integration by Parts,Integration,Parts,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int x^{4}\\sin x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nHere, we have  \\( x^{4} \\) , which tells us we will need to use the method of <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integration_by_parts\" title=\"Integration by parts\">integration by parts</a> 4 times.  Luckily, there is a quicker way for integrals involving powers of  \\( x \\)  multiplied by a function such as  \\( \\cos x \\)  or  \\( \\sin x \\)  or  \\( e^{x} \\) .  The method is called the tabular method.  Make a chart with three columns.  The first column will contain alternating +, -, +, ... starting with +.  The second column will start out with  \\( u=x^{4} \\)  and each row below will contain the derivative of the function above.  Keep going until you reach 0 as a derivative.  The third column contains  \\( dv=\\sin x \\)  and every subsequent row contains the integral of the function below.\n<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\begin{matrix}+\\ \\longrightarrow &amp;x^{4}&amp;\\ &amp;\\sin x\\\\\\ &amp;\\ &amp;\\searrow &amp;\\ \\\\-\\ \\longrightarrow &amp;4x^{3}&amp;\\ &amp;-\\cos x\\\\\\ &amp;\\ &amp;\\searrow &amp;\\ \\\\+\\ \\longrightarrow &amp;12x^{2}&amp;\\ &amp;-\\sin x\\\\\\ &amp;\\ &amp;\\searrow &amp;\\ \\\\-\\ \\longrightarrow &amp;24x&amp;\\ &amp;\\cos x\\\\\\ &amp;\\ &amp;\\searrow &amp;\\ \\\\+\\ \\longrightarrow &amp;24&amp;\\ &amp;\\sin x\\\\\\ &amp;\\ &amp;\\searrow &amp;\\\\\\ &amp;0&amp;\\ &amp;-\\cos x\\\\\\end{matrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br /><br />\nSo we have the answer already.  When multiplying in the first row, as you can see by the arrows, multiply the  \\( + \\)  by the  \\( x^{4} \\)  in the same row and by the  \\( -\\cos x \\)  in the row below.  Do all of these multiplications and add them together to get the answer.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int x^{4}\\sin x\\,dx=-x^{4}\\cos x+4x^{3}\\sin x+12x^{2}\\cos x-24x\\sin x-24\\cos x+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int \\sin ^{5}x\\cos ^{5}x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nTrigonometric integrals are split up into a few cases.  This problem is the case where either the  \\( \\sin x \\)  or  \\( \\cos x \\)  is to an odd power.  Both are odd, in fact, for this problem but the procedure is the same if only one is odd.  First, pick the one that has an odd power, either will work here.  For this specific example, let's turn 4 of those  \\( \\cos x \\)  into  \\( \\sin x \\)  and what we'll have left is a whole bunch of  \\( \\sin x \\)  and 1  \\( \\cos x \\) , which is the derivative of  \\( \\sin x \\) .  This sets up a nice integral by substitution.\n<br /><br />\n \\( I=\\int \\sin ^{5}x\\cos ^{5}x\\,dx=\\int \\sin ^{5}x(1-\\sin ^{2}x)^{2}\\cos x\\,dx=\\int (\\sin ^{9}x-2\\sin ^{7}x+\\sin ^{5}x)\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nLet  \\( u=\\sin x\\, \\)  and  \\( du=\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( I=\\int (u^{9}-2u^{7}+u^{5})\\,du={\\frac  {1}{10}}u^{{10}}-{\\frac  {1}{4}}u^{8}+{\\frac  {1}{6}}u^{6}+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nAnd substitution back in gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int \\sin ^{5}x\\cos ^{5}x\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{10}}\\sin ^{{10}}x-{\\frac  {1}{4}}\\sin ^{8}x+{\\frac  {1}{6}}\\sin ^{6}x+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe procedure for many integrals is the same with the main difference being which of the trigonometric substitutions are used and in which way they are used.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

If there is still an even number of  \\( \\cos x \\)  (and there is always an even number of  \\( \\sin x \\) , that is 0), continue to reduce them until you get to an odd power of  \\( \\cos x \\) .         "solution": "<p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {x\\,dx}{{\\sqrt  {3-2x-x^{2}}}}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Note  \\( \\int {\\frac  {x\\,dx}{{\\sqrt  {3-2x-x^{2}}}}}=\\int {\\frac  {x\\,dx}{{\\sqrt  {4-(x+1)^{2}}}}} \\) . Now make the trigonometric substitution  \\( x+1=2\\sin \\theta \\, \\) , so that  \\( dx=2\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\)  and  \\( x=2\\sin \\theta -1\\, \\) . Then,\n</p>\n<table>\n<tr>\n<td>  \\( \\int {\\frac  {x\\,dx}{{\\sqrt  {4-(x+1)^{2}}}}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int {\\frac  {(2\\sin \\theta -1)2\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta }{{\\sqrt  {4-4\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int {\\frac  {(2\\sin \\theta -1)2\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta }{{\\sqrt  {4\\cos ^{2}\\theta }}}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int (2\\sin \\theta -1)d\\theta =-2\\cos \\theta -\\theta +C. \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n<p>Now, if  \\( {\\frac  {x+1}{2}}=\\sin \\theta  \\) , it can be shown that  \\( \\cos \\theta ={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3-2x-x^{2}}}}{2}} \\)  and  \\( \\theta =\\arcsin \\left({\\frac  {x+1}{2}}\\right) \\) , so\n</p><p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {x\\,dx}{{\\sqrt  {3-2x-x^{2}}}}}=-\\arcsin \\left({\\frac  {x+1}{2}}\\right)-{\\sqrt  {3-2x-x^{2}}}+C \\) .\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.064 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.195 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 40/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 264/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:30611-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030653 and revision id 31543\n -->\n",

    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Trigonometric Substitution,Trigonometric,Substitution,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int \\operatorname{arcsec} x\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\nUse integration by parts with  \\( u=\\operatorname{arcsec} x\\, \\)  and  \\( dv=dx\\, \\) . Then, for  \\( x&gt;1\\, \\) ,  \\( du={\\frac  {dx}{x{\\sqrt  {x^{2}-1}}}}\\, \\)  and  \\( v=x\\, \\) . So \n</p>\n<table>\n<tr>\n<td>  \\( \\int \\operatorname{arcsec} x\\,dx \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int u\\,dv=uv-\\int v\\,du \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =x\\operatorname{arcsec} x-\\int {\\frac  {x\\,dx}{x{\\sqrt  {x^{2}-1}}}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =x\\operatorname{arcsec} x-\\int {\\frac  {dx}{{\\sqrt  {x^{2}-1}}}} \\) .\n</td></tr></table>\n<p>Now use the trigonometric substitution  \\( x=\\sec \\theta \\, \\)  on the latter integral, with  \\( dx=\\sec \\theta \\,\\tan \\theta \\,d\\theta  \\) .\nThen\n</p>\n<table>\n<tr>\n<td>  \\( \\int {\\frac  {dx}{{\\sqrt  {x^{2}-1}}}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int {\\frac  {\\sec \\theta \\,\\tan \\theta \\,d\\theta }{{\\sqrt  {\\sec ^{2}\\theta -1}}}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int {\\frac  {\\sec \\theta \\,\\tan \\theta \\,d\\theta }{{\\sqrt  {\\tan ^{2}\\theta }}}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\int \\sec \\theta \\,d\\theta =\\ln \\left|\\sec \\theta +\\tan \\theta \\right|+C \\) .\n</td></tr></table>\n<p>As  \\( \\sec \\theta =x\\, \\) , drawing a right triangle with hypotenuse of length  \\( x \\)  and adjacent side of length 1 yields  \\( \\tan \\theta ={\\sqrt  {x^{2}-1}} \\) . Putting all of this together then gives the solution\n</p><p> \\( \\int \\operatorname{arcsec} x\\,dx=x\\operatorname{arcsec} x-\\ln \\left(x+{\\sqrt  {x^{2}-1}}\\right)+C \\) , where the absolute value in the logarithm may be dropped due to the restriction  \\( x&gt;1.\\, \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.096 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.309 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 64/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 424/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:30610-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030654 and revision id 31542\n -->\n",

Let's take advantage of the identity that tells us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\cos ^{2}x=1-\\sin ^{2}x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nFirst note that\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {4x-x^{2}}}}}\\,dx=\\int {\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {4-(x-2)^{2}}}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nKeeping that in mind, let us use the substitution\n<br /><br />\n \\( x-2=2\\sin \\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dx=2\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {4-(x-2)^{2}}}}}\\,dx=\\int {\\frac  {2\\cos \\theta }{{\\sqrt  {4-4\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}}}d\\theta =\\int {\\frac  {\\cos \\theta }{\\cos \\theta }}d\\theta =\\theta +C=\\arcsin {\\frac  {x-2}{2}}+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nFirst, we must do an integration by parts.\n<br /><br />\n \\( u=\\arcsin x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( du={\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {1-x^{2}}}}}dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dv=x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( v={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int {\\frac  {x^{2}}{{\\sqrt  {1-x^{2}}}}}dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, we are at an integral which can be computed using trigonometric substitution.\n<br /><br />\n \\( x=\\sin \\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dx=\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int {\\frac  {\\sin ^{2}\\theta \\cos \\theta }{{\\sqrt  {1-\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}}}d\\theta ={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int \\sin ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, let us use the power reduction formula on  \\( \\sin ^{2}x \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int x\\arcsin x\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int {\\frac  {1-\\cos 2\\theta }{2}}d\\theta ={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\arcsin x-{\\frac  {1}{4}}\\arcsin x+{\\frac  {1}{4}}x+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nFor the back substitution, remember that  \\( x=\\sin \\theta  \\)  and therefore  \\( \\theta =\\arcsin x \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nWe could do this integral with partial fractions, but for instructive purposes let's use the method of trigonometric substitution.\n<br /><br />\n \\( x=\\sin \\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dx=\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx=\\int {\\frac  {\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta }{1-\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}d\\theta =\\int {\\frac  {\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta }{\\cos ^{2}\\theta }}d\\theta =\\int {\\frac  {\\sin \\theta }{\\cos \\theta }}d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nAt this point, we have to do a substitution again.\n<br /><br />\n \\( u=\\cos \\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( du=-\\sin \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {\\sin \\theta }{\\cos \\theta }}d\\theta =-\\int {\\frac  {du}{u}}=-\\ln |u|+C=-\\ln |\\cos \\theta |+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, we know  \\( x=\\sin \\theta  \\)  and we need to know the value of  \\( \\cos \\theta  \\) .  Using the well known trig identity,  \\( \\sin ^{2}x+\\cos ^{2}x=1 \\) , we get that  \\( \\cos \\theta ={\\sqrt  {1-x^{2}}} \\) .  So\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |1-x^{2}|+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calc1.73\" title=\"Calc1.73\">Click here</a> to see this integral done by partial fractions.\n<br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calc1.72\" title=\"Calc1.72\">Click here</a> to see this integral done by substitution.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Partial Fractions,Partial,Fractions,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {1}{x^{2}-1}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe key to this problem is realizing that we can split up  \\( {\\frac  {1}{x^{2}-1}}\\, \\)  into two fractions.  This method is the method of <b>Partial Fractions</b>.  We know\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{x^{2}-1}}={\\frac  {1}{(x+1)(x-1)}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, it is known that we can split this up into two fractions, one with a base of  \\( x+1\\, \\)  and the other with base  \\( x-1\\, \\) .  Let\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{(x+1)(x-1)}}={\\frac  {A}{x+1}}+{\\frac  {B}{x-1}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nMultiplying to get a common denominator and equating numerators gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( 1=A(x-1)+B(x+1)\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nHere, notice that this decomposition must be true for all  \\( x\\, \\)  so we can solve for  \\( A\\, \\)  and  \\( B\\, \\)  easily by picking values for  \\( x\\, \\) .\n<br /><br />\nLet  \\( x=1\\, \\) , then  \\( 1=A(0)+B(2)\\, \\)  which gives  \\( B={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) <br />\nLet  \\( x=-1\\, \\) , then  \\( 1=A(-2)+B(0)\\, \\)  which gives  \\( A=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo our integral becomes\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {1}{x^{2}-1}}\\,dx=\\int \\left[{\\frac  {-{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{x+1}}+{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{x-1}}\\right]\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis is now an integral for which we have a formula.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int \\left[{\\frac  {-{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{x+1}}+{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{x-1}}\\right]\\,dx=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |x+1|+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |x-1|+C\\, \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.084 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.273 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 58/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 384/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31062-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030702 and revision id 33143\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nAgain, this problem is a <b>Partial Fractions</b> problem.  Let\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)}}={\\frac  {A}{x+1}}+{\\frac  {B}{x+2}}+{\\frac  {C}{x+3}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, multiply through to get common denominators and equate the numerators.\n<br /><br />\n \\( 1=A(x+2)(x+3)+B(x+1)(x+3)+C(x+1)(x+2)\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nPick values of  \\( x\\, \\)  to cancel out all but one term.\n<br /><br />\nLet  \\( x=-1\\, \\) , then  \\( 1=2A\\, \\)  or  \\( A={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) \n<br />\nLet  \\( x=-2\\, \\) , then  \\( 1=-B\\, \\)  or  \\( B=-1\\, \\) \n<br />\nLet  \\( x=-3\\, \\) , then  \\( 1=2C\\, \\)  or  \\( C={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus our integral becomes\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)}}\\,dx=\\int \\left({\\frac  {0.5}{x+1}}-{\\frac  {1}{x+2}}+{\\frac  {0.5}{x+3}}\\right)\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |x+1|-\\ln |x+2|+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |x+3|+C\\, \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.068 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.212 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 43/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 284/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31063-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030703 and revision id 33145\n -->\n",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Partial Fractions,Partial,Fractions,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( {\\frac  {x!}{(x+n)!}} \\) <br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{(x+1)(x+2)(x+3)...(x+n)}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {A_{1}}{x+1}}+{\\frac  {A_{2}}{x+2}}+{\\frac  {A_{3}}{x+3}}+...+{\\frac  {A_{n}}{x+n}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Multiplying through to create a common denominator then equating the numerators:\n<br /><br />\n \\( 1={A_{1}}(x+2)(x+3)...(x+n)+{A_{2}}(x+1)(x+3)+...+(x+n)+{A_{3}}(x+1)(x+2)...(x+n)+...+{A_{n}}(x+1)(x+2)+...+(x+n-1)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Pick values of  \\( x\\, \\)  to cancel out all but one term:\n<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x=-1,{\\mbox{ then }}1={A_{1}}(1)(2)(3)...(n-1)\\Rightarrow A_{1}={\\frac  {1}{(n-1)!}}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x=-2,{\\mbox{ then }}1={A_{2}}(-1)(1)(2)...(n-2)\\Rightarrow A_{2}={\\frac  {1}{(-1)(n-2)!}}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x=-3,{\\mbox{ then }}1={A_{3}}(-2)(-1)(1)...(n-3)\\Rightarrow A_{3}={\\frac  {1}{(-2)(-1)(n-3)!}}\\, \\) <br />\n</p>\n<dl>\n<dd><dl>\n<dd> \\( \\vdots  \\) <br />\n</dd>\n</dl>\n</dd>\n</dl>\n<p> \\( {\\mbox{ Let }}x=-n,{\\mbox{ then }}1={A_{n}}(1-n)(2-n)(3-n)...(-1)\\Rightarrow A_{n}={\\frac  {\\pm 1}{(n-1)!}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Thus the general term for  \\( A_{r} \\)  can be deduced:\n</p><p> \\( A_{r}={\\frac  {(-1)^{{r-1}}}{(n-r)!(r-1)!}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence  \\( \\int {\\frac  {x!}{(x+n)!}}\\,dx=\\int \\sum _{{r=1}}^{n}{\\frac  {A_{r}}{x+r}}\\,dx=\\sum _{{r=1}}^{n}A_{r}\\ln |x+r|\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{r=1}}^{n}{\\frac  {(-1)^{{r-1}}\\ln |x+r|}{(n-r)!(r-1)!}} \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.068 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.205 seconds\nPreprocessor         "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.17", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( \\int {\\frac  {x!}{(x+n)!}}\\,dx\\, \\) "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Partial Fractions,Partial,Fractions,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince  \\( 1-x^{2}=(1-x)(1+x) \\) , we can use the method of partial fractions to compute this integral.\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {x}{1-x^{2}}}={\\frac  {A}{1-x}}+{\\frac  {B}{1+x}}\\Rightarrow x=A(1+x)+B(1-x)\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince this is true for all values of  \\( x \\) , pick values which will cause one of  \\( A \\)  or  \\( B \\)  to cancel out to find the other.\n<br /><br />\nLet  \\( x=1\\, \\) , then  \\( A={\\frac  {1}{2}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nLet  \\( x=-1\\, \\) , then  \\( B=-{\\frac  {1}{2}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the integral is split up into two integrals\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {x}{1-x^{2}}}\\,dx=\\int {\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{1-x}}\\,dx+\\int {\\frac  {-{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{1+x}}\\,dx=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |1-x|-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |1+x|+C=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln |1-x^{2}|+C\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calc1.72\" title=\"Calc1.72\">Click here</a> to see this integral done by substitution.\n<br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calc1.68\" title=\"Calc1.68\">Click here</a> to see this integral done by trigonometric substition.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int {\\frac  {dx}{\\sin ^{2}(x)-\\cos ^{2}(x)}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This may look formidable, but it takes only a couple of steps to get this to a plain old partial fractions problem.\n</p>\n<table>\n\n<tr>\n<td> \\( \\int {\\frac  {dx}{\\sin ^{2}(x)-\\cos ^{2}(x)}} \\) \n</td>\n<td> \\( =\\int {\\frac  {\\sec ^{2}(x)\\,dx}{\\sec ^{2}(x)\\left(\\sin ^{2}(x)-\\cos ^{2}(x)\\right)}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =\\int {\\frac  {\\sec ^{2}(x)\\,dx}{\\tan ^{2}(x)-1}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =\\int {\\frac  {du}{u^{2}-1}} \\)  </td>\n<td> (making substitution  \\( (u=\\tan(x)) \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =\\int {\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left({\\frac  {1}{u-1}}-{\\frac  {1}{u+1}}\\right)\\,du \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left(\\ln \\vert u-1\\vert -\\ln \\vert u+1\\vert \\right)+C \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln \\left\\vert {\\frac  {u-1}{u+1}}\\right\\vert +C \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\ln \\left\\vert {\\frac  {\\tan(x)-1}{\\tan(x)+1}}\\right\\vert +C \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n",

        "solution": "<p>A ball is thrown straight up from the ground. How high will it go?<br /><br />\n</p><p>The height of the ball at time  \\( t\\, \\)  is  \\( x(t)\\, \\) , and the force acting on the ball is  \\( -mg\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Newton's second law gives the relation<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m{\\frac  {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+mg=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( m=1\\, \\)  for convenience.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+g=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate the last equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx(t)}{dt}}+gt+C=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To get  \\( C\\, \\) , start with an initial velocity  \\( v_{0}\\, \\)  and set  \\( t=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{0}+C=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So now,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}+gt-v_{0}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate again.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x(t)+{\\frac  {1}{2}}gt^{2}-v_{0}t+D=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Since we have set  \\( x(0)=0\\, \\) ,  \\( D=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The equation of position is <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x(t)=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}gt^{2}+v_{0}t\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To find the maximum, set the first derivative equal to 0.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( -gt+v_{0}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( t_{{max}}={\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Check that the second derivative at this point is negative.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x&#39;&#39;\\left({\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)=-g\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the answer is this point  \\( t_{{max}}\\, \\)  evaluated in the position function.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x_{{max}}=x\\left({\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)={\\frac  {v_{0}^{2}}{2g}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Calculus</a>\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.104 seconds\nReal         "solution": "<p>Find the area under the curve  \\( f(x)=x^{2} \\)  on the interval  \\( [-1,1] \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe main definition given for an integral in many undergraduate calculus textbooks today is one using a type of Riemann sums, that is summing up rectangles while making them smaller and smaller while adding in more and more of them until you have filled in all of the space and get the exact area under the curve.  Really, all that is saying is an integral gives you the area between a function and the x-axis on a given interval.  So, to find the area between this curve and the x-axis, all we need to do is take the integral on the interval.\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=\\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}x^{2}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe first step you can use to simplify this integral a tiny bit is to recognize that  \\( x^{2} \\)  is an <a href=\"/wiki/index.php?title=Even_function&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"Even function (page does not exist)\">even function</a>.  An even function is one for which it is true that  \\( f(-x)=f(x) \\)  for all x.  Since this is true, it has a symmetry about  \\( x=0 \\) .  Thus, the value of this integral on  \\( [-1,1] \\)  is simply twice that of the integral on  \\( [0,1] \\) .  In some cases, this is a great help; in others, not so much.\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=\\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}x^{2}\\,dx=2\\int _{{0}}^{{1}}x^{2}\\,dx={\\frac  {2}{3}}x^{3}{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{1}}={\\frac  {2}{3}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the area between the function and the x-axis, on the interval  \\( [-1,1] \\)  is  \\( {\\frac  {2}{3}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.75",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Area Under the Curve,Under,Curve,Applications of Integration,Applications,Integration", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the total area between the curve f(x)=cosx and the x-axis on the interval[0,2pi].\n<br /><br />\nHere, we have to be very careful.  The question asks for the total area between the function and the x-axis but if we simply take the integral,\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos x\\,dx=\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}=0 \\) \n<br /><br />\nnotice that we get an answer of 0.  This is because the integral counts area above the x-axis as positive and that below the x-axis as negative.  This problem contains an equal amount of area above and below the graph.  So, we need to split this up into a few integrals\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\cos x\\,dx-\\int _{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {3\\pi }{2}}}}\\cos x\\,dx+\\int _{{{\\frac  {3\\pi }{2}}}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos x\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNotice the middle integral has a negative sign out in front.  This is because the graph is beneath the x-axis on that interval.  Since the integral counts it as negative area, a negative sign in front makes it positive.  The two integrals without negative signs in front represent regions where the function is above the x-axis.  So, the area is\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}-\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {3\\pi }{2}}}}+\\sin x{\\bigg |}_{{{\\frac  {3\\pi }{2}}}}^{{2\\pi }}=(1-0)-(-1-1)+(0--1)=4\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus the total area between the curve  \\( f(x)=\\cos x \\)  and the x-axis on the interval  \\( [0,2\\pi ] \\)  is 4 square units.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the area under the curve  \\( f(x)=x^{3}+4x^{2}-7x+8 \\)  on the interval  \\( [0,1] \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIf you look at this function on a graphing calculator, you will see that it is always positive on the interval  \\( [0,1] \\) .  Thus, we need only one integral to find the area.\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=\\int _{{0}}^{{1}}(x^{3}+4x^{2}-7x+8)\\,dx=\\left[{\\frac  {1}{4}}x^{4}+{\\frac  {4}{3}}x^{3}-{\\frac  {7}{2}}x^{2}+8x\\right]_{{0}}^{{1}}={\\frac  {1}{4}}+{\\frac  {4}{3}}-{\\frac  {7}{2}}+8={\\frac  {73}{12}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the area between the graph and the x-axis on the interval  \\( [0,1] \\)  is  \\( {\\frac  {73}{12}} \\)  square units.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Using calculus, find the formula for the area of a rectangle.\n<br /><br />\nSay we have a rectangle of length  \\( a \\)  and height  \\( b \\) .  We know that the area is given by the simple formula  \\( A=ab \\)  but now that we know calculus we can derive this formula and many others.  Set up the rectangle so that it is completely in the first quadrant but has one edge against the x-axis and another up against the y-axis.  Then the area can be found by an integral\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=\\int _{{0}}^{{a}}b\\,dx=bx{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{a}}=b(a)-b(0)=ab\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, by calculus we can find the equation which gives the area of a rectangle.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Area Under the Curve,Under,Curve,Applications of Integration,Applications,Integration", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Derive the formula for the area of a circle with arbitrary radius r.\n<br /><br />\nMoving a cirlce does not change its area so let us position this circle so that its center is at the point  \\( (0,0) \\) .  Then the equation for this circle is\n<br /><br />\n \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=r^{2}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nIn finding the area of this circle, we will use symmetry.  If we find the area of the portion in the first quadrant and multiply this by 4, we have the area of the whole circle.  The equation of the upper half of the circle is given by solving for y and taking only the positive square root,\n<br /><br />\n \\( y={\\sqrt  {r^{2}-x^{2}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the area of this circle is given by 4 times the integral of this function while integrating over the x-values for the first quadrant.\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=4\\int _{{0}}^{{r}}{\\sqrt  {r^{2}-x^{2}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis integral can be done by trig substitution.  Let\n<br /><br />\n \\( x=r\\sin \\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dx=r\\cos \\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSubstituting gives\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=4\\int _{{x=0}}^{{x=r}}{\\sqrt  {r^{2}-r^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta }}(r\\cos \\theta )\\,d\\theta =4\\int _{{x=0}}^{{x=r}}r^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta =4r^{2}\\int _{{x=0}}^{{x=r}}{\\frac  {1+\\cos(2\\theta )}{2}}\\,d\\theta =2r^{2}{\\bigg [}\\theta +{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\sin(2\\theta ){\\bigg ]}_{{x=0}}^{{x=r}}=2r^{2}{\\bigg [}\\theta +\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta {\\bigg ]}_{{x=0}}^{{x=r}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, substituting back in to get the expression in terms of x gives\n<br /><br />\n \\( A=2r^{2}{\\bigg [}\\arcsin {\\frac  {x}{r}}+{\\frac  {x}{r}}{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {r^{2}-x^{2}}}}{r}}{\\bigg ]}_{{0}}^{{r}}=2r^{2}\\left[{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}+0-(0+0)\\right]=\\pi r^{2}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis, of course is the formula we expected to get.  For an arbitrary circle with radius r, the area is given by  \\( \\pi r^{2} \\) .  The formula for this shape and many others can be found using calculus.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.86",

Since the volume of a cone is given by the formula  \\( V={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\pi r^{2}h \\) , we should get a volume of  \\( {\\frac  {64\\pi }{3}} \\) .  Our axis of revolution is the x-axis so our radius function is a function of x.  Moreover, it is  \\( r(x)=x \\)  since the distance from our axis of revolution to the function is always x.  Thus, the volume is given by\n<br /><br />\n \\( V=\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{4}}x^{2}\\,dx=\\pi \\left[{\\frac  {1}{3}}x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{4}}={\\frac  {64\\pi }{3}} \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

Thus, we can find the volume by finding the volume of the solid generated by revolving  \\( 4x-x^{2} \\)  about the x-axis and subtracting the volume of the solid generated by revolving  \\( y=x^{2} \\)  about the x-axis.\n</p><p> \\( V=\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(4x-x^{2})^{2}\\,dx-\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(x^{2})^{2}\\,dx=\\pi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(-8x^{3}+16x^{2})\\,dx \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\pi \\left[-2x^{4}+{\\frac  {16}{3}}x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{2}}=\\pi \\left[-32+{\\frac  {128}{3}}\\right]={\\frac  {32\\pi }{3}} \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Volume,Applications of Integration,Applications,Integration", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the volume, on the interval  \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 3 \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is a square with side length  \\( x^{2}-9x \\) .\n<br /><br />\nFirst, think about finding the area under a curve.  We integrate the function to do this but essentially what we are doing is adding up an infinite amount of infinitely skinny lines and these lines (1-D objects) add up to give us the area.  The function we integrate gives us the length of the line.  It is a generalization of the formula A=l\\times h for a rectangle.  We get the infinitely many heights and we add them up over the length, the difference being that they vary.  This problem is very similar though it might seem very different.  Here, we are adding up an infinite amount of infinitely thin squares (2-D objects) and we will end up with the volume of the object.  The function we integrate will give us the area, which we then add up to get a volume.  Thus, the formula for finding a volume by cross-sectional areas is\n<br /><br />\n \\( V=\\int _{{a}}^{{b}}A(x)\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nwhere we are finding the volume on the interval  \\( [a,b] \\)  and where A(x) gives a formula for the area of a general cross-section.  Here, we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( V=\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{2}-9x)^{2}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nbecause the area of a square is equal to the square of its side length.\n<br /><br />\n \\( V=\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{2}-9x)^{2}\\,dx=\\int _{{0}}^{{3}}(x^{4}-18x^{3}+81x^{2})\\,dx=\\left[{\\frac  {1}{5}}x^{5}-{\\frac  {9}{2}}x^{4}+27x^{3}\\right]_{{0}}^{{3}}={\\frac  {4131}{10}}=413.1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo, the volume of this shape, whose cross-section is always a square with varying side length, is 413.1 cubic units.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the volume, on the interval  \\( 0\\leq x\\leq \\pi  \\) , of a 3-D object whose cross-section at any given point is an equilateral triangle with side length  \\( \\sin {\\frac  {x}{2}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIn an equilateral triangle, taking one side as the base, the height is the length of the perpendicular bisector to that side.  If  \\( y \\)  is the side length in an equilateral triangle, the length of a perpendicular bisector is given by  \\( {\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}}y \\) .  So the area of a given equilateral triangle in this problem is given by  \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}}{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}}\\sin ^{2}\\left({\\frac  {x}{2}}\\right) \\) .  To find the volume, we integrate the area over the interval.  Thus\n<br /><br />\n \\( V=\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{4}}\\sin ^{2}\\left({\\frac  {x}{2}}\\right)\\,dx={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{4}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {1-\\cos x}{2}}dx={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{8}}{\\bigg [}x-\\sin x{\\bigg ]}_{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{8}}[2\\pi ]={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}\\pi }{4}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the volume of this shape is  \\( {\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}\\pi }{4}} \\)  units.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

Since the area does not depend on x, it does not matter which interval we integrate over so long as it has a length of 10.  So the volume is\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{10}}9\\pi \\,dx=9\\pi x{\\big |}_{{0}}^{{10}}=90\\pi \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the volume is  \\( 90\\pi  \\)  cubic units.         "solution": "<p>Calculate the arc length of the curve  \\( y=x^{2} \\)  from  \\( x=0 \\)  to  \\( x=4 \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>We calculate using the general formula for arc length:\n</p><p> \\( L=\\int _{0}^{4}{\\sqrt  {1+\\left({\\frac  {dy}{dx}}\\right)^{2}}}\\,dx=\\int _{0}^{4}{\\sqrt  {1+(2x)^{2}}}\\,dx \\) . We need to use a trig substitution on this&#160;; namely, let  \\( 2x=\\tan \\theta  \\) , so  \\( 2\\,dx=\\sec ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta  \\) . Calculate the antiderivative first:\n</p><p> \\( \\int {\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}\\,dx=\\int {\\sqrt  {1+\\tan ^{2}\\theta }}\\cdot {\\frac  {1}{2}}\\sec ^{2}\\theta \\,d\\theta =\\int {\\frac  {1}{2}}\\sec ^{3}\\theta \\,d\\theta ={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left(\\tan \\theta \\,\\sec \\theta +\\ln |\\tan \\theta +\\sec \\theta |\\right) \\) .\nWe substitute for  \\( x \\)  to get  \\( \\int {\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left(2x{\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}+\\ln |2x+{\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}|\\right)+C \\) .\n</p><p>Then  \\( L=\\int _{0}^{4}{\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}\\,dx=\\left.{\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left(2x{\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}+\\ln |2x+{\\sqrt  {1+4x^{2}}}|\\right)\\right|_{{x=0}}^{4}={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left(8{\\sqrt  {65}}+\\ln(8+{\\sqrt  {65}})\\right) \\) .\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.052 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.150 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 31/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 204/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31313-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030726 and revision id 34013\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p>Determine the arc length of the curve given by x = t cos t , y = t sin t from t=0 <br /><br />\n</p><p>We have a parametrization of the curve as  \\( x=t\\cos t,\\,y=t\\sin t \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=\\cos t-t\\sin t,\\,{\\dot  {y}}=\\sin t+t\\cos t \\) <br /><br />\n \\( ({\\dot  {x}})^{2}+({\\dot  {y}})^{2}=(\\cos t-t\\sin t)^{2}+(\\sin t+t\\cos t)^{2}=(\\cos ^{2}t-2t\\cos t\\sin t+t^{2}\\sin ^{2}t)+(\\sin ^{2}t+2t\\sin t\\cos t+t^{2}\\cos ^{2}t) \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =\\cos ^{2}t+\\sin ^{2}t+t^{2}\\sin ^{2}t+t^{2}\\cos ^{2}t=1+t^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In order to integrate we now need a substitution: Let  \\( t=\\cosh u\\Rightarrow dt=\\sinh u\\,du,{\\sqrt  {1+t^{2}}}=\\sinh u \\) <br /><br />\nHence  \\( L=\\int _{{\\operatorname {arcosh}0}}^{{\\operatorname {arcosh}u}}\\sinh ^{2}u\\,du=\\left[{\\frac  {\\sinh 2u-2u}{4}}\\right]_{{\\operatorname {arcosh}0}}^{{\\operatorname {arcosh}u}}=\\left[{\\frac  {2t{\\sqrt  {1+t^{2}}}-2\\operatorname {arcosh}\\,t}{4}}\\right]_{0}^{t}={\\frac  {1}{2}}t{\\sqrt  {1+t^{2}}}-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\operatorname {arcosh}\\,t \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.040 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.101 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 19/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 124/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33067-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030728 and revision id 38409\n -->\n",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the average value of the function  \\( f(x)=e^{{2x}} \\)  on the interval  \\( [0,4] \\) .\n<br /><br />\nAn integral gives us the total value of a function over an interval.  If we then take this and divide it by the length of the interval, then we attain the average value of the function on the interval.  Thus the average value of a function on an interval [a,b] is given by\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{b-a}}\\int _{{a}}^{{b}}f(x)\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nFor this specific function, we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{4-0}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4}}e^{{2x}}\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left[{\\frac  {1}{2}}e^{{2x}}\\right]_{{0}}^{{4}}={\\frac  {1}{8}}\\left[e^{8}-1\\right]\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the average value of  \\( f(x) \\)  on the interval  \\( [0,4] \\)  is  \\( {\\frac  {1}{8}}\\left[e^{8}-1\\right] \\) .  Though the function increases rapidly and thus is different on every interval, its average value per 1 unit, on this interval, is about 372.49.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

Then divide this value by the length of the interval to find the average value of the function on the interval.
