        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Mean Value Theorem,Value,Theorem,Applications of Integration,Applications,Integration", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the average speed of a car, starting at time 0, if it drives for 5 hours and its speed at time t (in hours) is given by  \\( s(t)=5t^{2}+7t+e^{t} \\)  in miles per hour.\n<br /><br />\nThis problem is done just like any other average value problem.  Integrating the speed function over the interval gives the total distance traveled since s'(t)=x(t).  Dividing this by the length of the interval gives you the distance traveled in 1 hour, which gives you the average speed per hour.  Thus the average speed is\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{5}}\\int _{{0}}^{{5}}5t^{2}+7t+e^{t}\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{5}}\\left[{\\frac  {5}{3}}t^{3}+{\\frac  {7}{2}}t^{2}+e^{t}\\right]_{{0}}^{{5}}={\\frac  {1}{5}}\\left[{\\frac  {5}{3}}5^{3}+{\\frac  {7}{2}}5^{2}+e^{5}-1\\right]={\\frac  {1769+6e^{5}}{30}}\\approx 88.65\\, \\)  mph\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc1.80",

        "solution": "<p>We wish to show that there is a c in (a,b) such that  \\( f&#39;(c)={\\frac  {f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}} \\) <br /><br />\nFrom Rolle's theorem we have that if  \\( f(a)=f(b) \\) , then there is a c in (a,b) such that  \\( f&#39;(c)=0 \\) <br /><br />\nConsider  \\( h(x)=[b-a]f(x)-[f(b)-f(a)]x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( h(b)=[b-a]f(b)-[f(b)-f(a)]b=bf(a)-af(b)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( h(a)=[b-a]f(a)-[f(b)-f(a)]a=bf(a)-af(b)\\, \\) <br /><br />\nSo  \\( h(a)=h(b) \\) <br /><br />\nWe can apply Rolle's Theorem to h: <br />  \\( h&#39;(c)=[b-a]f&#39;(c)-[f(b)-f(a)]=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( \\Rightarrow f&#39;(c)={\\frac  {f(b)-f(a)}{b-a}} \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.052 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.147 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 28/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 184/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33069-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128030734 and revision id 38401\n -->\n",

The first series,  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}} \\) , diverges by the integral test (which we have not learned at this point) and the second series,  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}}} \\) , converges also by the integral test.         "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {3^{{n+1}}}{7^{n}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis is not quite in the same form as our formula but it is a geometric series in a slight disguise.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {3^{{n+1}}}{7^{n}}}=3\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left({\\frac  {3}{7}}\\right)^{n}=3{\\frac  {1}{1-{\\frac  {3}{7}}}}={\\frac  {21}{4}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo, this geometric series, with common ratio  \\( {\\frac  {3}{7}} \\) , converges to  \\( {\\frac  {21}{4}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

This is a geometric series though.  Remember the formula\n<br /><br />\n \\( a^{{mn}}=\\left(a^{m}\\right)^{n}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo here we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left({\\frac  {1}{3}}\\right)^{{2n}}=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[\\left({\\frac  {1}{3}}\\right)^{2}\\right]^{n}=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left({\\frac  {1}{9}}\\right)^{{n}}={\\frac  {1}{1-{\\frac  {1}{9}}}}={\\frac  {9}{8}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n+1}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nSince the terms of this sequence are positive and decreasing, we can use the integral test to see if the series converges.  If the integral\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{x+1}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nconverges or diverges, then this sum will do the same.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{x+1}}\\,dx=\\ln |n+1|{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}=\\infty \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, this integral diverges.  By the integral test, this series also diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}e^{{-3n}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nAgain, use the integral test.  Notice that the integral test states the series starts at  \\( n=1 \\)  and this series starts at  \\( n=0 \\) .  This does not change the fact that the integral test works.  One extra term, or a million for that matter, will not change the convergence or divergence of a series.  The one thing you must test is to make sure the function is continuous on the entire interval.  For example,  \\( {\\frac  {1}{n}} \\)  is undefined when  \\( n=0 \\)  so starting such a series at 0 would not work.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{\\infty }}e^{{-3x}}\\,dx=-{\\frac  {1}{3}}e^{{-3x}}{\\bigg |}_{{0}}^{{\\infty }}=0-\\left(-{\\frac  {1}{3}}e^{{-3\\times 0}}\\right)={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis integral converges to a real number.  Since this function is continuous, positive, and decreasing, by the integral test, our series also converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n}{e^{n}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nWe can use the integral test on this one because the function is continuous, positive, and decreasing.  To do the integral, we will use integration by parts.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {x}{e^{x}}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( u=x\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( du=dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( dv=e^{{-x}}\\,dx\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( v=-e^{{-x}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {x}{e^{x}}}\\,dx=-xe^{{-x}}+\\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}e^{{-x}}\\,dx=\\left[-xe^{{-x}}-e^{{-x}}\\right]_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nTaking the limit as  \\( x\\rightarrow \\infty  \\)  and plugging in 1 gives\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {x}{e^{x}}}\\,dx={\\frac  {-2}{e}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, by the integral test, since this converges, the series also converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Explain why the integral test is or is not applicable to  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}n^{2} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe function  \\( f(x)=x^{2} \\)  is positive and continuous on the interval  \\( [1,\\infty ] \\) .  However, it is increasing whereas the integral test only works on functions which are decreasing.  The divergence of this series, though, is easily established.  Any continuous function which is positive and increasing can not go to 0.  If the terms of a series do not go to 0, then the series diverges by the nth term test.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Explain why the integral test is or is not applicable to  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}-{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe integral test states a function must be continuous, positive, and decreasing.  This function is continuous but it is negative and increasing.  However, we can easily use the integral test.  Instead, look at the function  \\( f(x)={\\frac  {1}{x^{2}}} \\) .  This function is continuous, positive, and decreasing on the interval  \\( [1,\\infty ] \\)  so the integral test applies.  In fact, the integral test confirms that its series converges.  Thus, since this series converges, multiplying every term by -1 will simply change the sign of the sum but will not affect convergence at all and this is all we need to show to know that the given series converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Explain why the integral test is or is not applicable to  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {|\\sin n|+1}{\\ln(n+1)}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis series contains terms which are all positive since the numerator and denominator are always positive.  This function is also always continuous, though it has many sharp turns.  However, this function is never decreasing.  The sine function causes this series to continually increase for a short while and then decrease for a short while, increase for a short while and then decrease for a short while, and so on.  Thus, we can not use the integral test on this series.  However, the direct comparison test shows us that this series diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Integral Test,Integral,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{p}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis type of series is called a p-series.  The idea of this problem is to find which values of p give us a convergent series and which values of p give us a divergent series.  When we have that info, we can find the convergence or divergence of any p-series without having to calculate hundreds of different integrals separately, simply by knowing the value of p.  Use the integral test to determine convergence and divergence.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\int _{{1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{x^{p}}}={\\frac  {x^{{-p+1}}}{-p+1}}{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}={\\frac  {1}{1-p}}{\\frac  {1}{x^{{p-1}}}}{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }} \\) \n<br /><br />\nFirst, if  \\( p=1 \\)  the integral yields\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\ln |x|{\\bigg |}_{{1}}^{{\\infty }}=\\lim _{{b\\to \\infty }}\\lim _{{a\\to 1^{+}}}\\left(\\ln b-\\ln a\\right)=\\lim _{{b\\to \\infty }}\\lim _{{a\\to 1^{+}}}\\ln {\\frac  {b}{a}}=\\infty \\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo, when  \\( p=1 \\)  the integral diverges.\n<br /><br />\nIf  \\( p&gt;1 \\)  the integral converges because as  \\( x\\rightarrow \\infty  \\)  the integral goes to  \\( 0 \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIf  \\( p&lt;1 \\)  the integral diverges because as  \\( x\\rightarrow \\infty  \\)  the integral goes to  \\( \\infty  \\) .\n<br /><br />\nSo, by the integral test, the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{p}}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nconverges when  \\( p&gt;1 \\)  and diverges otherwise, for any real p.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.8", 
        "problem": "Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{p}}} \\) ."

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}+4}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}}} \\)  converges because it is a p-series with  \\( p=3&gt;1 \\)  and our series looks a lot like this series so we would think that is also converges.  Thankfully we have the direct comparison test so that we can test our series with other series with known convergence or divergence.\n<br /><br />\n \\( 0&lt;{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}+4}}&lt;{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}}} \\)  for all  \\( n&gt;0 \\) \n<br /><br />\nWe have a known convergent series with positive terms,  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}}} \\) , and its terms are all larger, term by term, than our series which also has positive terms.  Thus, by the direct comparison test, our series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}+4}} \\)  converges.  This makes complete sense.  If we have an infinite sum of positive numbers which converges to a finite number, then it makes perfect sense that another infinite sum of smaller positive numbers would not only converge, but converge to a smaller positive number.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

Since\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{n}}&lt;{\\frac  {1}{n-3}}&lt;{\\frac  {\\ln n}{n-3}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nso, by the direct comparison, our series diverges.  We can use the direct comparison test because our series has positive terms and so does the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}} \\) .  Again, this makes sense.  If we have a series with positive terms which diverges, then it goes off to infinity.  Another series with even bigger positive terms will clearly also go off to infinity.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

First, let us manipulate our series a bit.\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {2n^{2}}{4n^{4}+8n^{3}+3}}={\\frac  {1}{2n^{2}+4n+{\\frac  {3}{2n^{2}}}}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nWe can divide by  \\( n^{2} \\)  since  \\( n \\)  is never 0.         "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n+4}{(n+2)(n+1)}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nAnother comparison test we can use is the limit comparison test.  To do this test, we compare two series by looking at the ratio of their terms as  \\( n\\rightarrow \\infty  \\) .  If this term is a finite positive number, then both series either converge or diverge.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{n}}}{{\\frac  {n+4}{(n+2)(n+1)}}}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {(n+2)(n+1)}{n(n+4)}}=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince this is a finite, positive number, then both  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n+4}{(n+2)(n+1)}} \\)  and  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}} \\)  converge or both diverge.  We know that  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}} \\)  diverges so our series also diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.23",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Comparison of Series,Comparison,Series,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}\\sin {\\frac  {1}{n}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nLet\u2019s use the limit comparison test.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {\\sin {\\frac  {1}{n}}}{{\\frac  {1}{n}}}}=\\lim _{{k\\rightarrow 0}}{\\frac  {\\sin k}{k}}=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis limit is known to be 1.  If you do not see this, use L\u2019Hospital\u2019s Rule.  Thus, by the limit comparison test, since  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}} \\)  diverges, then our series also diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.24",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Comparison of Series,Comparison,Series,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n+1}{n\\times 3^{{n+1}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nLet us compare this series with the geometric series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left({\\frac  {1}{3}}\\right)^{n} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIf <i>r</i> &lt; 1, then the series converges.  If <span style=\"white-space:nowrap\"><i>r</i> &gt; 1,</span> then the series diverges.  If <span style=\"white-space:nowrap\"><i>r</i> = 1,</span> the ratio test is inconclusive, and the series may converge or diverge. Since in our case, <i>r</i> is equal to 1/3, the geometric series must converge.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{3^{n}}}}{{\\frac  {n+1}{n3^{{n+1}}}}}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {3n}{n+1}}=3\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, since this limit is finite and positive, both series converge or diverge.  Since the geometric series converges, then our series must also converge.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.25", 
        "problem": "Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n+1}{n\\times 3^{{n+1}}}} \\) ."
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Dirichlet's Test,Dirichlet's,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {\\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{2}}}{k}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nTo show convergence for this series we will use Dirichlet\u2019s test.  The terms of this sequence are the product of  \\( {\\frac  {1}{k}} \\)  and  \\( \\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{2}} \\) .  The first sequence of numbers decreases toward 0 as  \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty  \\) .  For the second sequence of numbers,  \\( \\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{2}} \\) , let us look at the partial sums\n<br /><br />\n \\( s_{n}=\\sum _{{k=1}}^{{n}}\\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{2}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe terms of the sequence are {1, 1, 0, 0, 1, 1, 0, 0, ...}.  Thus, this second sequence of numbers has bounded partial sums.  Since our series has terms which are a product of the terms of one sequence which decreases to 0 and another which has bounded partial sums, by Dirichlet\u2019s test, this series converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.51", 
        "problem": "Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {\\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{2}}}{k}} \\) .\n"
    },

        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Dirichlet's Test,Dirichlet's,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {\\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{3}}}{\\ln k}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nHere we have  \\( {\\frac  {1}{\\ln k}} \\)  which goes to 0 as  \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty  \\)  and  \\( \\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{3}} \\)  for which the sequence of partial sums is bounded.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\{s_{n}\\}=\\{\\sum _{{k=2}}^{{n}}\\sin {\\frac  {k\\pi }{3}}\\}=\\{{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}},{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}},0,-{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}},-{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}},0,{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}},{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}},...\\}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, by Dirichlet\u2019s test this series converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=7}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)^{k} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nWe can see that this series converges since it is a geometric series with common ratio  \\( {\\frac  {-1}{2}} \\)  and also because it is an alternating series with terms decreasing in magnitude.  But, to give another example for Dirichlet's test, we will show this series converges by it.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=7}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)^{k}=\\sum _{{k=7}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(-1\\right)^{k}\\left({\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)^{k} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis is in just the form to use Dirichlet's test.  The sequence of partial sums\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\{s_{n}\\}=\\left\\{\\sum _{{k=7}}^{{n}}\\left(-1\\right)^{k}\\right\\} \\) \n<br /><br />\nis bounded since it alternates between -1 and 0.  Also,  \\( \\left({\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)^{k} \\)  decreases to 0 as  \\( k\\rightarrow \\infty  \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThus, by Dirichlet's test, this series converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

Of the remaining n-2 values, the first half, a total of  \\( {\\frac  {n}{2}}-1 \\) , will give a positive value for sine and the second half will cancel those all out.  Thus, an easy to calculate bound (we just need to show that there is one, not find the least upper bound) is\n<br /><br />\n \\( 0\\leq \\{s_{n}\\}\\leq {\\frac  {n}{2}}-1 \\) \n<br /><br />\nsince sine can be at most 1.  If n is odd, this is only slightly different. If you can not see this, use  \\( L&#39;H{\\hat  {o}}pital&#39;s \\)  Rule.  First, in taking the limit as  \\( n\\rightarrow \\infty  \\) , we get  \\( {\\frac  {\\infty }{\\infty }} \\) .  Since this is an indeterminate form, it is likely that  \\( L&#39;H{\\hat  {o}}pital&#39;s \\)  Rule might be the way to find the limit of the terms.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\to \\infty }}{\\frac  {n^{2}}{e^{n}}}=\\lim _{{n\\to \\infty }}{\\frac  {2n}{e^{n}}}=\\lim _{{n\\to \\infty }}{\\frac  {2}{e^{n}}}=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, by  \\( L&#39;H{\\hat  {o}}pital&#39;s \\)  Rule, since the limit exists, this method gives us the correct limit.  The terms of this series go to 0 because the exponential function increases much more quickly than the power function.         "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}} \\)  including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally.\n<br /><br />\nThis series converges by the alternating series test.  The terms alternate and go to  \\( 0 \\)  and the absolute value of the terms decreases.\n<br /><br />\nBy definition a series converges absolutely if the series with terms that are the absolute values of the terms of the original series also converges.  In this case, the series we need to consider is\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}}\\right|=\\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{\\ln n}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nOne way to determine the convergence of this new series is the direct comparison test.\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{\\ln n}}&gt;{\\frac  {1}{n}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nWe know that the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}} \\)  diverges.  Thus, by the direct comparison test, since the terms of our series are all even greater than a series which diverges, our series must also diverge.\n<br /><br />\nWe say  \\( \\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}} \\)  converges conditionally because the series itself converges but the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}}\\right| \\)  diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.16", 
        "problem": "Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=2}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{\\ln n}} \\)  including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally.\n"

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Alternating Series,Alternating,Series,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}} \\)  including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally.\n<br /><br />\nWe can use the alternating series test here to determine that the series converges since the terms go to 0 and the absolute value of the terms decreases.  However, this series converges absolutely and any series that converges absolutely simply converges so let us just prove that this series is absolutely convergent.  To do this, examine the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\\right|=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nComparing this series to another, we see that\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{n^{2}+3n+4}}&lt;{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nand we know that the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}}} \\)  converges.  Thus, by the direct comparison test, the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}}\\right|=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}+3n+4}} \\)  converges and thus our original series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n^{2}+3n+4}} \\)  not only converges but converges absolutely.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.17",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Alternating Series,Alternating,Series,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence of  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{n!}} \\)  including whether the sum converges absolutely or conditionally.\n<br /><br />\nThe terms of the factorial function get very big very quickly.  So we would think this sequence would converge.  Let\u2019s look at the series which contains the absolute value of the terms of this sequence.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{n!}}\\right|=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n!}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nFor  \\( n&gt;3 \\) , we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{n^{2}}}&gt;{\\frac  {1}{n!}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nand we know that  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{2}}} \\)  converges because it is a p-series with  \\( p&gt;1 \\) .  Thus, the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n!}} \\)  also converges by the direct comparison test.  The first three terms do not change the convergence of a series.  Adding a finite number to a convergent series does not change it to a divergent series.  Finally, since this converges, we know that  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}}{n!}} \\)  converges absolutely.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.18",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Ratio Test,Ratio,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {2^{n}}{(2n)!}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nLet us use the ratio test.  It works well for series whose terms involve exponential functions and factorial functions.  We will compare the terms of the series with the terms right next to them, looking at the limit of this.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {a_{{n+1}}}{a_{n}}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {2^{{n+1}}}{(2n+2)!}}}{{\\frac  {2^{n}}{(2n)!}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {2}{(2n+2)(2n+1)}}\\right|=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo, since this limit converges to 0, by the ratio test, our series converges absolutely.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.38", 
        "problem": "Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {2^{n}}{(2n)!}} \\) ."
    },

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n}{3^{{n+1}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nLet us use the root test to see if we can conclude anything.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {n+1}{3^{{n+2}}}}}{{\\frac  {n}{3^{{n+1}}}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {n+1}{3n}}={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince this is a value between 0 and 1, our series converges absolutely by the ratio test.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis is a p-series with  \\( p=3 \\)  so we know that it converges.  However, let us see what happens with the ratio test.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{(n+1)^{3}}}}{{\\frac  {1}{n^{3}}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {n^{3}}{n^{3}+3n^{2}+3n+1}}\\right|=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nWith the ratio test giving us a limit of 1, we can make no conclusions by the ratio test.  Though we do know this test converges, the ratio test does not give us any information.  This is an example that shows us the different tests have their advantages and disadvantages.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

However, let us look at the ratio test once more.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{n+1}}}{{\\frac  {1}{n}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {n}{n+1}}\\right|=1\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nAgain, the ratio test is inconclusive for a p-series.  In fact, the ratio test is inconclusive for any p-series.  The previous example showed a p-series which converged and this shows a p-series which diverges.  The ratio test is inconclusive in both cases.  The integral test works well for p-series but the ratio test does not.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

Of course, the terms go to  \\( \\infty  \\)  since an exponential function increases more quickly than a power function so we also know it diverges by the nth term test.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n}{(n+2)!}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nOur instinct should be that this series converges since the factorial function on the bottom increases much more quickly than the simple linear function on the top.  The terms should go to 0 extremely quickly.  However, to prove this, we must use the ratio test.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {n+1}{(n+3)!}}}{{\\frac  {n}{(n+2)!}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {n+1}{n(n+3)}}\\right|=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, since this goes to 0, by the ratio test, this series does indeed converge and converge absolutely.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n4^{n}}{n!}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIt might not be obvious which grows faster, our numerator or our denominator.  The numerator is a linear function multiplied by an exponential whereas the denominator of our fraction is a factorial faction.  The ratio test will help us determine which grows more quickly.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {(n+1)4^{{n+1}}}{(n+1)!}}}{{\\frac  {n4^{n}}{n!}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {4(n+1)}{n(n+1)}}\\right|=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, the terms go to 0 which means the factorial function grows much more quickly than the linear function multiplied by the exponential function.  We also have shown, by the ratio test, that the series converges absolutely.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n^{k}a^{n}}{n!}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nSo here we have a power function of any order, k could be any number, 1, 100, 1,000,000, or even higher, and we also have an exponential function where  \\( a \\)  can also be any number as high as you want.  Yet, by the ratio test, we will show that a simple factorial function will eventually grow to be much greater than even the product of these two.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {(n+1)^{k}a^{{n+1}}}{(n+1)!}}}{{\\frac  {n^{k}a^{n}}{n!}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {(n+1)^{k}a}{n^{k}(n+1)}}\\right|=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe degree of the denominator is one greater than the degree of the numerator so this limit does go to 0.  Thus, by the ratio test, this series converges absolutely.  This also gives us the information that even a normal factorial function grows more quickly than the product of any power function even when multiplied by an exponential function.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Root Test,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n}{3^{n}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {n}{3^{n}}}}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {{\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}}}{3}}={\\frac  {1}{3}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince the limit is less than 1, by the root test, this series converges absolutely.  It is true that\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}}=1 \\) ,\n<br /><br />\nwhich we just used for this problem.  I will show this is true.\n<br /><br />\nLet  \\( y=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}} \\) .  From here, we can take the natural log of both sides, and in fact, on the right side, we can put the natural log on the inside of the limit.  This is the trick for finding this limit analytically.  So, we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\ln y=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\ln {\\sqrt[ {n}]{n}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}}\\ln n=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {\\ln n}{n}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nHere, plugging in infinity gives an indeterminate form so we can use L'Hopitals rule, provided the limit exists.  This gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\ln y=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {\\ln n}{n}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {{\\frac  {1}{n}}}{1}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{n}}=0 \\) \n<br /><br />\nSo, we have  \\( \\ln y=0 \\) .  Thus,  \\( y=1 \\)  as claimed.  Thus\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {(n!)^{n}}{(n^{n})^{2}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nTo use the root test on this, it will be convenient to rewrite what we have using the rules for powers.\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {(n!)^{n}}{(n^{n})^{2}}}={\\frac  {(n!)^{n}}{n^{{2n}}}}={\\frac  {(n!)^{n}}{(n^{2})^{n}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nNow, we can use the root test on this series easily.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {(n!)^{n}}{(n^{2})^{n}}}}}=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {n!}{n^{2}}}=\\infty  \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, since this limit goes to infinity, the series diverges by the root test.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Root Test,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac  {237}{50}}\\right)^{n} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis series looks tricky.  Instinctively, since we have  \\( (n+1)^{n} \\)  on the bottom, we should think this series is going to converge, even with the  \\( n! \\)  in the numerator.  But, let us use the root test to find out for sure.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac  {237}{50}}\\right)^{n}}}={\\frac  {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}}}={\\frac  {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {1}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {2}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {3}{n+1}}\\times \\ldots \\times {\\frac  {n}{n+1}}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis limit looks to be 0, and in fact it is, but how can we show that.  The trick is that as n goes to infinity, it can be arbitrarily large.  We know that\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {1}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {2}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {3}{n+1}}\\times \\ldots \\times {\\frac  {n}{n+1}}}}&lt;{\\frac  {237}{50}}K\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {n}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {n}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {n}{n+1}}\\times \\cdots \\times {\\frac  {n}{n+1}}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe thing here is that I can make K as small as I want.  For here, making it  \\( {\\frac  {1}{100}} \\)  suffices.  Since we are taking the limit as n goes to infinity, we can assume  \\( n&gt;10,000 \\) .  If this is true, then in changing  \\( {\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {1}{n+1}}}} \\)  to  \\( {\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {n}{n+1}}}} \\) , we multiplied by at least  \\( {\\sqrt  {10,000}} \\) .  So, we can bring a  \\( {\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {10,000}}}}={\\frac  {1}{100}} \\)  outside of the square root, though we can bring out an arbitrarily small number by assuming n is as big as we choose.  Thus, we have\n<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {237}{50}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{{\\frac  {1}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {2}{n+1}}\\times {\\frac  {3}{n+1}}\\times \\ldots \\times {\\frac  {n}{n+1}}}}&lt;{\\frac  {237}{50}}\\times {\\frac  {1}{100}}{\\sqrt[ {n}]{\\left({\\frac  {n}{n+1}}\\right)^{n}}}={\\frac  {237}{5000}}\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {n}{n+1}}={\\frac  {237}{5000}}&lt;1 \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, this series converges by the root test.  Also, note that the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac  {a}{b}}\\right)^{n} \\) \n<br /><br />\nconverges which we can prove easily by assuming n is even bigger and pulling out an even smaller constant to make up for any  \\( {\\frac  {a}{b}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.73", 
        "problem": "iscuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{n=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {n!}{(n+1)^{n}}}\\left({\\frac  {23}{50}}\\right)^{n} \\) .\n"

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Cauchy Condensation Test,Cauchy,Condensation,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{k}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nBy the Cauchy condensation test, we know that this series and the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{2^{k}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\neither both converge or both diverge.  Looking at this new series, it is clear to see that it diverges.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{2^{k}}}=\\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}1 \\) \n<br /><br />\nThe terms do not even go to 0 in this series, so by the nth term test, it diverges.  Thus, by the Cauchy condensation test, it is also true that our series diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.61", 
        "problem": "iscuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{k}} \\) ."
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Cauchy Condensation Test,Cauchy,Condensation,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{\\ln k}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThe terms of this series go to 0, but does it converge?  Using the Cauchy condensation test, it is true that this series and\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{\\ln 2^{k}}}={\\frac  {1}{\\ln 2}}\\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {2^{k}}{k}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nconverge or diverge together.  It is well known that the terms of  \\( 2^{k} \\)  increase much more quickly than the terms of  \\( k \\)  so we know that these terms do not go to 0, but instead increase to  \\( \\infty  \\)  and thus this series diverges.\nWe can prove this using the ratio test:\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\lim _{{k\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {{\\frac  {2^{{k+1}}}{k+1}}}{{\\frac  {2^{k}}{k}}}}\\right|=\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}{\\frac  {2k}{k+1}}=2\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\nSince this number is greater than 1, by the ratio test, this series diverges.  Since this series diverges, by the Cauchy condensation test, our original series also diverges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.62", 
        "problem": "iscuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{\\ln k}} \\) ."
    },

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Cauchy Condensation Test,Cauchy,Condensation,Series of Real Numbers,Series,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{k^{2}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nBy now, you probably know that this series converges since it is a p-series with p=2.  However, let us look at this series again using the Cauchy condensation test.  By this test, we know that our series and the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{(2^{k})^{2}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nconverge or diverge together.  It is easy to show that this series converges by simplifying it.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{(2^{k})^{2}}}=\\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{2^{k}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThis is just a geometric series with common ratio  \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}} \\)  and first term  \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}} \\)  which is well known to converge to 1.  Thus, this series converges and therefore the original series converges by the Cauchy condensation test.\n<br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/Calc6.63", 
        "problem": "iscuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{k^{2}}} \\) ."
    },

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {2^{k}}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nIn this problem, we will use the Cauchy condensation test in the opposite direction that we have been using it.  This series is already in the form\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}a_{{2^{k}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nwhich we get by a bit of simplification, or perhaps complication.\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {2^{k}}}}}=\\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{(2^{k})^{{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nThus, this series converges or diverges with the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{k^{{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis series converges because it is a p-series with p&gt;1.  Thus, our original series also converges.\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Discuss the convergence or divergence of the series  \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{(2^{k})^{n}}} \\) , where n is some real number.\n<br /><br />\nLet us multiply the numerator and denominator of this by  \\( 2^{k} \\) .  This gives us\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}{\\frac  {1}{(2^{k})^{{n+1}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis is the form\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}2^{k}a_{{2^{k}}} \\) \n<br /><br />\nand thus converges or diverges together with the series\n<br /><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{k=1}}^{{\\infty }}{\\frac  {1}{k^{{n+1}}}} \\) .\n<br /><br />\nThis, we know converges if  \\( n&gt;0 \\)  and diverges for any other value of n ( \\( n\\leq 0 \\) ) by the n-series test.  Thus, our original series converges if  \\( n&gt;0 \\)  and diverges if  \\( n\\leq 0 \\) .\n<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus,Calculus,Series of Real Functions,Series,Functions", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Evaluate  \\( \\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {m^{2}\\,n}{3^{m}\\left(m\\,3^{n}+n\\,3^{m}\\right)}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Solution:  First rewrite the summand as  \\( {\\frac  {m}{3^{m}}}{\\frac  {m\\,n}{m\\,3^{n}+n\\,3^{m}}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Then make the substitution  \\( a_{j}={\\frac  {3^{j}}{j}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Now call the sum  \\( S \\) , for notational purposes.<br /><br />With this notation it follows  \\( S=\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {1}{a_{m}}}{\\frac  {1}{a_{m}+a_{n}}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Then recognize  \\( S=\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {1}{a_{n}}}{\\frac  {1}{a_{m}+a_{n}}} \\) . Only here the indices have been reversed, first in name and then in order.<br /><br />\n</p><p>Adding the two previous expressions for  \\( S \\)  gives  \\( 2S=\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac  {1}{a_{m}}}+{\\frac  {1}{a_{n}}}\\right)\\left({\\frac  {1}{a_{m}+a_{n}}}\\right) \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>But  \\( {\\frac  {1}{a_{m}}}+{\\frac  {1}{a_{n}}}={\\frac  {a_{m}+a_{n}}{a_{m}\\,a_{n}}} \\) . So it follows that  \\( 2S=\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {1}{a_{m}\\,a_{n}}} \\)  which is equivalent to  \\( \\left(\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {1}{a_{m}}}\\right)^{2} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>So now all that is left is to evaluate  \\( \\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {1}{a_{m}}}=\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {m}{3^{m}}} \\) , and call this  \\( A\\, \\) .  Now it follows from  \\( A=\\sum _{{m=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {m}{3^{m}}}={\\frac  {1}{3}}+{\\frac  {2}{9}}+{\\frac  {3}{27}}+... \\)  that  \\( 3A=1+{\\frac  {2}{3}}+{\\frac  {3}{9}}+... \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Subtracting gives  \\( 2A=1+{\\frac  {1}{3}}+{\\frac  {1}{9}}+...={\\frac  {1}{1-1/3}}={\\frac  {3}{2}} \\) . So  \\( A={\\frac  {3}{4}} \\) , and since  \\( 2S=A^{2}\\, \\)  it follows that  \\( S={\\frac  {9}{32}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Calculus</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Determine the interval of convergence for the power series  \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {n(3x-4)^{n}}{{\\sqrt[ {3}]{n^{4}}}(2x)^{{n-1}}}}. \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Note  \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {n(3x-4)^{n}}{{\\sqrt[ {3}]{n^{4}}}(2x)^{{n-1}}}}=2x\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac  {3x-4}{2x}}\\right)^{n}n^{{-{\\frac  {1}{3}}}} \\) .\nUse the Ratio Test to check for absolute convergence:\n</p>\n<table>\n<tr>\n<td>  \\( \\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {a_{{n+1}}}{a_{n}}}\\right| \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\lim _{{n\\rightarrow \\infty }}\\left|{\\frac  {3x-4}{2x}}\\cdot {\\sqrt[ {3}]{{\\frac  {n}{n+1}}}}\\right| \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\left|{\\frac  {3x-4}{2x}}\\right|=\\left|{\\frac  {3}{2}}-{\\frac  {2}{x}}\\right|&lt;1 \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n<table>\n<tr>\n<td>  \\( \\Rightarrow -1&lt;{\\frac  {3}{2}}-{\\frac  {2}{x}}&lt;1 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\Rightarrow -{\\frac  {5}{2}}&lt;-{\\frac  {2}{x}}&lt;-{\\frac  {1}{2}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( \\Rightarrow {\\frac  {1}{4}}&lt;{\\frac  {1}{x}}&lt;{\\frac  {5}{4}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr>\n<td> </td>\n<td>  \\( \\Rightarrow {\\frac  {4}{5}}&lt;x&lt;4 \\) .\n</td></tr></table>\n<p>We need to check both endpoints for convergence as well. If  \\( x=4\\, \\) , then the power series becomes  \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {8}{n^{{\\frac  {1}{3}}}}} \\) . Note this is a  \\( p \\) -series with  \\( p&lt;1 \\) , implying divergence. If  \\( x={\\frac  {4}{5}} \\) , the power series becomes  \\( \\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {8}{5}}(-1)^{n}{\\frac  {1}{n^{{\\frac  {1}{3}}}}} \\) . This is an alternating  \\( p \\) -series, implying conditional convergence. Thus, the interval of convergence is  \\( x\\in \\left[{\\frac  {4}{5}},4\\right) \\) .\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Back to Calculus</a>\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Formulate an integral equation from the BVP:  \\( u&#39;&#39;+p(x)u&#39;+q(x)u=f(x),\\,\\,x&gt;a,\\,\\,u(a)=u_{0},\\,\\,u&#39;(a)=u_{1} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Solve for  \\( u&#39;&#39;\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u&#39;&#39;=-p(x)u&#39;-q(x)u+f(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate both sides from  \\( a \\)  to  \\( x \\)  with respect to a new dummy variable  \\( y \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{x}u&#39;&#39;(y)\\,dy=-\\int _{a}^{x}p(y)u&#39;(y)\\,dy-\\int _{a}^{x}\\left[q(y)u(y)-f(y)\\right]\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u&#39;(x)-u&#39;(a)=-\\left[p(y)u(y){\\big |}_{{y=a}}^{x}-\\int _{a}^{x}p&#39;(y)u(y)dy\\right]-\\int _{a}^{x}\\left[q(y)u(y)-f(y)\\right]\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u&#39;(x)=u_{1}-\\left[p(x)u(x)-p(a)u(a)\\right]+\\int _{a}^{x}u(y)\\left[p&#39;(y)-q(y)\\right]+f(y)\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate again. Notice how the limits of integration change.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x)-u(a)=\\int _{a}^{x}\\left[u_{1}+p(a)u_{0}-p(y)u(y)\\right]dy+\\int _{a}^{x}\\int _{a}^{s}u(y)\\left[(p&#39;(y)-q(y))\\right]+f(y)\\,dy\\,ds\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Fact:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{x}\\int _{a}^{s}f(y)\\,dy\\,ds=\\int _{a}^{x}f(y)(x-y)\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the last result becomes<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x)=u_{0}+\\int _{a}^{x}u_{1}+p(a)u_{0}-p(y)u(y)+\\left\\{u(y)\\left[p&#39;(y)-q(y)\\right]+f(y)\\right\\}(y-x)dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x)=u_{0}+\\int _{a}^{x}u(y)\\left[-p(y)+p&#39;(y)-q(y)\\right](y-x)dy+\\int _{a}^{x}u_{1}+p(a)u_{0}+f(y)(y-x)dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This equation is of the form  \\( u(x)=\\int _{a}^{x}k(x,y)u(y)\\,dy+F(x)\\, \\) , which is a Volterra equation of the second kind.<br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Approximate  \\( y(x)=x^{2}+\\int _{0}^{1}\\sin(xz)y(z)dz\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nOne method: Expand both  \\( \\,y(x) \\)  and  \\( \\,\\sin(xz) \\)  in \nTaylor series;  \\( \\,y \\)  in powers of  \\( \\,x \\) , and\n \\( \\,\\sin(xz) \\)  in powers of  \\( \\,xz \\) . We can save \nourselves some effort if we note from the integral equation that \n \\( \\,y(0)=0 \\) ; and from repeatedly differentiating the integral\nequation, that  \\( \\,y&#39;&#39;(0)=2\\, \\)  (so the coefficient of the \n \\( x^{2} \\)  term in the  \\( y \\)  expansion is 1), and that \n \\( \\,y^{{(2n)}}(0)=0 \\)  for  \\( n=2,3,\\dots \\, \\)  (because we get \nthe sine in the integrand for those terms). Thus, the Taylor series expansion \nfor   \\( \\,y(x) \\)  (about  \\( \\,x=0 \\) ) has the form \n \\( \\,y(x)=c_{1}\\,x+x^{2}+c_{2}\\,x^{3}+c_{3}\\,x^{5}+\\dots  \\) . <br /><br />\nThe expansion for  \\( \\,\\sin(xz) \\)  is \n \\( \\sin(xz)=xz-(xz)^{3}/3!+(xz)^{5}/5!+\\dots \\, \\) .<br /><br />\nInserting these in the integral equation, we get\n \\( \\,c_{1}x+x^{2}+c_{2}x^{3}+c_{3}x^{5}+\\dots =x^{2}+\\int _{0}^{1}(xz-{\\frac  {x^{3}z^{3}}{6}}+{\\frac  {x^{5}z^{5}}{120}}+\\dots )(c_{1}z+z^{2}+c_{2}z^{3}+c_{3}z^{5}+\\dots )\\,dz \\) <br /><br />\nor after some expanding and rearrangement (and subtracting the  \\( \\,x^{2} \\) \nterm from both sides)<br /><br />\n \\( \\,c_{1}x+c_{2}x^{3}+c_{3}x^{5}+\\dots =x\\int _{0}^{1}(c_{1}z^{2}+z^{3}+c_{2}z^{4}+c_{3}z^{6}+\\dots )\\,dz\\,-{\\frac  {x^{3}}{6}}\\int _{0}^{1}(c_{1}z^{4}+z^{5}+c_{2}z^{6}+c_{3}z^{8}+\\dots )\\,dz \\) \n<br />\n \\( +{\\frac  {x^{5}}{120}}\\int _{0}^{1}(c_{1}z^{6}+z^{7}+c_{2}z^{8}+c_{3}z^{{10}}+\\dots )\\,dz-+\\dots  \\) .<br /><br />\nAll of the integrals on the right side are readily evaluated.\nFor example, retaining only terms through  \\( \\,x^{5} \\) , we get<br /><br />\n \\( \\,c_{1}x+c_{2}x^{3}+c_{3}x^{5}=x({\\frac  {c_{1}}{3}}+{\\frac  {1}{4}}+{\\frac  {c_{2}}{5}}+{\\frac  {c_{3}}{7}})\\,-x^{3}({\\frac  {c_{1}}{30}}+{\\frac  {1}{36}}+{\\frac  {c_{2}}{42}}+{\\frac  {c_{3}}{54}})+x^{5}({\\frac  {c_{1}}{840}}+{\\frac  {1}{960}}+{\\frac  {c_{2}}{1080}}+{\\frac  {c_{3}}{1320}}) \\) <br /><br />\nEquating coefficients for each power of  \\( \\,x \\)  on the left and\nright sides gives a system of equations for the coefficients  \\( \\,c_{1},c_{2},c_{3}. \\) \nUpon solving that system, we get \n \\( y(x)\\approx 0.36361\\,x+x^{2}-0.038996\\,x^{3}+0.0014395\\,x^{5} \\) . Repeating\nthe calculation, this time including terms through  \\( \\,x^{7} \\) , gives \n \\( c_{4}=-2.7175\\times 10^{{-5}}\\, \\)  and leaves the lower-order coefficients essentially\nunchanged, evidence that the above approximation for  \\( \\,y(x) \\)  is quite good\nfor  \\( x\\in [0,1] \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Transform the BVP to an integral equation: \\( {\\frac  {d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}}+y=x,y(0)=0,y&#39;(1)=0 \\) </p>\n<p><br />\nFirst, integrate both sides from  \\( x \\)  to 1 (so that the boundary condition  \\( y&#39;(1)=0 \\) \ncan be applied). This gives<br />\n \\( y&#39;(1)-y&#39;(x)+\\int _{x}^{1}y(u)\\,du=\\int _{x}^{1}u\\,du={\\frac  {u^{2}}{2}}{\\Big |}_{x}^{1}={\\frac  {1}{2}}-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}} \\) \n</p><p>Applying the condition  \\( y&#39;(1)=0 \\)  and multiplying both sides by (-1) results in<br />\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(x)-\\int _{x}^{1}y(u)\\,du={\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}}-{\\frac  {1}{2}} \\) \n</p><p>Next, integrate both sides from 0 to  \\( x \\) :<br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\big (}y(x)-y(0){\\big )}-\\int _{0}^{x}\\int _{z}^{1}y(u)\\,du\\,dz=\\int _{0}^{x}{\\frac  {u^{2}}{2}}-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\,du=\\left({\\frac  {u^{3}}{6}}-{\\frac  {u}{2}}\\right){\\Big |}_{0}^{x}={\\frac  {x^{3}}{6}}-{\\frac  {x}{2}} \\) \n</p><p>or, applying the condition  \\( y(0)=0 \\) ,<br />\n</p><p> \\( y(x)-\\int _{0}^{x}\\int _{z}^{1}y(u)\\,du\\,dz={\\frac  {x^{3}}{6}}-{\\frac  {x}{2}} \\) \n</p>\nThe double integral may be simplified if we invert the order of integration.         "solution": "<p>Find the value of lambda for which the homogeneous Fredholm integral equation  \\( y(x)=\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{x}e^{t}y(t)dt\\, \\)  has a nontrivial solution, and find all the solutions.<br /><br />\n</p><p>First, divide both sides by  \\( \\,e^{x} \\) :<br />\n \\( {\\frac  {y(x)}{e^{x}}}=\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{t}y(t)dt\\, \\) <br />\nThe right side is a constant; therefore, the left side\nmust also be a constant. Thus  \\( {\\frac  {y(x)}{e^{x}}}=C \\) ,\nso  \\( \\,y(x)=Ce^{x} \\) .<br />\nInsert this in the integral equation:\n \\( Ce^{x}=\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{x}e^{t}Ce^{t}\\,dt \\) <br />\nSince we want a nontrivial solution, we may assume that\n \\( C\\neq 0 \\) , so divide both sides by \n \\( \\,Ce^{x} \\) ; this yields\n \\( 1=\\lambda \\int _{0}^{1}e^{{2t}}\\,dt \\) <br /> \nEvaluate the integral; this gives \n \\( 1=\\lambda {\\frac  {e^{2}-1}{2}} \\) <br />\nThus, a nontrivial solution exists only for \n \\( \\lambda ={\\frac  {2}{e^{2}-1}} \\) \nand the general solution in this case is \n \\( \\,y(x)=Ce^{x} \\)  where\n \\( \\,C \\)  is an arbitrary constant.\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus\" title=\"Calculus\">Calculus</a>&#160;: <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integral_Equations\" title=\"Integral Equations\">Integral Equations</a>\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.076 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.227 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 40/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 264/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31302-0!*!0!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128031909 and revision id 33989\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p>Solve:  \\( \\sin(x)=\\int _{0}^{x}e^{{x-t}}u(t)dt\\, \\) \n</p><p>Differentiate both sides with respect to x.\n</p><p> \\( \\cos(x)={\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\int _{0}^{x}e^{{x-t}}u(t)dt\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\cos(x)=\\int _{0}^{x}{\\frac  {\\partial }{\\partial x}}e^{{x-t}}u(t)dt+u(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\cos(x)=\\int _{0}^{x}e^{{x-t}}u(t)dt+u(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\cos(x)=\\sin(x)+u(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( u(x)=\\cos(x)-\\sin(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/IE18",

        "solution": "<p>Convert to an integral equation:  \\( y&#39;&#39;+y=\\cos(x),y(0)=0,y&#39;(0)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;&#39;=-y+\\cos(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{x}y&#39;&#39;(\\xi )d\\xi =\\int _{0}^{x}-y(\\xi )+\\cos(\\xi )d\\xi \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(x)-y&#39;(0)=\\int _{0}^{x}-y(\\xi )+\\cos(\\xi )d\\xi \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(x)=-\\int _{0}^{x}y(\\xi )d\\xi +\\left[\\sin(x)-\\sin(0)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{x}y&#39;(\\xi )d\\xi =-\\int _{0}^{x}\\!\\!\\!\\int _{0}^{s}y(\\xi )d\\xi ds+\\int _{0}^{x}\\sin(\\xi )d\\xi \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y(x)-y(0)=-\\int _{0}^{x}y(\\xi )(x-\\xi )d\\xi +\\left[-\\cos(x)+\\cos(0)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p>The solution is\n</p><p> \\( y(x)=-\\int _{0}^{x}y(\\xi )(x-\\xi )d\\xi +(1-\\cos(x))\\, \\) \n</p><p>To check the solution, start differentiating.\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(x)=-{\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\int _{0}^{x}y(\\xi )(x-\\xi )d\\xi +\\sin(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(x)=-\\int _{0}^{x}{\\frac  {\\partial }{\\partial x}}y(\\xi )(x-\\xi )d\\xi +\\sin(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(x)=-\\int _{0}^{x}y(\\xi )d\\xi +\\sin(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;&#39;(x)=-{\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\int _{0}^{x}y(\\xi )d\\xi +\\cos(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;&#39;(x)=-y(x)+\\cos(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y&#39;&#39;(x)+y(x)=\\cos(x)\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\int _{0}^{a}[\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\sqrt  {a^{2}-x^{2}}}}}xydy]dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now  \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{{\\sqrt  {a^{2}-x^{2}}}}}xydy\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( [{\\frac  {xy^{2}}{2}}]_{{0}}^{{{\\sqrt  {a^{2}-x^{2}}}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {x(a^{2}-x^{2})}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}}[a^{2}x-x^{2}]\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore, \\( I=\\int _{0}^{a}[a^{2}x-x^{2}]dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( [{\\frac  {a^{2}x^{2}}{2}}-{\\frac  {x^{3}}{3}}]_{0}^{a}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {a^{4}}{2}}-{\\frac  {a^{3}}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {a^{3}}{6}}[3a-2]\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>The limits of x are from  \\( -y\\, \\)  to  \\( {\\sqrt  {y}}\\, \\)  and y are from 0 to 2.\n</p><p>Therefore, \\( I=\\iint _{D}(1+x+y)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{2}[\\int _{{x=-y}}^{{{\\sqrt  {y}}}}(1+x+y)dx]dy\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now  \\( \\int _{{x=-y}}^{{{\\sqrt  {y}}}}(1+x+y)dx=[x+{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}}+yx]_{{x=-y}}^{{{\\sqrt  {y}}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( [{\\sqrt  {y}}+{\\frac  {y}{2}}+y{\\sqrt  {y}}]-[-y+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}-y^{2}]\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( [{\\sqrt  {y}}+{\\frac  {y}{2}}+y^{{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}+y+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}]\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence  \\( I=\\int _{0}^{2}[{\\sqrt  {y}}+{\\frac  {y}{2}}+y^{{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}+y+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}]dy\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( [{\\frac  {2}{3}}y^{{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{4}}+{\\frac  {2}{5}}y^{{{\\frac  {5}{2}}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}+{\\frac  {y^{3}}{6}}]_{0}^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( [{\\frac  {2}{3}}2^{{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}+1+{\\frac  {2}{5}}2^{{{\\frac  {5}{2}}}}+2+{\\frac  {8}{6}}]\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\sqrt  {32}}({\\frac  {1}{3}}+{\\frac  {2}{5}})+3+{\\frac  {4}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( 4{\\sqrt  {2}}({\\frac  {11}{15}})+{\\frac  {13}{3}}={\\frac  {44}{15}}{\\sqrt  {2}}+{\\frac  {13}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

    {
        "title": "Multivariable Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Multivariable Calculus,Multivariable,Calculus,Multiple Integrals,Multiple,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Here density  \\( f(x,y)=xy\\, \\) \n</p><p>Mass M= \\( \\iint _{R}f(x,y)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}\\int _{0}^{2}xydxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}[{\\frac  {xy^{2}}{2}}]_{0}^{2}dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( \\int _{0}^{4}2xdx=16\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( x_{c},y_{c}\\, \\)  be the centre of gravity of R then,\n</p><p> \\( x_{c}={\\frac  {1}{M}}\\iint _{R}xf(x,y)dxdy={\\frac  {1}{16}}\\int _{0}^{4}\\int _{0}^{2}x(xy)dxdy\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {1}{16}}\\int _{0}^{4}x^{2}[{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}]_{0}^{2}dx={\\frac  {1}{8}}\\int _{0}^{4}x^{2}dx={\\frac  {8}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y_{c}={\\frac  {1}{M}}\\iint _{R}yf(x,y)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}\\int _{0}^{2}y(xy)dxdy={\\frac  {1}{16}}\\int _{0}^{4}x[{\\frac  {y^{3}}{3}}]_{0}^{2}dx={\\frac  {1}{6}}\\int _{0}^{4}xdx={\\frac  {4}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Moment of inertia relative to x axis\n</p><p> \\( I_{x}=\\iint _{R}y^{2}f(x,y)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}\\int _{0}^{2}y^{2}(xy)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}x[{\\frac  {y^{4}}{4}}]_{0}^{2}dx=4\\int _{0}^{4}xdx=4[{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}}]_{0}^{4}=32\\, \\) \n</p><p>Similarly, \\( I_{y}=\\iint _{R}x^{2}f(x,y)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}\\int _{0}^{2}x^{2}(xy)dxdy=\\int _{0}^{4}x^{3}[{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}]_{0}^{2}dx=2\\int _{0}^{4}x^{3}dx=2[{\\frac  {x^{4}}{4}}]_{0}^{4}=128\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( I_{0}=I_{x}+I_{y}=160\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "problem": "Find the mass,coordinates of the centre of gravity and moments of inertia relative to x-axis,y-axis and origin of a reactangle  \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 4,0\\leq y\\leq 2\\, \\)  having mass density xy.\n"
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Multivariable Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Multivariable Calculus,Multivariable,Calculus,Multiple Integrals,Multiple,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>The tetrahedron is bounded below by z=0(xy plane) and bounded above by the surface  \\( z={\\frac  {6-6x-3y}{2}}=f(x,y)\\, \\) \n</p><p>The projection of R of this surface  \\( z=f(x,y)\\, \\)  onto the xy-plane is the triangular region,say OAB bounded by the lines x=0,y=0 and  \\( 6x+3y=6\\, \\) .         "solution": "<p>Because of symmetry,we need to compute the volume in the first octant only.Hence,if V is the total volume,then  \\( V=8\\iint _{R}\\int _{{0}}^{{c{\\sqrt  {1-({\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}})}}}}dzdydx\\, \\)  where R is the region bounded by the ellipse  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\)  in the first quadrant.Therefore,\n</p><p> \\( V=8\\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{0}}^{{b{\\sqrt  {1-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}}}}}c{\\sqrt  {1-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}}}dydx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( 8c\\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{0}}^{{b{\\sqrt  {1-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}}}}}{\\sqrt  {1-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}}}dydx\\, \\) \n</p><p>We shall first evaluate the inner integral,let  \\( I_{1}=\\int _{{0}}^{{b{\\sqrt  {p}}}}{\\sqrt  {p-{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}}}dy\\, \\)  where  \\( p=1-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Setting  \\( {\\frac  {y}{b}}={\\sqrt  {p}}\\sin \\theta \\, \\) ,we obtain  \\( dyb{\\sqrt  {p}}\\cos \\theta d\\theta \\, \\) ,then\n</p><p> \\( I_{1}=\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}({\\sqrt  {p}}\\cos \\theta )b{\\sqrt  {p}}\\cos \\theta d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( bp\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\cos ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( bp\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}{\\frac  {1+\\cos 2\\theta }{2}}d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {bp}{2}}[\\theta +{\\frac  {\\sin 2\\theta }{2}}]_{{0}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {bp}{2}}{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}={\\frac  {bp\\pi }{4}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>We therefore have\n</p><p> \\( V=8c\\int _{0}^{a}{\\frac  {bp\\pi }{4}}dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( 2cb\\pi \\int _{0}^{a}[1-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}]dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( 2cb\\pi [x-{\\frac  {1}{a^{2}}}{\\frac  {x^{3}}{3}}]_{0}^{a}\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( 2cb\\pi [a-{\\frac  {a}{3}}]\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {4}{3}}cab\\pi \\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {4}{3}}\\pi abc\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Mass= \\( \\int _{0}^{1}\\int _{0}^{1}\\int _{0}^{1}xyzdxdydz\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( \\int _{0}^{1}\\int _{0}^{1}[{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}}yz]_{0}^{1}dydz\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int _{0}^{1}[z{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2}}]_{0}^{1}dz\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {1}{4}}\\int _{0}^{1}zdz\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {1}{4}}[{\\frac  {z^{2}}{2}}]_{0}^{1}={\\frac  {1}{8}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Mass of the tetrahedron= \\( \\iiint _{V}\\rho dxdydz\\, \\)  where rho is the constant density of the substance.\n</p><p> \\( M=\\rho \\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{y=0}}^{{b(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})}}\\int _{{z=0}}^{{c(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}}-{\\frac  {y}{b}})}}dzdydx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( \\rho \\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{y=0}}^{{b(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})}}c(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}}-{\\frac  {y}{b}})dydx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( \\rho c\\int _{0}^{a}[(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})y-{\\frac  {y^{2}}{2b}}]_{{0}}^{{b(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})}}dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( {\\frac  {cb\\rho }{2}}\\int _{0}^{a}(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})^{2}dx={\\frac  {\\rho bc}{2}}{\\frac  {a}{3}}={\\frac  {\\rho abc}{6}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let x1,y1,z1 be the coordinates of the centroid.Then\n</p><p> \\( Mx_{1}=\\rho \\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{y=0}}^{{b(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})}}\\int _{{z=0}}^{{c(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}}-{\\frac  {y}{b}})}}xdzdydx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( \\rho \\int _{0}^{a}\\int _{{y=0}}^{{b(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})}}cx(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}}-{\\frac  {y}{b}})dydx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( c\\rho \\int _{0}^{a}[x(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})y-{\\frac  {xy^{2}}{ab}}]_{{y=0}}^{{b(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})}}dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>= \\( c\\rho b\\int _{0}^{a}x(1-{\\frac  {x}{a}})^{2}dx=\\rho bc{\\frac  {a^{2}}{12}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}={\\frac  {\\rho a^{2}bc}{12}}{\\frac  {6}{\\rho abc}}={\\frac  {a}{4}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Similarly, \\( y_{1}={\\frac  {b}{4}},z_{1}={\\frac  {c}{4}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "title": "Multivariable Calculus Practice", 
        "tags": "Multivariable Calculus,Multivariable,Calculus,Multiple Integrals,Multiple,Integrals", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>The given integral is  \\( \\iiint _{E}y^{2}x^{2}dV\\, \\) \n</p><p>Where E is the region bounded by the paraboloid  \\( x=1-y^{2}-z^{2} \\)  and the plane  \\( x=0 \\) \n</p><p>First, we'll set up the limits of integration. The bounds are a paraboloid along the x-axis intersected by the y-z plane. So, the limits are:\n</p><p> \\( -1\\leq y\\leq 1 \\)  \n</p><p> \\( -{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}\\leq z\\leq {\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}} \\) \n</p><p> \\( 0\\leq x\\leq 1-y^{2}-z^{2} \\) \n</p><p><br />\nSolve...\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}\\int _{{-{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}}}^{{{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}}}\\int _{{0}}^{{1-y^{2}-z^{2}}}y^{2}z^{2}dxdzdy\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}\\int _{{-{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}}}^{{{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}}}y^{2}z^{2}[x]_{{0}}^{{1-y^{2}-z^{2}}}dzdy\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{-1}}^{{1}}\\int _{{-{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}}}^{{{\\sqrt  {1-y^{2}}}}}y^{2}z^{2}(1-y^{2}-z^{2})dzdy\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nNow changing to polar cordinates, on the y-z plane:  \\( y=r\\cos \\theta ,z=r\\sin \\theta ,-y^{2}-z^{2}=-r^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>and for the limits of integration r = 1 and the intersection is the unit circle on the y-z plane so:\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\int _{{0}}^{{1}}r^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta {r^{2}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta (1-r^{2})rdrd\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\int _{{0}}^{{1}}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\sin ^{2}\\theta (r^{5}-r^{7})drd\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\int _{{0}}^{{1}}(r^{5}-r^{7})dr\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta [[{\\frac  {1}{6}}r^{6}]-[{\\frac  {1}{8}}r^{8}]]_{{0}}^{{1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta ({\\frac  {1}{6}}-{\\frac  {1}{8}})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{24}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p>NOTE THAT:  \\( \\sin ^{2}\\theta \\cos ^{2}\\theta =(\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta )^{2}\\, \\)  and  \\( \\sin(2\\theta )=2\\sin \\theta \\cos \\theta \\, \\)  by double-angle formula. Divide by 2 and square both sides\n</p><p>So that...  \\( \\sin ^{2}\\theta \\cos ^{2}\\theta ={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\sin ^{2}(2\\theta )\\, \\)  Plug this into integral.\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{24}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {1}{4}}\\sin ^{2}(2\\theta )d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{96}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2\\pi }}\\sin ^{2}(2\\theta )d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p>Substitute u=2<i>&#952;</i> so 1/2du=d<i>&#952;</i> and when <i>&#952;</i> = 2\u03c0 then u = 4\u03c0 and when <i>&#952;</i> = 0 then u = 0\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{192}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}\\sin ^{2}(u)du\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{192}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}({\\frac  {1}{2}}-{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\cos(2u))du\\, \\)  By half-angle formula\n</p><p>Factor constants and integrate term by term\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{192}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}{\\frac  {1}{2}}du-{\\frac  {1}{384}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}\\cos(2u)du\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{384}}[u]_{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}-{\\frac  {1}{384}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}\\cos(2u)du\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {\\pi }{96}}-{\\frac  {1}{384}}\\int _{{0}}^{{4\\pi }}\\cos(2u)du\\, \\) \n</p><p>Substitute v=2u so 1/2dv=du and when u = 4\u03c0 then v = 8\u03c0 and when u = 0 then v = 0\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\pi }{96}}-{\\frac  {1}{768}}\\int _{{0}}^{{8\\pi }}\\cos(v)dv\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\pi }{96}}-{\\frac  {1}{768}}[\\sin(v)]_{{0}}^{{8\\pi }}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\pi }{96}}-{\\frac  {1}{768}}[0]\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence... \\( \\iiint _{E}y^{2}x^{2}dV={\\frac  {\\pi }{96}}\\, \\) \n</p>\n<!--         "solution": "<p> \\( \\int _{{-2}}^{{2}}\\int _{{0}}^{{{\\sqrt  {4-y^{2}}}}}\\int _{{-{\\sqrt  {4-x^{2}-y^{2}}}}}^{{{\\sqrt  {4-x^{2}-y^{2}}}}}y^{2}{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}}}dzdxdy\\, \\) \n</p><p>The region of integration is a hemisphere along the positive x axis intersected by the y-z plane\n</p><p><br />\nIn spherical co-ordinates the region is given by:\n</p><p><br />\n \\( R={(\\rho ,\\theta ,\\phi ):0\\leq \\rho \\leq 2,-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}\\leq \\theta \\leq {\\frac  {\\pi }{2}},0\\leq \\phi \\leq \\pi }\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( x=\\rho \\sin \\phi \\cos \\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y=\\rho \\sin \\phi \\sin \\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z=\\rho \\cos \\phi \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\rho ^{2}=x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nSo..  \\( \\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(\\rho \\sin \\phi \\sin \\theta )^{2}(\\rho )\\rho ^{2}\\sin \\phi d\\rho d\\phi d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\int _{{0}}^{{2}}\\rho ^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\phi \\sin ^{2}\\theta (\\rho )\\rho ^{2}\\sin \\phi d\\rho d\\phi d\\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\sin ^{3}\\phi d\\phi \\int _{{0}}^{{2}}\\rho ^{5}d\\rho \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\sin ^{3}\\phi d\\phi [{\\frac  {1}{6}}\\rho ^{6}]_{{0}}^{{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {32}{3}}\\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\sin ^{3}\\phi d\\phi \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {32}{3}}\\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\sin \\phi (1-\\cos ^{2}\\phi )d\\phi \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {32}{3}}\\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta \\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}(\\sin \\phi -\\sin \\phi \\cos ^{2}\\phi )d\\phi \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {32}{3}}\\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta [\\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\sin \\phi d\\phi -\\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}\\sin \\phi \\cos ^{2}\\phi d\\phi ]\\, \\) \n</p><p>By u substitution let u = cos<i>&#966;</i> so then du = -sin<i>&#966;</i> d<i>&#966;</i> and when <i>&#966;</i> = \u03c0, u = -1 and when <i>&#966;</i> = 0, u = 1\n</p><p> \\( \\( {\\frac  {32}{3}}\\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}\\sin ^{2}\\theta d\\theta [2-{\\frac  {2}{3}}]\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {128}{9}}\\int _{{-{\\frac  {\\pi         "solution": "<p> \\( \\iint _{{R}}(x+y)e^{{x^{2}-y^{2}}}dA\\, \\) \n</p><p>where  \\( _{{R}}\\, \\)  is the rectangle enclosed by the lines\n</p><p> \\( x-y=0\\, \\)  \n</p><p> \\( x-y=2\\, \\)  \n</p><p> \\( x+y=0\\, \\)  \n</p><p> \\( x+y=3\\, \\) \n</p><p>For change of variables, Let\n</p><p> \\( u=x-y\\, \\)  and\n</p><p> \\( v=x+y\\, \\) \n</p><p>So then by solving for x and y we get...\n</p><p> \\( x={\\frac  {1}{2}}(u+v)\\, \\)   and\n</p><p> \\( y={\\frac  {1}{2}}(v-u)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 0\\leq u\\leq 2\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 0\\leq v\\leq 3\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{{0}}^{{3}}\\int _{{0}}^{{2}}(v)e^{{uv}}\\cdot |J|dudv\\, \\)     Where |J| is the Jacobian determinant\n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {\\partial (x,y)}{\\partial (u,v)}}=\\left[{\\begin{matrix}{\\frac  {1}{2}}&amp;{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\\\[6pt]-{\\frac  {1}{2}}&amp;{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\end{matrix}}\\right]={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac         "title": "Calculus of Variations Practice", 
        "tags": "Calculus of Variations,Calculus,of,Variations", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the path that minimizes the arclength of the curve between  \\( (x_{0},y_{0})=(0,0)\\, \\)  and  \\( (x_{1},y_{1})=(1,1)\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>The goal is to minimize arclength as  \\( x\\, \\)  goes from  \\( 0 \\)  to  \\( 1 \\) . This quantity is described in this integral:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{1}(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{1/2}}dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Euler-Lagrange_equations\" title=\"Euler-Lagrange equations\">Euler-Lagrange equation</a> is defined as:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( EL:{\\frac  {d}{dx}}{\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y&#39;}}-{\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y}}=0\\, \\)  where  \\( f\\, \\)  is the integrand in the integral above.<br /><br />\n</p><p>Compute the derivatives for the given problem.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y}}=0\\, \\)  since  \\( f\\, \\)  is independent of  \\( y\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y&#39;}}={\\frac  {1}{2}}(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{-1/2}}2y&#39;=(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{-1/2}}y&#39;\\, \\) <br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}{\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y&#39;}}=(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{-1/2}}y&#39;&#39;-(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{-3/2}}y&#39;^{2}y&#39;&#39;\\, \\) \n</p><p>Simplify the expression by factoring out  \\( y&#39;&#39;\\, \\)  and putting the common denominator  \\( (1+y&#39;^{2})^{{3/2}}\\, \\)  on the bottom.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( EL:{\\frac  {y&#39;&#39;(1+y&#39;^{2}-y&#39;^{2})}{(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{3/2}}}}={\\frac  {y&#39;&#39;}{(1+y&#39;^{2})^{{3/2}}}}=0\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p><p>This equation will hold only if  \\( y&#39;\\, \\)  is constant so that  \\( y&#39;&#39;=0\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>In that case, <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(x)=c_{1}x+c_{2}\\, \\)  and since  \\( y(0)=0,y(1)=1\\, \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( c_{2}=0\\, \\)  and  \\( 1=c_{1}+c_{2}\\, \\)  so that  \\( c_{1}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore, <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(x)=x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus_of_Variations\" title=\"Calculus of Variations\">Calculus of Variations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

<a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://roladarh.strefa.pl/news-1150.html\">movie quot quot</a> \noueltou\nFind the extrema of  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}\\, \\)  subject to the constraint  \\( x^{2}+2y^{2}-z^{2}-1=0\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Using <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Lagrange_multipliers\" title=\"Lagrange multipliers\">Lagrange multipliers</a>, make a new function:<br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n \\( f=x^{2}+y^{2}+z^{2}+\\lambda x^{2}+2\\lambda y^{2}-\\lambda z^{2}-\\lambda =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Take the partial derivatives of this function with respect to  \\( x \\) ,  \\( y \\) , and  \\( z \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>1)  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial x}}=2x+2\\lambda x=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n2)  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y}}=2y+4\\lambda y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n3)  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial z}}=2z-2\\lambda z=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>For each equation above, find a value of lambda that works and force that value into the other two equations. Choose the other two variables appropriately to satisfy the equalities.<br /><br /> \n</p><p>From 1),  \\( \\lambda =-1 \\) , and in that case  \\( y=z=0 \\) . Plugging into our constraint equation yields  \\( x=1,-1 \\) .<br /><br />\nFrom 2),  \\( \\lambda =-1/2 \\) , and in that case  \\( x=z=0,y=1/{\\sqrt  {2}},-1/{\\sqrt  {2}} \\) .<br /><br />\nFrom 3),  \\( \\lambda =1 \\) , and in that case  \\( x=y=0,z=i,-i \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Combining these results, the extrema are<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( (1,0,0),(-1,0,0),(0,1/{\\sqrt  {2}},0),(0,-1/{\\sqrt  {2}},0),(0,0,i),(0,0,-i)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The last two solutions may be disregarded if we are restricting to real variables.<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus_of_Variations\" title=\"Calculus of Variations\">Calculus of Variations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the maximum of  \\( xy^{2}z^{2}\\, \\)  subject to the constraint  \\( x+y+z=12\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Using <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multipliers\">Lagrange multipliers</a>, make a new function:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f=xy^{2}z^{2}+\\lambda (x+y+z-12)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Take the partials of  \\( f\\, \\)  with respect to  \\( x\\, \\) ,  \\( y\\, \\) , and  \\( z\\, \\)  and set them equal to zero.<br /><br />\n</p><p>1)  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial x}}=y^{2}z^{2}+\\lambda =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n2)  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial y}}=2xyz^{2}+\\lambda =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n3)  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial f}{\\partial z}}=2xy^{2}z+\\lambda =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This is a trick. Notice that if you multiply the last three equations by  \\( x\\, \\) ,  \\( y\\, \\) , and  \\( z\\, \\)  respectively and then add them, you can factor out a  \\( (x+y+z)\\, \\)  term that is equal to  \\( 12\\, \\) . So multiplying,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( xy^{2}z^{2}+\\lambda x=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( 2xy^{2}z^{2}+\\lambda y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( 2xy^{2}z^{2}+\\lambda z=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now add these equations to get<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 5xy^{2}z^{2}+\\lambda (x+y+z)=5xy^{2}z^{2}+12\\lambda =0\\, \\) . So,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\lambda ={\\frac  {-5}{12}}xy^{2}z^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug this value of lambda back into 1), 2), and 3) to get:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x={\\frac  {12}{5}},y={\\frac  {24}{5}},z={\\frac  {24}{5}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Calculus_of_Variations\" title=\"Calculus of Variations\">Calculus of Variations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",
