        "solution": "<p>Tangents are drawn parallel to the line  \\( y=mx\\, \\)  to touch the circles of the coaxal system  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2\\lambda x+c=0\\, \\) .Show that the locus of their points of contact is the curve  \\( x^{2}+2mxy-y^{2}=c\\, \\) \n</p><p>Given coaxal system  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2\\lambda x+c=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let P(x_1,y_1) be the point of contact. The equation of the tangent at(x1,y1) to the circle is\n</p><p> \\( xx_{1}+yy_{1}+\\lambda (x+x_{1})+c=0\\, \\) . equation be 2.\n</p><p> \\( (x_{1}+\\lambda )x+y_{1}y+(\\lambda x_{1}+c)=0\\, \\) . this equation be 3.\n</p><p>P lies on the given equation\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}+2\\lambda x_{1}+c=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Slope of 2 is\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {-(x_{1}+\\lambda )}{y_{1}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Given that 2 is parallel to  \\( y=mx\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {-(x_{1}+\\lambda )}{y_{1}}}=m\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\lambda =-(x_{1}+my_{1})\\, \\) \n</p><p>Substituting the value of lambda in 3,we get\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}-2x_{1}(x_{1}+my_{1})+c=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}^{{2}}+2mx_{1}y_{1}-y_{1}^{{2}}-c=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore, locus of P is\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+2mxy-y^{2}-c=0\\, \\) \n</p>",

equation is  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>The equation to the radical axis is\n</p><p> \\( 2gx+2fy+c=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Any circle of the coaxal system is\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+\\lambda (2gx+2fy+c)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let the equation of the circle cutting the system of coaxal circles orthogonally be\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+2ax+2by+d=0\\, \\) . the equation be {b}{a}})=2ak={\\frac  {ck}{g+kf}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore, the euquation to the orthogonal system is \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+y^{2}+{\\frac  {c}{g+kf}}+{\\frac  {ck}{g+kf}}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\(         "solution": "<p>Prove that the locus of the midpoints of the focal chords of the parabola  \\( y^{2}=4ax\\, \\)  is another parabola whose vertex is the focus of  \\( y^{2}=4ax\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Given the parabola is  \\( y^{2}=4ax\\, \\) . Let  \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  be the midpoint of a \nfocal chord.\n</p><p>Equation of the chord with  \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  as midpoint is \n</p><p> \\( yy_{1}-2a(x+x_{1})=y_{1}^{{2}}-4ax_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( yy_{1}-2ax=y_{1}^{{2}}-2ax_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Since this equation passes thtough the focus  \\( (a,0)\\, \\) , we have\n</p><p> \\( y_{1}^{{2}}=2a(x_{1}-a)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore, the locus of the midpoint is  \\( y^{2}=2a(x-a)\\, \\) \n</p><p>This is a parabola with vertex  \\( (a,0)\\, \\)  which is the focus of the given parabola.\n</p>",

        "title": "Geometry Practice", 
        "tags": "Geometry,Geometry,The Parabola,Parabola,Plane", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Prove that the locus of midpoints of chords of constant length 2l of the parabola  \\( y^{2}=4ax\\, \\)  is  \\( (y^{2}-4ax)(y^{2}+4a^{2})+4a^{2}l^{2}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( P(at_{1}^{{2}},2at_{1}),Q(at_{2}^{{2}},2at_{2})\\, \\)  be the two extremeties of the given \n</p><p>parabola sothat PQ=2l. let this be equation 1.\n</p><p>Let  \\( R(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  be the midpoint of the chord PQ.Then\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}={\\frac  {at_{1}^{{2}}+at_{2}^{{2}}}{2}}={\\frac  {a(t_{1}^{{2}}+t_{2}^{{2}})}{2}},y_{1}=a(t_{1}+t_{2})\\, \\) \n</p><p>From the above two equalities,we have\n</p><p> \\( y_{1}^{{2}}=a^{2}(t_{1}^{{2}}+t_{2}^{{2}}+2t_{1}t_{2})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y_{1}^{{2}}=a^{2}({\\frac  {2x_{1}}{a}}+2t_{1}t_{2})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( t_{1}t_{2}={\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}-2ax_{1}}{2a^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>From equation 1,\n</p><p> \\( 4l^{2}=PQ^{{2}}=a^{2}[t_{1}^{{2}}-t_{2}^{{2}}]^{2}+4a^{2}[t_{1}-t_{2}]^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 2l^{2}=a^{2}(t_{1}-t_{2})^{2}[(t_{1}+t_{2})^{2}+4]=a^{2}[(t_{1}+t_{2})^{2}-4t_{1}t_{2}][(t_{1}+t_{2})^{2}+4]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 4a^{2}l^{2}=(y_{1}^{{2}}-2y_{1}^{{2}}+4ax_{1})(y_{1}^{{2}}+4a^{2})\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,the locus of  \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  is\n</p><p> \\( 4a^{2}l^{2}+(y^{2}-4ax)(y^{2}+4a^{2})=0\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the lengths of major axis,minor axis,latus rectum,eccentricity,centre,foci,equations of directrices of the ellipse   \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{64}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{36}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Given ellipse is  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{64}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{36}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>From the equation,\n</p><p> \\( a^{2}=64,b^{2}=36\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( a=8,b=6,a&gt;b\\, \\) \n</p><p>Major axis is 16 and Minor axis is 12.\n</p><p>Latus rectum is \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {2\\cdot 36}{8}}=9\\, \\) \n</p><p>Length of the latusrectum is 9 units.\n</p><p>eccentricity  \\( e={\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {64-36}{64}}}}={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {7}}}{4}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Foci are  \\( (\\pm 8\\cdot {\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {7}}}{4}},0)=(\\pm 2{\\sqrt  {7}},0)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Equations of directrices are  \\( x=\\pm {\\frac  {32}{{\\sqrt  {7}}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\sqrt  {7}}x=\\pm 32\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the equations to the tangents to the ellipse  \\( x^{2}+2y^{2}=3\\, \\)  drawn from the point (1,2) \n</p><p>Any line through (1,2) with slope m is  \\( y-2=m(x-1),y=mx+(2-m)\\, \\) \n</p><p>This is a tangent to the given ellipse  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{3}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{{\\frac  {3}{2}}}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Condition for tangency  is  \\( c^{2}=a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( (2-m)^{2}=3m^{2}+{\\frac  {3}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 4m^{2}+8m-5=0,(2m+5)(2m-1)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( m={\\frac  {1}{2}},{\\frac  {-5}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>By substituting the values of m in the tangent equation,we get\n</p><p>Therefore,the equations of the tangents are  \\( x-2y+3=0,5x+2y-9=0\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n[Main page]]:<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Geometry\" title=\"Geometry\">Geometry</a>:<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Geometry#Plane\" title=\"Geometry\">The Ellipse</a>\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.060 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.151 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 25/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 164/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:31648-0!*!0!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128033754 and revision id 34801\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p>Show that the foot of the perpendicular drawn from the centre on any tangent to the ellipse lies on the curve  \\( (x^{2}+y^{2})^{2}=a^{2}x^{2}+b^{2}y^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The equation of the tangent at any point  \\( P(\\theta )=(a\\cos \\theta ,b\\sin \\theta )\\, \\)  is \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {x\\cos \\theta }{a}}+{\\frac  {y\\cos \\theta }{b}}=1\\, \\)  Equation 1.\n</p><p>Let  \\( M(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  be the foot of the perpendicular from the centre (0,0) to the \n</p><p>tangent,then Product of the slopes of PM and CM is -1.\n</p><p>Hence\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {y_{1}}{x_{1}}}\\cdot {\\frac  {{\\frac  {-\\cos \\theta }{a}}}{{\\frac  {\\sin \\theta }{b}}}}=-1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {x_{1}}{{\\frac  {\\cos \\theta }{a}}}}={\\frac  {y_{1}}{{\\frac  {\\sin \\theta }{b}}}}=\\lambda \\, \\)  (say)\n</p><p> \\( ax_{1}=\\lambda \\cos \\theta ,by_{1}=\\lambda \\sin \\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\lambda ^{2}=a^{2}x_{1}^{{2}}+b^{2}y_{1}^{{2}}\\, \\) . Equation 2.\n</p><p> \\( \\lambda ={\\sqrt  {a^{2}x_{1}^{{2}}+b^{2}y_{1}^{{2}}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,  \\( {\\frac  {\\cos \\theta }{a}}={\\frac  {x_{1}}{\\lambda }},{\\frac  {\\sin \\theta }{b}}={\\frac  {y_{1}}{\\lambda }}\\, \\)  Equation 3.\n</p><p>But M lies on the first line.\n</p><p>From 3,  \\( {\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{\\lambda }}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{\\lambda }}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore, from 2, \\( [x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}]^{2}=\\lambda ^{2}=a^{2}x_{1}^{{2}}+b^{2}y_{1}^{{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Henc the P lies on  \\( (x^{2}+y^{2})^{2}=(a^{2}x^{2}+b^{2}y^{2})\\, \\) \n</p>",

Let \n</p><p>its roots be m1,m2.Then,m1,m2 are the slopes of tangents from P to the ellipse.\n</p><p>Therefore, \\( \\tan \\theta _{1}\\tan \\theta _{2}=m_{1}m_{2}={\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( -1={\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}=a^{2}+b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,the point of intersection of perpendicular tangents to the ellipse lies on the circle \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the locus of the point of intersection of the two tangents to the ellipse  \\( b^{2}x^{2}+a^{2}y^{2}=a^{2}b^{2}\\, \\) ,which include an angle theta.\n</p><p>Given the ellipse  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( y=mx+{\\sqrt  {a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\)  be a tangent passing through a point \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) \n</p><p>Readjusting the variables,we have\n</p><p> \\( m^{2}(x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2})-2mx_{1}y_{1}+y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let the roots of the quadratic equation be  \\( m_{1},m_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Two tangents pass thro'P.If their inclinations are  \\( \\alpha ,\\beta \\, \\)  then  \\( \\tan \\alpha =m_{1},\\tan \\beta =m_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Given  \\( \\theta =\\alpha -\\beta \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\tan \\theta =\\tan(\\alpha -\\beta )\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\tan \\theta ={\\frac  {\\tan \\alpha -\\tan \\beta }{1+\\tan \\alpha \\tan \\beta }}={\\frac  {m_{1}-m_{2}}{1+m_{1}m_{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Simplifying, we get\n</p><p> \\( (1+m_{1}m_{2})^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\theta =(m_{1}-m_{2})^{2}=(m_{1}+m_{2})^{2}-4m_{1}m_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( [1+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}}]\\tan ^{2}\\theta =[{\\frac  {2x_{1}y_{1}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}}]^{2}-4({\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2}}{x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}}})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( (x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\theta =4x_{1}^{{2}}y_{1}^{{2}}-4(y_{1}^{{2}}-b^{2})(x_{1}^{{2}}-a^{2})\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,the locus of P is  \\( (x^{2}+y^{2}-a^{2}-b^{2})^{2}\\tan ^{2}\\theta =4x^{2}y^{2}-4(y^{2}-b^{2})(x^{2}-a^{2})\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Show that the two lines  \\( 9x+2y=1,3x+2y=11\\, \\)  are conjugate w.r.t the ellipse  \\( 3x^{2}+2y^{2}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( P(x_{1},y_{1}),Q(x_{2},y_{2})\\, \\)  be the poles of the two given lines w.r.t the ellipse.\n</p><p>The equation of polar of P is\n</p><p> \\( 3xx_{1}+2yy_{1}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Comparing this with  \\( 9x+2y=1\\, \\)  we get\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {3x_{1}}{9}}={\\frac  {2y_{1}}{2}}={\\frac  {1}{1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( (3,1)\\, \\) \n</p><p>The equation of polar of Q is\n</p><p> \\( 3xx_{2}+2yy_{2}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Comparing this with  \\( 3x+2y=11\\, \\)  we get\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {3x_{2}}{3}}={\\frac  {2y_{2}}{2}}={\\frac  {1}{11}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\left({\\frac  {1}{11}},{\\frac  {1}{11}}\\right)\\, \\) \n</p><p>The condition for the two lines to be conjugate is  \\( S_{{12}}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 3(3)({\\frac  {1}{11}})+2(1)({\\frac  {1}{11}})-1={\\frac  {9}{11}}+{\\frac  {2}{11}}-1={\\frac  {11}{11}}-1=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence the two lines are conjugate.\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>A chord PQ of an ellipse subtends a right angle at the centre of the ellipse  \\( S=0\\, \\) .Show that the point of intersection of tangents at P and Q lies on the ellipse \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}={\\frac  {1}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let the tangents at P and Q intersects at  \\( R(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) ,then PQ is the chord of tangents drawn from  \\( (x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore  \\( PQ={\\frac  {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>The equation of the pair of lines CP and CQ is obtained by homogenising the equation of S=0 with PQ.\n</p><p>The combined equation is  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=[{\\frac  {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}[{\\frac  {1}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}]-{\\frac  {2x_{1}y_{1}xy}{a^{2}b^{2}}}+y^{2}[{\\frac  {1}{b^{2}}}-{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}]=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>But angle PCQ is 90.\n</p><p>Therefore,the coefficients of square of x and square of y is equal to zero.\n</p><p> \\( [{\\frac  {1}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}]+[{\\frac  {1}{b^{2}}}-{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}]=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}={\\frac  {1}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence the point of intersection of tangents at P and Q lies on the ellipse\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}={\\frac  {1}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1}{b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "title": "Geometry Practice", 
        "tags": "Geometry,Geometry,The Ellipse,Ellipse,Plane", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Show that the equation of the auxiliary circle of the ellipse  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\)  is  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The equation to the ellipse is  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>The equation to the tangent of the ellipse is  \\( y=mx\\pm {\\sqrt  {a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}}},y-mx=\\pm {\\sqrt  {a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The equation to the perpendicular from either focus  \\( (\\pm ae,0)\\, \\)  on this tangent is given by  \\( y={\\frac  {-1}{m}}(x\\pm ae),my+x=\\pm ae\\, \\) \n</p><p>To find the locus of point of intersection of the above two equations,eliminate m from them.\n</p><p>Squaring and adding the two equations,we get\n</p><p> \\( (y-mx)^{2}+(my+x)^{2}=a^{2}m^{2}+b^{2}+a^{2}e^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}(1+m^{2})+y^{2}(1+m^{2})=a^{2}m^{2}+a^{2}(1-e^{2})+a^{2}e^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( (x^{2}+y^{2})(1+m^{2})=a^{2}(m^{2}+1)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore the locus is the auxiliary circle concentric with the ellipse.\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Tangents at right angles are drawn to the ellipse \\( S=0\\, \\) .Show that the locus of the midpoints of chords of contact is the curve  \\( [{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}={\\frac  {x^{2}+y^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let   \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  be the mid point of a chord QR of the given ellipse.\n</p><p>Equation to chord QR is  \\( S_{1}=S_{{11}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}={\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{2}}}=k\\, \\)  (say)\n</p><p>Let the tangents at Q and R to the ellipse meet at M.\n</p><p>Therefore coordinates of M are  \\( \\left({\\frac  {-a^{2}x_{1}}{a^{2}k}},{\\frac  {-b^{2}y_{1}}{b^{2}k}}\\right)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\left({\\frac  {-x_{1}}{k}},{\\frac  {-y_{1}}{k}}\\right)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Given that the tangents MQ and MR are perpendiculars.\n</p><p>Mlies on director circle  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}+b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{k^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{k^{2}}}=a^{2}+b^{2},k^{2}={\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( [{\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}={\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore the locus of P is\n</p><p> \\( [{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}={\\frac  {x^{2}+y^{2}}{a^{2}+b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the locus of the midpoints of chords of an ellipse,whose poles lie on the auxiliary circle.\n</p><p>Let the ellipse be  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( P(x_{1},y_{1})\\, \\)  be the midpoint of a chord AB of the ellipse.\n</p><p>Therefore,the equation to AB is  \\( {\\frac  {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}={\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{2}}}=k\\, \\)  (say)\n</p><p>The pole of the above line w.r.t the ellipse is\n</p><p> \\( Q\\left({\\frac  {-x_{1}}{k}},{\\frac  {-y_{1}}{k}}\\right)\\, \\) \n</p><p>But Q lies on auxiliary circle  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Hence,  \\( x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}=k^{2}a^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}^{{2}}+y_{1}^{{2}}=a^{2}[{\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,the locus of P is \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2}[{\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}]^{2}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>P is a point on the ellipse  \\( S=0\\, \\)  and Q is its corresponding point on the auxiliary circle. Prove that the locus of the point of intersection of the normals at P and Q is the circle given by  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=(a+b)^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Equation to the normal at  \\( P(\\theta )\\, \\)  on the ellipse is\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {ax}{\\cos \\theta }}-{\\frac  {by}{\\sin \\theta }}=a^{2}-b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>P1 is the corresponding point on  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=a^{2},P_{1}=1(a\\cos \\theta ,a\\sin \\theta )\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,equation to the normal to auxiliary circle is  \\( y=a\\tan \\theta \\, \\) \n</p><p>From the above, \\( \\tan \\theta ={\\frac  {y}{x}},\\sin \\theta ={\\frac  {x}{{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}}},\\cos \\theta ={\\frac  {y}{{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Eliminating theta from the equation of normal,we get\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {ax{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}}{x}}-{\\frac  {by{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}}{y}}=a^{2}-b^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( (a-b){\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}=a^{2}-b^{2},{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}=a+b\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,the locus of the first two equations is  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=(a+b)^{2}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the centre,eccentricity,length of latusrectum,foci,vertices and equations to the directrices of the hyperbola  \\( {\\frac  {(y-4)^{2}}{9}}-{\\frac  {(x-5)^{2}}{16}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>For the given hyperbola, \\( b^{2}=9,a^{2}=16,(h,k)=(5,4)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Centre is  \\( (5,4)\\, \\) \n</p><p>eccentricity   \\( {\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {a^{2}+b^{2}}}}{b}}={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {9+16}}}{3}}={\\frac  {5}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Length of latusrectum is  \\( {\\frac  {2a^{2}}{b}}={\\frac  {2(16)}{3}}={\\frac  {32}{3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Foci  \\( (h,k\\pm be)=(5,4\\pm 5)=(5,9),(5,-1)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Vertices  \\( (h,k\\pm b)=(5,4\\pm 3)=(5,7),(5,1)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Equations to directrices  \\( y=k\\pm {\\frac  {b}{e}}=4\\pm {\\frac  {9}{5}}={\\frac  {29}{5}},{\\frac  {11}{5}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( 5y-29=0,5y-11=0\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Prove that the locus of points the polars of which w.r.t the hyperbola  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\)  touch the circle  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=c^{2}\\, \\)  i f  \\( {\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}={\\frac  {1}{c^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The polar of P w.r.t the hyperbola given is\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {xx_{1}}{a^{2}}}-{\\frac  {yy_{1}}{b^{2}}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p>This polar touches the circle  \\( x^{2}+y^{2}=c^{2}\\, \\)  whose centre is (0,0) and radius c.\n</p><p>Hence\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {|-1|}{{\\sqrt  {{\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}}}}}=c\\, \\) \n</p><p>Squaring on both sides,\n</p><p> \\( 1=c^{2}({\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{c^{2}}}={\\frac  {x_{1}^{{2}}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y_{1}^{{2}}}{b^{4}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore,the locus of the polars is \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{c^{2}}}={\\frac  {x^{2}}{a^{4}}}+{\\frac  {y^{2}}{b^{4}}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

    {
        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Introduction", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>State and prove <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Gronwall%27s_lemma\" title=\"Gronwall's lemma\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Gronwall's lemma</a>.\n</p><p>Lemma: Let  \\( r(t)\\, \\)  be continuous for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\)  and satisfy the inequalities\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq r(t)\\leq \\epsilon +\\delta {\\Big |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}r(s)ds{\\Big |}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>for some non-negative constants  \\( \\epsilon \\, \\)  and  \\( \\delta \\, \\) . Then\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq r(t)\\leq \\epsilon \\exp \\left\\{\\delta |t-t_{0}|\\right\\}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Proof:\n</p><p>It is sufficient to consider the case  \\( t\\geq t_{0}\\, \\) . The proof for the other case is the same. Let\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( R(t)=\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}r(s)ds\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Then  \\( R(t)\\, \\)  is continuous and differentiable, and  \\( R&#39;=r\\, \\) . Hence the inequality takes the form\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq R&#39;\\leq \\epsilon +\\delta R\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Now multiply both sides by the non-negative function  \\( \\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\, \\) , so that\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq \\left[R\\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\right]&#39;\\leq \\epsilon \\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\} \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Now integrate the inequality from  \\( t_{0}\\, \\)  to  \\( t\\, \\) :\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq R\\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\leq {\\frac  {\\epsilon }{\\delta }}\\left[1-\\exp \\left\\{-\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\right]\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>or\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq R\\leq {\\frac  {\\epsilon }{\\delta }}\\left[\\exp \\left\\{\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}-1\\right]\\, \\) .\n</p>\n</center>\n<p>But,\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq r=R&#39;\\leq \\epsilon +\\delta R\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>or\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( 0\\leq r\\leq \\epsilon \\exp \\left\\{\\delta (t-t_{0})\\right\\}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>which completes the proof.\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/ODE0.1", 
        "problem": "State and prove "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Introduction", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Describe <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Picard_Iteration\" title=\"Picard Iteration\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Picard Iteration</a>.\n</p><p>Theorem- Let  \\( f(x,t)\\, \\)  be continuous for\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\alpha ,|x-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta \\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>and satisfy a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Lipschitz_condition\" title=\"Lipschitz condition\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Lipschitz condition</a> with constant  \\( L\\, \\)  in this region. Let  \\( |f(x,t)|\\leq M\\, \\)  there and let  \\( \\delta =\\min \\left\\{\\alpha ,\\beta /M\\right\\}\\, \\) . Then the initial value problem \n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x(t)=x_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x(s),s)ds\\, \\)  \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>has a unique solution for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) .\n</p><p>Proof- The uniqueness of the solution has already been established in <a href=\"/wiki/index.php?title=ODE0.3&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1\" class=\"new\" title=\"ODE0.3 (page does not exist)\">ODE0.3</a>. The existence of the solution is proved in three steps.\n</p><p>(i) Define the following sequence of iterates:\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x^{0}(t)=x_{0}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{1}(t)=x_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x^{0}(s),s)ds\\, \\) \n</p><p>...\n</p><p> \\( x^{{N+1}}(t)=x_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x^{N}(s),s)ds\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p><br />\nThe first approximation  \\( x^{0}\\, \\)  is made by neglecting the integral. The next  \\( x^{1}\\, \\)  is made by using  \\( x^{0}\\, \\)  in the intgrand as a correction term.\n</p><p>In order for the iterates to be defined, it is required to prove that each iterate stays within its domain of definition of  \\( f(x,t)\\, \\) . It will be shown that the iterates are defined for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\)  and satisfy the inequalities\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm  {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>The first step of induction is easy:\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x^{{0}}(t)-x_{0}|=0\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm  {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>The induction hypothesis is to assume that \n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x^{r}(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\left|\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}|f(x^{N}(s),s)|ds\\right|\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\leq M|t-t_{0}|\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm  {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>The completes the induction.\n</p><p>(ii)\n</p><p>Next it is shown that the sequence of iterates is uniformly and absolutely convergent. From the general term of the iteration it is clear that\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x^{{N+1}}(t)-x^{N}(t)=\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}\\left\\{f(x^{N}(s),s)-f(x^{{N-1}}(s),s)\\right\\}ds\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Take the norm of both sides and use the Lipschitz condition.\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x^{N}(t)|\\leq L{\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}{\\Big |}x^{N}(s)-x^{{N-1}}Big|ds{\\Bigg |}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>This produces a sequence of inequalities.\n</p><p>From part (i),  \\( |x^{1}(t)-x^{0}(t)|\\leq M|t-t_{0}|\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The induction hypothesis is\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x^{r}(t)-x^{{r-1}}(t)|\\leq ML^{{r-1}}{\\frac  {|t-t_{0}|^{r}}{r!}}(r=1,...,N)\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Now it follows that\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x^{N}(t)|\\leq {\\frac  {ML^{N}}{N!}}{\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}|s-t_{0}|^{N}ds{\\Bigg |}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =ML^{N}{\\frac  {|t-t_{0}|^{{N+1}}}{(N+1)!}}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Now  \\( x^{N}(t)\\, \\)  can be written as the partial sum\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x^{0}(t)+\\sum _{{r=1}}^{N}\\left\\{x^{r}(t)-x^{{r-1}}(t)\\right\\}=x^{N}(t)\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>But the series on the left is domainated term-by-term by the series\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x_{0}+\\sum _{{r=1}}^{N}ML^{{r-1}}{\\frac  {|t-t_{0}|^{r}}{r!}}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>As  \\( m\\to \\infty \\, \\) , this series is uniformly and asymptotically convergent to\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x_{0}+{\\frac  {M}{L}}\\left[\\exp\\{L|t-t_{0}|\\}-1\\right]\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>So by the comparison test,  \\( x^{N}(t)\\, \\)  comverges uniformly for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\)  to a limit function  \\( x(t)\\, \\) .\n</p><p>(iii)\n</p><p>Again from the general term of the iteration, it can be seen that each iterate is a continuous function of  \\( t\\, \\)  for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) . Hence, since  \\( x^{N}(t)\\, \\)  converges uniformly to  \\( x(t)\\, \\) , it follows that  \\( x(t)\\, \\)  is a continuous function of  \\( t\\, \\)  for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta \\, \\) . \n</p><p>It follows from  \\( |x^{{N+1}}(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm  {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\)  that as  \\( N\\to \\infty \\, \\) ,\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( |x(t)-x_{0}|\\leq \\beta ({\\mathrm  {for}}|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta )\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>It remains to show that  \\( x(t)\\, \\)  satisfies the IVP  \\( x(t)=x_{0}+\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x(s),s)ds\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Let  \\( N\\to \\infty \\, \\)  in the general iteration term.\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( x^{{N+1}}(t)\\to x(t)\\, \\) \n</p><p>and\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x^{N}(s),s)ds\\to \\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}f(x(s),s)ds\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Finally using the Lipschitz condition,\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( {\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}\\left\\{f(x(s),s)-f(x^{N}(s),s)\\right\\}ds{\\Bigg |}\\leq {\\Bigg |}\\int _{{t_{0}}}^{t}L|x(s)-x^{N}(s)|ds{\\Bigg |}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\leq L\\delta \\max _{{|t-t_{0}|\\leq \\delta }}|x(t)-x^{N}(t)|\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>and the right hand side tends to zero as  \\( N\\to \\infty \\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/ODE0.2",

Notice that two inital conditions ( \\( t=0\\, \\) ) are needed for a unique solution to a second order ODE, and the general solution has two arbitrary constants.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(0)=c_{1}+c_{2}=1,\\,\\,\\,c_{1}=1-c_{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(0)=-c_{1}-3c_{2}=0,\\,\\,\\,c_{2}=-1/2,\\,\\,\\,c_{1}=3/2\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the unique solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(t)={\\frac  {3}{2}}e^{{-t}}-{\\frac  {1}{2}}e^{{-3t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( y&#39;&#39;+4y&#39;+5y=0,\\,\\,\\,y(0)=1,\\,y&#39;(0)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The characteristic equation is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m^{2}+4m+5=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the quadratic formula to get  \\( m=-2\\pm i\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The general solution is  \\( y(t)=e^{{-2t}}\\left[c_{1}\\cos(t)+c_{2}\\sin(t)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug in the IC's:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(0)=c_{1}=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(t)=e^{{-2t}}\\left[-\\sin(t)+c_{2}\\cos(t)\\right]-2e^{{-2t}}\\left[c_{1}\\cos(t)+c_{2}\\sin(t)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;(0)=c_{2}-2c_{1}=0,\\,\\,\\,c_{2}=2\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The unique solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(t)=e^{{-2t}}\\left[\\cos(t)+2\\sin(t)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

    {
        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Second order,Second,order", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p><br />\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}y&#39;&#39;+7xy&#39;+8y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The adjoint of an equation in the form<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a(x)y&#39;&#39;+b(x)y&#39;+c(x)y=0\\, \\)  is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a(x)y&#39;&#39;+[2a&#39;(x)-b(x)]y&#39;+[a&#39;&#39;(x)-b&#39;(x)+c(x)]y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the adjoint for this DE is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}y&#39;&#39;-3xy&#39;+3y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Any solution of the adjoint equation is an integrating factor for the original problem. <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y=x\\, \\)  is one solution. Multiply  \\( x\\, \\)  through the original DE.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x^{3}y&#39;&#39;+7x^{2}y&#39;+8xy=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This is an exact equation, since<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}[a(x)y&#39;+b(x)y]=a&#39;(x)y&#39;+a(x)y&#39;&#39;+b&#39;(x)y+b(x)y&#39;\\, \\) <br />\n \\( =a(x)y&#39;&#39;+[a&#39;(x)+b(x)]y&#39;+b&#39;(x)y\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In the case of an exact equation the last relation equals 0, so<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a(x)=x^{3},a&#39;(x)=3x^{2}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( b&#39;(x)=8x,b(x)=4x^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}[x^{3}y&#39;+4x^{2}y]=0\\, \\) . Integrating, <br />\n</p><p> \\( x^{3}y&#39;+4x^{2}y=c_{1}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y&#39;+4x^{{-1}}y=c_{1}x^{{-3}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the integrating factor  \\( e^{{\\int 4x^{{-1}}dx}}=x^{4}\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x^{4}y&#39;+4x^{3}y=c_{1}x\\, \\) <br />\n \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}[x^{4}y]=c_{1}x\\, \\) <br />\n \\( x^{4}y={\\frac  {c_{1}}{2}}x^{2}+c_{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Finally,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y={\\frac  {c_{1}}{2}}x^{{-2}}+c_{2}x^{{-4}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p><br />\n==Alternate Solution== <br /><br />\n \\( x^{2}y&#39;&#39;+7xy&#39;+8y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This equation is recognizable as an Euler equation since the exponent on the  \\( x \\)  is the same as the order of the derivative in each term. So try for a solution in the form  \\( y=x^{r} \\) .\n</p><p> \\( y=x^{r},\\quad y&#39;=rx^{{r-1}},\\quad y&#39;&#39;=r(r-1)x^{{r-2}} \\) \n</p><p>Substituting these in the equation gives:\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}r(r-1)x^{{(r-2)}}+7xrx^{{(r-1)}}+8x^{r}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{r}(r^{2}+6r+8)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( (r+2)(r+4)=0,\\quad r=-2,\\ -4\\, \\) \n</p><p>The solution is therefore  \\( y=Ax^{{-2}}+Bx^{{-4}},\\ x\\neq 0\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/ODE5.1", 
        "problem": " \\( x^{2}y&#39;&#39;+7xy&#39;+8y=0\\, \\) \n"
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Second order,Second,order", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( y&#39;&#39;+2y&#39;+5y=e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>First, solve the homogeneous equation to get  \\( y_{h} \\) . Then, guess a particular solution  \\( y_{p} \\)  and add them together to get the general solution  \\( y=y_{h}+y_{p} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{h}&#39;&#39;+2y_{h}&#39;+5y_{h}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Set up the characteristic equation and solve.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m^{2}+2m+5=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m={\\frac  {-2\\pm {\\sqrt  {4-20}}}{2}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m=-1\\pm 2i\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Therefore, the solution to the homogeneous equation is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{h}=c_{1}e^{{-x}}\\cos(2x)+c_{2}e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y_{h}=e^{{-x}}[c_{1}\\cos(2x)+c_{2}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Now, check the homogeneous solution to see if any new information can be gained. Start by taking the first and second derivatives of  \\( y_{h} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{h}&#39;=e^{{-x}}[(-2c_{1}-c_{2})\\sin(2x)+(-c_{1}+2c_{2})\\cos(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( y_{h}&#39;&#39;=e^{{-x}}[(-4c_{1}-2c_{2})\\cos(2x)-(-2c_{1}+4c_{2})\\sin(2x)]-e^{{-x}}[(-2c_{1}-c_{2})\\sin(2x)+(-c_{1}+2c_{2})\\cos(2x)]\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y_{h}&#39;&#39;=e^{{-x}}[(-3c_{1}-4c_{2})\\cos(2x)+(4c_{1}-3c_{2})\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Substitution of these derivatives into the homogeneous version of the original differential equation and collection of the exponential and trig functions gives the following relations.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( e^{{-x}}\\cos(2x)[-4c_{1}+c_{1}-4c_{2}-2c_{1}+2c_{2}+5c_{1}]=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)[4c_{1}-3c_{2}-4c_{1}-2c_{2}+5c_{2}]=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So from the first equation,  \\( c_{1} \\)  is arbitrary and  \\( -2c_{2}=0 \\) , so  \\( c_{2}=0 \\) . From the second equation, no new information is obtained. Therefore, a better homogeneous equation is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{h}=c_{1}e^{{-x}}\\cos(2x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Now a particular solution should be guessed. Based on the nonhomogeneous part of the original DE,  \\( e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x) \\)  , a first guess is <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{p}=Ae^{{-x}}[c_{3}\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) , with  \\( A \\) ,  \\( c_{3} \\) , and  \\( c_{4} \\)  undetermined constants. <br /><br />\n</p><p>But, the homogeneous solution appears as one of the terms of the guessed particular solution, so that term should be multiplied by  \\( x \\) . Now, a guess for the particular solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{p}=Ae^{{-x}}[c_{3}x\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Find the first and second derivatives of  \\( y_{p} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{p}&#39;=Ae^{{-x}}[-2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+c_{3}\\cos(2x)+2c_{4}\\cos(2x)]-Ae^{{-x}}[c_{3}x\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y_{p}&#39;=Ae^{{-x}}[-c_{3}x\\cos(2x)-2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+(c_{3}+2c_{4})\\cos(2x)-c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( y_{p}&#39;&#39;=Ae^{{-x}}[2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)-c_{3}\\cos(2x)-4c_{3}x\\cos(2x)-2c_{3}\\sin(2x)-2(c_{3}+2c_{4})\\sin(2x)-2c_{4}\\cos(2x)]\\, \\) <br /> \\( -Ae^{{-x}}[-c_{3}x\\cos(2x)-2c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+(c_{3}+2c_{4})\\cos(2x)-c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y_{p}&#39;&#39;=Ae^{{-x}}[-3c_{3}x\\cos(2x)+4c_{3}x\\sin(2x)+(-2c_{3}-4c_{4})\\cos(2x)+(-4c_{3}-3c_{4})\\sin(2x)]=e^{{-x}}\\sin(2x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Substitute these derivatives into the original DE to get these relations:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Ae^{{-x}}[(-3c_{3}-2c_{3}+5c_{3})x\\cos(2x)+(2c_{3}+2c_{3}-4c_{3})x\\sin(2x)+\\, \\) <br /> \\( (-c_{3}-2c_{4}-c_{3}-2c_{4}+2c_{3}+4c_{4})\\cos(2x)+(-4c_{3}-4c_{4}+c_{4}-2c_{4}+5c_{4})\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So comparing the coefficients of  \\( x\\sin(2x) \\)  and  \\( x\\cos(2x) \\)  gives no information about  \\( c_{3} \\)  except that it is arbitrary so far. The other terms give the relations<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( -4c_{3}=1\\, \\)  so that  \\( c_{3}={\\frac  {-1}{4}}\\, \\) , and<br />\n \\( c_{4} \\)  is arbitrary, so that the particular solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{p}=e^{{-x}}[-{\\frac  {1}{4}}x\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Finally, the general solution is <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(x)=y_{h}+y_{p}=e^{{-x}}[-{\\frac  {1}{4}}x\\cos(2x)+c_{1}\\cos(2x)+c_{4}\\sin(2x)]\\, \\) \n</p><p><br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( y&#39;&#39;-3y&#39;+2y=3e^{{x}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Set up and solve the characteristic equation for the homogeneous solution.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m^{2}-3m+2=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m={\\frac  {3\\pm {\\sqrt  {9-8}}}{2}}={\\frac  {3}{2}}\\pm {\\frac  {1}{2}}=2,1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the solution to the homogeneous equation is <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y_{h}=c_{1}e^{{2x}}+c_{2}e^{{x}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Guess a particular solution similar to the structure of the nonhomogeneous part of the DE.         "solution": "<p>A ball is thrown straight up from the ground. How high will it go?<br /><br />\n</p><p>The height of the ball at time  \\( t\\, \\)  is  \\( x(t)\\, \\) , and the force acting on the ball is  \\( -mg\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Newton's second law gives the relation<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m{\\frac  {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+mg=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( m=1\\, \\)  for convenience.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+g=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate the last equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx(t)}{dt}}+gt+C=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To get  \\( C\\, \\) , start with an initial velocity  \\( v_{0}\\, \\)  and set  \\( t=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{0}+C=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So now,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}+gt-v_{0}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate again.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x(t)+{\\frac  {1}{2}}gt^{2}-v_{0}t+D=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Since we have set  \\( x(0)=0\\, \\) ,  \\( D=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The equation of position is <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x(t)=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}gt^{2}+v_{0}t\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To find the maximum, set the first derivative equal to 0.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( -gt+v_{0}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( t_{{max}}={\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Check that the second derivative at this point is negative.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x&#39;&#39;\\left({\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)=-g\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the answer is this point  \\( t_{{max}}\\, \\)  evaluated in the position function.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x_{{max}}=x\\left({\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)={\\frac  {v_{0}^{2}}{2g}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential         "solution": "<p>Find the general solution of the equation  \\( u&#39;&#39;+\\omega ^{2}u=f(t)\\, \\)  where  \\( \\omega \\in {\\mathbb  {R}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nTwo linearly independent solutions to the homogeneous equation are  \\( u^{1}=cos\\omega t,u^{2}=\\sin \\omega t\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fundamental_matrix\" title=\"Fundamental matrix\" class=\"mw-redirect\">fundamental matrix</a> is \n</p><p> \\( X={\\begin{bmatrix}cos\\omega t&amp;\\sin \\omega t\\\\-\\omega \\sin \\omega t&amp;\\omega \\cos \\omega t\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Wronskian\" title=\"Wronskian\">Wronskian</a> is\n</p><p> \\( W=\\omega \\cos ^{2}\\omega t+\\omega \\sin ^{2}\\omega t=\\omega \\, \\) \n</p><p>From ODE theory, the particular solution is \n</p><p> \\( u_{p}(t)=\\int _{a}^{t}{\\frac  {f(s)}{W(s)}}\\left[u^{2}(t)u^{1}(s)-u^{1}(t)u^{2}(s)\\right]ds\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{\\omega }}\\int _{a}^{t}f(s)\\left[\\sin \\omega t\\cos \\omega s-\\cos \\omega t\\sin \\omega s\\right]ds\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{\\omega }}\\int _{a}^{t}f(s)\\sin \\omega (t-s)ds\\, \\) \n</p><p>So the general solution is \n</p><p> \\( u(t)=\\cos \\omega t+\\sin \\omega t+{\\frac  {1}{\\omega }}\\int _{a}^{t}f(s)\\sin \\omega (t-s)ds\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Uniqueness/Existence Theorems,Uniqueness/Existence,Theorems", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Consider the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Initial_value_problem\" title=\"Initial value problem\">initial value problem</a>\n</p>\n<center> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=|x|^{{2/q}},x(0)=0\\, \\) </center>\n<p>where  \\( \\,q \\)  is a positive integer. Find all values of  \\( \\,q \\)  for which there is a unique solution. In the latter case, justify your answer by using an appropriate theorem.\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Let  \\( q=1\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=|x|^{2}=x^{2}, \\) \n</p><p>Check the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Lipschitz_condition\" title=\"Lipschitz condition\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Lipschitz condition</a>.\n</p><p> \\( |f(x,t)-f(y,t)|=|x^{2}-y^{2}|\\leq |x+y||x-y|=L|x-y|\\, \\) \n</p><p>So  \\( f\\, \\)  is Lipschitz if  \\( x\\, \\)  is bounded.\n</p><p>Solving the DE,\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=x^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=x^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{x^{2}}}=dt\\implies {\\frac  {-1}{x}}=t+c\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x={\\frac  {-1}{t+c}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(0)={\\frac  {-1}{c}}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>There is no solution to this DE.\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Let  \\( q=2\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=|x|\\, \\) \n</p><p>Check Lipschitz.\n</p><p> \\( |f(x,t)-f(y,t)|=||x|-|y||\\leq L|x-y|\\, \\)  is true.\n</p><p>Solve the DE.\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=|x|,x(0)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>if  \\( x&lt;0\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=-x\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{-x}}=dt\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( -\\ln x=t+c_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(t)=-e^{{t+c_{1}}}\\,=c_{2}e^{t} \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(0)=c_{2}=0\\implies c_{2}=0\\implies x=0\\, \\)  is the unique solution.\n</p><p><br />\nIf  \\( x=0\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(t)=c_{3}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(0)=0\\implies c_{3}=0\\implies x=0\\, \\)  is the unique solution.\n</p><p><br />\nIf  \\( x&gt;0\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=x\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{x}}=dt\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\ln x=t+c_{4}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(t)=e^{{t+c_{4}}}\\,=c_{5}e^{t} \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(0)=c_{5}=0\\implies c_{5}=0\\implies x=0\\, \\)  is the unique solution.\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Let  \\( q=n\\geq 3\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=|x|^{{2/n}}=x^{{2/n}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Test Lipschitz.\n</p><p> \\( |x^{{2/n}}-y^{{2/n}}|=|(x^{{1/n}}+y^{{1/n}})(x^{{1/n}}-y^{{1/n}})|\\leq |x^{{1/n}}+y^{{1/n}}||x-y|\\, \\) \n</p><p>But  \\( (x^{{1/n}}+y^{{1/n}})\\, \\)  is not bounded by a constant so  \\( x\\, \\)  is not Lipschitz and therefore there is not a unique solution.\n</p><p>Solve the DE.\n</p><p> \\( {\\dot  {x}}=|x|^{{2/n}}=x^{{2/n}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{{-2/n}}dx=dt\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {nx^{{\\frac  {n-2}{n}}}}{n-2}}=t+c_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{{\\frac  {n-2}{n}}}={\\frac  {n-2}{n}}(t+c_{1})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(t)=\\left[{\\frac  {n-2}{n}}(t+c_{1})\\right]^{{\\frac  {n}{n-2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(0)=\\left[{\\frac  {n-2}{n}}c_{1}\\right]^{{\\frac  {n}{n-2}}}=0\\implies c_{1}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>So  \\( x(t)=\\left[{\\frac  {n-2}{n}}t\\right]^{{\\frac  {n}{n-2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>There are infinitely many solutions because the equation holds for all  \\( n\\geq 3\\, \\) .\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/ODEUET1",

        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>For the first-order system  \\( x_{1}&#39;=x_{2},x_{2}&#39;=-\\sin x_{1}-x_{2}|x_{2}|+\\cos t\\, \\) , show that the right-hand side satisfies a Lipschitz condition in the domain  \\( |x|\\leq \\beta \\, \\)  for  \\( |t|\\leq \\alpha \\, \\) , where  \\( \\alpha \\, \\)  and  \\( \\beta \\, \\)  are arbitrary but finite numbers. Deduce that the IVP  \\( x_{1}(0)=0\\, \\)  and  \\( x_{2}(0)=0\\, \\)  has a unique solution for  \\( |t|\\leq \\delta \\, \\)  and obtain an estimate for  \\( \\delta \\, \\) . By allowing  \\( \\alpha \\, \\)  and  \\( \\beta \\, \\)  to be as large as possible, attempt to improve your estimate of  \\( \\delta \\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n \\( f({\\vec  x},t)={\\begin{bmatrix}x_{2}\\\\-\\sin x_{1}-x_{2}|x_{2}|+\\cos t\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The Lipschitz constant is  \\( L=\\max \\left|{\\frac  {\\partial f_{1}}{\\partial x_{1}}}\\right|\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( L=\\max \\left\\{1+|\\cos x_{1}|+2|x_{2}|\\right\\}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( L\\leq 2+2|x_{2}|\\, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( |x|\\leq \\beta \\, \\)  then\n</p><p> \\( L\\leq 2(1+\\beta )\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nThe magnitude of  \\( f\\, \\)  gives an upper bound:\n</p><p> \\( |f({\\vec  x},t)=|x_{2}|+|\\sin x_{1}|+|x_{2}^{2}|+|\\cos t|=\\beta ^{2}+\\beta +2=M\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( \\delta =\\min \\left\\{\\alpha ,{\\frac  {\\beta }{\\beta ^{2}+\\beta +2}}\\right\\}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nPick  \\( \\alpha =\\beta =1\\, \\)  so that  \\( \\delta =\\min \\left\\{1,{\\frac  {1}{4}}\\right\\}={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nImprove the estimate for  \\( \\delta \\, \\)  by allowing  \\( \\alpha \\, \\)  and  \\( \\beta \\, \\)  to be as large as possible.\n</p><p><br />\nMaximize  \\( {\\frac  {\\beta }{\\beta ^{2}+\\beta +2}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nThe derivative is  \\( {\\frac  {\\beta ^{2}+\\beta +2-\\beta (2\\beta +1)}{(\\beta ^{2}+\\beta +2)^{2}}}=0\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Just set the numerator equal to 0.\n</p><p> \\( \\beta ^{2}+\\beta +2-\\beta (2\\beta +1)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( -\\beta ^{2}+2=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\beta ={\\sqrt  {2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nNow let  \\( \\alpha &gt;{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {2}}}{4+{\\sqrt  {2}}}}\\, \\)  so that  \\( \\delta ={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {2}}}{4+{\\sqrt  {2}}}}=0.2612\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Linear Systems,Linear,Systems", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Solve the system of ODE's:  \\( {\\begin{cases}x_{t}=6x-3y\\\\y_{t}=2x+y\\end{cases}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Guess the solutions <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x=Ae^{{\\lambda t}},x_{t}=\\lambda Ae^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y=Be^{{\\lambda t}},y_{t}=\\lambda Be^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug these guesses into the original equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\lambda Ae^{{\\lambda t}}=6Ae^{{\\lambda t}}-3Be^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( \\lambda Be^{{\\lambda t}}=2Ae^{{\\lambda t}}+Be^{{\\lambda t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Write this system of equations in matrix form.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}6-\\lambda &amp;-3\\\\2&amp;1-\\lambda \\\\\\end{bmatrix}} \\)  \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}A\\\\B\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}0\\\\0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Find lambda by taking the determinant of the matrix.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( (6-\\lambda )(1-\\lambda )+6=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( 6-7\\lambda +\\lambda ^{2}+6=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( \\lambda ^{2}-7\\lambda +12=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( \\lambda ={\\frac  {7\\pm {\\sqrt  {49-48}}}{2}}={\\frac  {7\\pm 1}{2}}=3,4\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>There are two values for lambda, so there will be two solutions and the sum of these two solutions is the general solution.<br /><br />\n</p><p>If  \\( \\lambda =3\\, \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 3A-3B=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( 2A-2B=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\nAdd these equations to get<br />\n \\( A-B=0\\, \\) , so  \\( A=B=C_{1}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>One solution is  \\( x=C_{1}e^{{3t}},y=C_{1}e^{{3t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>If  \\( \\lambda =4\\, \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 2A-3B=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( 2A-3B=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThese equations imply<br />\n \\( B=(2/3)A\\, \\) , so if  \\( B=C_{2},A=(3/2)C_{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Then the general solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x=C_{1}e^{{3t}}+(3/2)C_{2}e^{{4t}}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( y=C_{1}e^{{3t}}+C_{2}e^{{4t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Write the single  \\( n \\) th order equation  \\( u^{{(n)}}=g(u,u&#39;,...,u^{{(n-1)}},t)\\, \\)  as a first-order system.\n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( x_{1}=u,x_{2}=u&#39;,...,x_{n}=u^{{(n-1)}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now form the first order system\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}&#39;=x_{2}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( x_{2}&#39;=x_{3}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( ...\\, \\) <br />\n \\( x_{{n-1}}&#39;=x_{n}\\, \\) <br />\n \\( x_{n}&#39;=g(x_{1},x_{2},...,x_{n},t)\\, \\) <br />\n</p><p>With the following initial conditions\n</p><p> \\( u(t_{0})=u,u&#39;(t_{0})=u_{2},...,u^{{(n-1)}}(t_{0})=u_{n}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( {\\vec  x}={\\begin{bmatrix}x_{1}\\\\x_{2}\\\\...\\\\x_{n}\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\vec  {x}}&#39;={\\begin{bmatrix}x_{2}\\\\x_{3}\\\\...\\\\g\\end{bmatrix}}={\\vec  {f}}(x,t)\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( {\\vec  {f}}(x,t)\\, \\)  be continuous for  \\( |t-t_{0}|\\leq \\alpha ,|{\\vec  x}-{\\vec  {x}}(0)|\\leq \\beta \\, \\)  and satisfy and Lipschitz condition with constant  \\( L\\, \\)  in this region.         "solution": "<p>Find a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fundamental_matrix\" title=\"Fundamental matrix\" class=\"mw-redirect\">fundamental matrix</a> and the Wronskian for the following linear system:  \\( {\\begin{cases}x_{1}&#39;=x_{2}\\\\x_{2}&#39;=x_{1}\\end{cases}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The matrix of coefficients  \\( A\\, \\)  is  \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}0&amp;1\\\\1&amp;0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Eigenvalues\" title=\"Eigenvalues\" class=\"mw-redirect\">eigenvalues</a> are  \\( \\lambda =\\pm 1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>For  \\( \\lambda =1\\, \\)  an <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Eigenvector\" title=\"Eigenvector\" class=\"mw-redirect\">eigenvector</a> is  \\( u_{1}={\\begin{bmatrix}1\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>For  \\( \\lambda =-1\\, \\)  an eignvector is  \\( u_{{-1}}={\\begin{bmatrix}-1\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Therefore two linearly independent solutions are:\n</p><p> \\( x^{1}=e^{t}{\\begin{bmatrix}1\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}e^{t}\\\\e^{t}\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{2}=e^{{-t}}{\\begin{bmatrix}-1\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}-e^{{-t}}\\\\e^{{-t}}\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>So a fundamental matrix is  \\( X(t)={\\begin{bmatrix}e^{t}&amp;-e^{{-t}}\\\\e^{t}&amp;e^{{-t}}\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The Wronskian is the determinant of this matrix after evaluation at  \\( t=0\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( W=1+1=2\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the particular solution which vanishes at  \\( t=0\\, \\)   and identify the Green's matrix  \\( G_{0}(t,s)\\, \\)  of the system  \\( {\\begin{cases}x_{1}&#39;=x_{2}+g_{1}(t)\\\\x_{2}&#39;=-x_{1}+g_{2}(t)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The homogeneous equations can be written  \\( {\\vec  x}&#39;=A(x){\\vec  x}\\, \\)  where \n</p><p> \\( A={\\begin{bmatrix}0&amp;1\\\\-1&amp;0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nFind the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Eigenvalues\" title=\"Eigenvalues\" class=\"mw-redirect\">eigenvalues</a>  \\( \\lambda =\\pm i\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Eigenvector\" title=\"Eigenvector\" class=\"mw-redirect\">eigenvector</a> for  \\( \\lambda _{1}=i\\, \\)  is  \\( {\\vec  {u_{1}}}={\\begin{bmatrix}1\\\\i\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The real and imaginary parts are  \\( {\\vec  v}={\\begin{bmatrix}1\\\\0\\end{bmatrix}},{\\vec  w}={\\begin{bmatrix}0\\\\1\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So if  \\( \\lambda =\\alpha +i\\beta \\, \\)  then\n</p><p> \\( e^{{\\lambda t}}=e^{{\\alpha t}}(\\cos \\beta t+i\\sin \\beta t)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\vec  x}=e^{{\\lambda t}}{\\vec  {u_{1}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\vec  x}=e^{0}(\\cos t+i\\sin t){\\begin{bmatrix}1\\\\i\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\vec  x}={\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos t+i\\sin t\\\\-\\sin t+i\\cos t\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>So two linearly independent solutions are the real and imaginary parts of  \\( {\\vec  x}\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}={\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos t\\\\-\\sin t\\end{bmatrix}},x_{2}={\\begin{bmatrix}\\sin t\\\\\\cos t\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>So the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fundamental_matrix\" title=\"Fundamental matrix\" class=\"mw-redirect\">fundamental matrix</a> is\n</p><p> \\( X(t)={\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos t&amp;\\sin t\\\\-\\sin t&amp;\\cos t\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nNow the particular solution is \n</p><p> \\( x_{p}=X(t)\\int _{0}^{t}X^{{-1}}(s)g(s)ds\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nDefine Green's matrix\n</p><p> \\( G_{0}(t,s)={\\begin{cases}0&amp;t\\leq s\\leq b\\\\X(t)X^{{-1}}(s)&amp;a\\leq s&lt;t\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos t\\cos s+\\sin t\\sin s&amp;-\\cos t\\sin s+\\sin t\\cos s\\\\-\\sin t\\cos s+\\cos t\\sin s&amp;\\sin t\\sin s+\\cos t\\cos s\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find a fundamental matrix, <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Characteristic_multipliers\" title=\"Characteristic multipliers\" class=\"mw-redirect\">characteristic multipliers</a> (Floquet multipliers) and <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Characteristic_exponents\" title=\"Characteristic exponents\" class=\"mw-redirect\">characteristic exponents</a> (Floquet exponents) for the system  \\( {\\begin{cases}x_{1}&#39;=-x_{1}+x_{2}\\\\x_{2}&#39;=\\left(1+\\cos t-{\\frac  {\\sin t}{2+\\cos t}}\\right)x_{2}\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Start with the second equation since it does not involve the first.\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx_{2}}{dt}}=\\left(1+\\cos t-{\\frac  {\\sin t}{2+\\cos t}}\\right)x_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Seperate variables.\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx_{2}}{x_{2}}}=\\left(1+\\cos t-{\\frac  {\\sin t}{2+\\cos t}}\\right)dt\\, \\) \n</p><p>Integrate.\n</p><p> \\( \\ln x_{2}=t+\\sin t+\\ln(2+\\cos t)+c_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Exponentiate.\n</p><p> \\( x_{2}=c_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now use this equation in the first ODE.\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}&#39;=-x_{1}+c_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}&#39;+x_{1}=c_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Use the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integrating_factor\" title=\"Integrating factor\">integrating factor</a>  \\( \\rho =e^{{\\int dt}}=e^{t}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\left[e^{t}x_{1}\\right]&#39;=c_{2}e^{{2t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)\\, \\) \n</p><p>Integrate.\n</p><p> \\( e^{t}x_{1}=c_{2}e^{{2t+\\sin t}}+c_{3}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Multiply by  \\( e^{{-t}}\\, \\)  (which is okay because it's always positive).\n</p><p> \\( x_{1}=c_{2}e^{{t+\\sin t}}+c_{3}e^{{-t}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>A fundamental matrix is  \\( X(t)={\\begin{bmatrix}{\\frac  {\\partial x_{1}}{\\partial c_{2}}}&amp;{\\frac  {\\partial x_{1}}{\\partial c_{3}}}\\\\{\\frac  {\\partial x_{2}}{\\partial c_{2}}}&amp;{\\frac  {\\partial x_{2}}{\\partial c_{3}}}\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}e^{{t+\\sin t}}&amp;e^{{-t}}\\\\e^{{t+\\sin t}}(2+\\cos t)&amp;0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( X^{{-1}}(0)={\\begin{bmatrix}0&amp;1/3\\\\1&amp;-1/3\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( X(2\\pi )={\\begin{bmatrix}e^{{2\\pi }}&amp;e^{{-2\\pi }}\\\\3e^{{2\\pi }}&amp;0\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The monodromy matrix is  \\( B=X^{{-1}}(0)X(2\\pi )={\\begin{bmatrix}e^{{2\\pi }}&amp;0\\\\0&amp;e^{{-2\\pi }}\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The characteristic multipliers are  \\( \\rho _{{1,2}}=e^{{-2\\pi }},e^{{2\\pi }}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The characteristic exponents are  \\( \\mu _{{1,2}}=-1,1\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>For the differential equation  \\( u&#39;&#39;+a_{1}(t)u&#39;+a_{2}(t)u=0\\, \\) , where  \\( a_{i}(t+T)=a_{i}(t)\\, \\)  for all  \\( t(i=1,2)\\, \\) , show that the characteristic multipliers  \\( \\rho _{1}\\, \\)  and  \\( \\rho _{2}\\, \\)  satisfy the relation  \\( \\rho _{1}\\rho _{2}=\\exp \\left\\{-\\int _{0}^{T}a_{1}(t)dt\\right\\}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Let  \\( x_{1}=u,x_{2}=u&#39;\\, \\) . Now the equation can be written as a first order system:\n</p><p><br />\n \\( x_{1}&#39;=x_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{2}&#39;=-a_{1}(t)x_{2}-a_{2}(t)x_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( A={\\begin{bmatrix}0&amp;1\\\\-a_{2}(t)&amp;-a_{1}(t)\\\\\\end{bmatrix}} \\) \n</p><p><br />\nAssume we have two linearly independent solutions  \\( u^{1}\\, \\)  and  \\( u^{2}\\, \\) . Now a fundamental matrix is \n</p><p> \\( X={\\begin{bmatrix}u^{1}&amp;u^{2}\\\\u&#39;^{1}&amp;u&#39;^{2}\\\\\\end{bmatrix}} \\) \n</p><p>Also assume that  \\( u^{1}(0)=1,u^{2}(0)=0,u&#39;^{1}(0)=0,u&#39;^{2}(0)=1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Now the monodromy matrix is\n</p><p> \\( B={\\begin{bmatrix}u^{1}(T)&amp;u^{2}(T)\\\\u&#39;^{1}(T)&amp;u&#39;^{2}(T)\\\\\\end{bmatrix}} \\) \n</p><p>The determinant of  \\( B\\, \\)  is  \\( \\exp \\left\\{\\int _{0}^{T}{\\mathrm  {tr}}A\\right\\}=\\exp \\left\\{-\\int _{0}^{T}a_{1}(t)dt\\right\\}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The characteristic multipliers  \\( \\rho \\, \\)  are the eigenvalues of  \\( B\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( \\rho ^{2}-2\\phi \\rho +exp\\left\\{-\\int _{0}^{T}a_{1}(t)dt\\right\\}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore  \\( \\rho _{1}\\rho _{2}=\\exp \\left\\{-\\int _{0}^{T}a_{1}(t)dt\\right\\}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Parametric Resonance,Parametric,Resonance", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>For the equation  \\( u&#39;&#39;+(\\delta +\\epsilon \\cos t+\\epsilon \\sin 2t)u=0\\, \\)  show that the conditions for <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Parametric_resonance\" title=\"Parametric resonance\">parametric resonance</a> are  \\( \\epsilon =0\\, \\)  and  \\( \\delta =k^{2}\\, \\)  or  \\( (k+1/2)^{2},(k=0,1,2,...)\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( \\epsilon =0\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Then  \\( u&#39;&#39;+\\delta u=0\\, \\)  has two L.I. solutions  \\( \\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t\\, \\)  and  \\( {\\frac  {\\sin {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t}{{\\sqrt  {\\delta }}}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fundamental_matrix\" title=\"Fundamental matrix\" class=\"mw-redirect\">fundamental matrix</a> is  \\( X(t)={\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t&amp;{\\frac  {\\sin {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t}{{\\sqrt  {\\delta }}}}\\\\-{\\sqrt  {\\delta }}\\sin {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t&amp;\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Notice  \\( X(0)=I\\, \\)  (the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Identity_matrix\" title=\"Identity matrix\">identity matrix</a>) so this is a principal fundamental matrix.\n</p><p>The monodromy matrix  \\( B\\, \\)  is the inverse of the fundamental matrix evaluated at zero times the fundamental matrix evaluted at the period of the coefficients.\n</p><p> \\( B=X^{{-1}}(0)\\cdot X(2\\pi )=I\\cdot X(2\\pi )=X(2\\pi )={\\begin{bmatrix}\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi &amp;{\\frac  {\\sin {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi }{{\\sqrt  {\\delta }}}}\\\\-{\\sqrt  {\\delta }}\\sin {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}t&amp;\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi \\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The eigenvalues of  \\( B\\, \\)  are  \\( \\rho _{{1,2}}=\\phi \\pm {\\sqrt  {\\phi ^{2}-1}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Also it is true that  \\( \\phi ={\\frac  {1}{2}}{\\mathrm  {Trace}}(B)=\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi \\, \\) .\n</p><p>So now  \\( \\rho _{{1,2}}=\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi \\pm i\\sin {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi \\, \\) .\n</p><p>It is true that  \\( -1\\leq \\phi \\leq 1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>In case  \\( -1&lt;\\phi &lt;1\\, \\) , the solutions are <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Bounded\" title=\"Bounded\" class=\"mw-redirect\">bounded</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Oscillatory\" title=\"Oscillatory\">oscillatory</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Stable\" title=\"Stable\" class=\"mw-redirect\">stable</a>.\n</p><p>In case  \\( \\phi =-1,\\,\\,\\,\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi =-1\\implies \\delta =\\left(k+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)^{2}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>In case  \\( \\phi =1,\\,\\,\\,\\cos {\\sqrt  {\\delta }}2\\pi =1\\implies \\delta =k^{2}\\, \\) .\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/ODEPR1", 
        "problem": "For the equation  \\( u&#39;&#39;+(\\delta +\\epsilon \\cos t+\\epsilon \\sin 2t)u=0\\, \\)  show that the conditions for parametric resonance are  \\( \\epsilon =0\\, \\)  and  \\( \\delta =k^{2}\\, \\)  or  \\( (k+1/2)^{2},(k=0,1,2,...)\\, \\) .\n"

        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Lyapunov Functions,Lyapunov,Functions", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Consider the system of equations  \\( {\\begin{cases}x&#39;=y-xf(x,y)\\\\y&#39;=-x-yf(x,y)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Find a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Lyapunov_function\" title=\"Lyapunov function\">Lyapunov function</a> to determine the stability of the equilibrium solution  \\( (0,0)\\, \\) . Consider the three cases in your calculations: a)  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  positive semidefinate, b)  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  positive definite and c)  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  negative definate.\n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\begin{cases}x&#39;=y-xf(x,y)\\\\y&#39;=-x-yf(x,y)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( L=x^{2}+y^{2}\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}=2x{\\dot  {x}}+2y{\\dot  {y}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =2x\\left[y-xf(x,y)\\right]+2y\\left[-x-yf(x,y)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =-2x^{2}f(x,y)-2y^{2}f(x,y)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =-f(x,y)[2x^{2}+2y^{2}]\\, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  is positive semidefinite, then  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}\\leq 0\\, \\)  so the zero solution is uniformly stable.\n</p><p>If  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  is positive definite, then  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}&lt;0\\, \\)  so the zero solution is asymptotically stable.\n</p><p>If  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  is negative definite, then  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial L}{\\partial t}}&gt;0\\, \\)  so the zero solution is unstable.\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( y&#39;+xy=xy^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>A <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://mathworld.wolfram.com/BernoulliDifferentialEquation.html\">Bernoulli Equation</a> has the form <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;+p(x)y=q(x)y^{n}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>And for these types of DE's a substitution of  \\( z=y^{{1-n}}\\, \\)  is recommended. In the present problem,  \\( n=2\\, \\)  and so<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z=y^{{-1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y=z^{{-1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y&#39;=-{\\frac  {z&#39;}{z^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Substituting these new variables into the original equation,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( -{\\frac  {z&#39;}{z^{2}}}+{\\frac  {x}{z}}={\\frac  {x}{z^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z&#39;-xz=-x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the integrating factor  \\( e^{{\\int -xdx}}=e^{{-x^{2}/2}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( e^{{-x^{2}/2}}z&#39;-e^{{-x^{2}/2}}xz=-e^{{-x^{2}/2}}x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}[e^{{-x^{2}/2}}z]=-e^{{-x^{2}/2}}x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( e^{{-x^{2}/2}}z=e^{{-x^{2}/2}}+c_{1}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z=1+c_{1}e^{{x^{2}/2}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Undoing the substitution  \\( z=y^{{-1}} \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y^{{-1}}=1+c_{1}e^{{x^{2}/2}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y=(1+c_{1}e^{{x^{2}/2}})^{{-1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a>\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.096 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.291 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 52/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 344/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:1305-0!*!0!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034147 and revision id 1471\n -->\n",

        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,Nonlinear", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{y}}={\\frac  {y&#39;&#39;}{1+y&#39;^{2}}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Multiply both sides by  \\( 2y&#39;\\, \\) :<br /><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {2y&#39;}{y}}={\\frac  {2y&#39;y&#39;&#39;}{1+y&#39;^{2}}} \\) <br /><br />\nObserve that the numerator of the term on the right side\nis the derivative (with respect to  \\( x \\) ) of the\ndenominator of that term (indeed, that is why the factor  \\( 2y&#39; \\) \nwas chosen -- a sort of <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integrating_factor\" title=\"Integrating factor\">integrating factor</a>). Integrate both sides with respect\nto  \\( x \\) ; the result is<br /><br />\n \\( 2\\ln |y|=\\ln(1+y&#39;^{2})+a\\, \\)  <br /><br />\n(Alternatively, since the differential equation does not explicitly involve \n \\( x \\) , the substitution \n \\( {\\frac  {dy}{dx}}=p,{\\frac  {d^{2}y}{dx^{2}}}=p{\\frac  {dp}{dy}} \\)  converts the \nequation to a first-order equation in  \\( p \\)  and  \\( y \\) \nwhich is separable. Integrating and back-substituting  \\( dy/dx\\, \\) \nfor  \\( p\\, \\)  yields the same result as given above, as of course it must.)<br /><br />\nExponentiating both sides, we get \\( y^{2}=c^{2}(1+y&#39;^{2})\\, \\) <br /><br />\nwhere  \\( c^{2}=e^{a}\\, \\)  (we are free to write  \\( c^{2} \\)  since \n \\( e^{a}&gt;0 \\)  for all real  \\( a \\) ).<br /><br />\n</p><p>Solving the above for  \\( y&#39; \\) ,<br /><br />\n \\( y&#39;=\\pm {\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {y^{2}-c^{2}}}}{c}} \\) <br /><br />\nDivide both sides by  \\( {\\sqrt  {y^{2}-c^{2}}} \\)  and integrate:<br /><br />\n \\( \\int {\\frac  {dy}{{\\sqrt  {y^{2}-c^{2}}}}}=\\int \\pm {\\frac  {dx}{c}} \\)  (where we have used\n \\( y&#39;dx=dy \\)  in the integral on the left)<br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the trig substitution  \\( y=c\\,\\sec(\\theta ) \\) , \n \\( dy=c\\,\\sec(\\theta )\\tan(\\theta )\\,d\\theta  \\) \nto get\n</p><p> \\( \\int \\sec(\\theta )\\,d\\theta =\\pm \\int {\\frac  {dx}{c}}\\qquad  \\)  Integrating,\n</p><p> \\( \\ln {|\\sec(\\theta )+\\tan(\\theta )|}=\\pm x/c+d\\, \\)  or after back-substitution,<br /><br />\n \\( \\ln {|y/c+{\\sqrt  {y^{2}/c^{2}-1}}|}=\\pm x/c+d\\qquad  \\)  Exponentiating both sides and\nmultiplying both sides by  \\( c \\) ,<br /><br />\n \\( y+{\\sqrt  {y^{2}-1}}=ce^{{\\pm (x/c)+d}}\\qquad  \\)  Solving this for  \\( y \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y={\\frac  {c\\left(e^{{2(\\pm (x/c)+d)}}+1\\right)}{2e^{{\\pm (x/c)+d}}}}=c\\,{\\frac  {e^{{\\pm (x/c)+d}}+e^{{\\mp (x/c)-d}}}{2}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Either case may be written in the form\n \\( y=c\\cosh(x/c\\,+\\,b)\\, \\)  where  \\( b \\)  and  \\( c \\)  are arbitrary constants, as may be verified by substituting this solution into the original differential equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,About an irregular singular point,About,irregular,singular,point,Power Series,Power,Series", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Given the differential equation  \\( x^{{3}}y&#39;&#39;+4x^{{2}}y&#39;+3y=0\\, \\) <br />\n</p><p>i.e., &#160;  \\( y&#39;&#39;+{\\frac  {4x^{{2}}}{x^{{3}}}}y&#39;+{\\frac  {3}{x^{{3}}}}y=0, \\) <br />\n</p><p>&#8658;  \\( y&#39;&#39;+{\\frac  {4}{x}}y&#39;+{\\frac  {3}{x^{{3}}}}y=0, \\) <br />\n</p><p>So  \\( P(x)={\\frac  {4}{x}},Q(x)={\\frac  {3}{x^{{3}}}}, \\) <br />\n</p><p> \\( \\therefore x=0 \\)  is a singular point because the functions  P(x) and  Q(x) are not analytic at  x=0.\n</p><p>To check for regularity consider the functions  \\( (x-0) \\) ,P(x) and  \\( (x-0)^{{2}} \\) ,Q(x)<br />\n</p><p>i.e.,  \\( x{\\frac  {4}{x}} \\)  and  \\( x^{{2}}{\\frac  {3}{x^{{3}}}} \\) <br />\n</p><p>i.e., 4 and  \\( {\\frac  {3}{x}} \\)  which are not analytic at  \\( x=0 \\) <br />\n</p><p>Hence x=0 is and irregualr singular point\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.060 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.184 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 34/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 224/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33323-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034150 and revision id 45492\n -->\n",
