    {
        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,About a regular singular point,About,regular,singular,point,Power Series,Power,Series", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Using Frobenius' Theorem find two linearly independent solutions to the following equation.   \\( x=0 \\)  is a regular singular point.\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle 2x^{{2}}y&#39;&#39;-xy&#39;+\\left(x^{{2}}+1\\right)y=0 \\) \n</p>\n<hr />\n<p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Problem_Setup\">Problem Setup</span></h2>\n<p>Substitute:<br /><br />\n \\( y=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}\\, \\)  ,   \\( \\displaystyle y&#39;=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}} \\)  ,  and  \\( \\displaystyle y&#39;&#39;=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Which yields:<br /><br />\n \\( \\displaystyle 2x^{{2}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}}-x\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}+x^{{2}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}+\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Simplify:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}-\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}+\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r+2}}+\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>We now want to have all the powers of x match.  In order to do this we will substitute k for the value of n:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k=n}}-\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k=n}}+\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r+2}}}}_{{k=n+2}}+\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k=n}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Which yields:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)C_{{k}}x^{{k+r}}-\\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k}}x^{{k+r}}+\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k=2}}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{{\\color {red}k-2}}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}+\\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{k}}x^{{k+r}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Notice that in the third term, the index of summation, the index for the constant, and exponent of  \\( x \\)  all changed.  Now, in order to add together the sums we need to have the indexes for each sum match.  To do this we list the terms for each sum at  \\( k=0,1,... \\)  until each index is the same.  In this example we need to have the  \\( k=0 \\)  indexes match the  \\( k=2 \\)  index so we list the terms at  \\( k=0 \\)  and  \\( k=1 \\) . In order to reduce the amount of work required we will add together the sums where  \\( k=0 \\)  and then factor out the  \\( C_{k} \\)  term. At this point we can also factor out the  \\( x^{r} \\)  term.<br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\displaystyle \\left[\\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}}+\\sum _{{k=2}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{k-2}}x^{{k}}\\right]x^{{r}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>From the sum:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The first two terms are:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2\\left(0+r\\right)(0+r-1)x^{{0}}-(0+r)x^{{0}}+x^{{0}}\\right]C_{{0}}=\\left(2r^{{2}}-3r+1\\right)C_{{0}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>and<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2\\left(1+r\\right)\\left(1+r-1\\right)x^{{1}}-(1+r)x^{{1}}+x^{{1}}\\right]C_{{1}}=\\left(2r^{{2}}+r\\right)C_{{1}}x \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Which finally gives us:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle x^{{r}}\\cdot \\left[\\left(2r^{{2}}-3r+1\\right)C_{{0}}+\\left(2r^{{2}}+r\\right)C_{{1}}x+\\sum _{{k=2}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}}+C_{{k-2}}x^{{k}}\\right]=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Solving\">Solving</span></h2>\n<p>Now we are ready to solve the equation.  We start by equating the terms on the left hand side with the terms on the right hand side (which are all equal to zero).  Which gives us the following implications:<br /><br />\n</p><p>(1)    \\( \\displaystyle \\left(2r^{{2}}-3r+1\\right)C_{{0}}=0\\rightarrow \\left(2r-1\\right)\\left(r-1\\right)C_{0}=0 \\)  hence  \\( \\displaystyle r=1 \\)  and  \\( \\displaystyle r={\\frac  {1}{2}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>(2)    \\( \\displaystyle \\left(2r^{{2}}+r\\right)C_{{1}}x=0 \\)  hence  \\( \\displaystyle C_{1}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>(3)    \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2\\left(k+r\\right)\\left(k+r-1\\right)x^{{k}}-\\left(k+r\\right)x^{{k}}+x^{{k}}\\right]C_{{k}}+C_{{k-2}}x^{{k}}=0\\;,\\;k=2,3,4,\\ldots  \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\;\\Rightarrow C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{2\\left(k+r\\right)(k+r-1)-\\left(k+r\\right)+1}}\\;,\\;k=2,3,4,\\ldots  \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p><p>We can now substitute the values for  \\( r \\)  that satisfy (1) into (3) to yield two different recurrence relations:\n</p><p>(4)    \\( \\displaystyle r={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\;,\\;C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{2\\left(k+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)(k+{\\frac  {1}{2}}-1)-\\left(k+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)+1}}\\;,\\;k=2,3,4,\\ldots  \\) <br />\n \\( \\displaystyle \\Rightarrow \\;C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k-1\\right)}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>(5)    \\( \\displaystyle {\\displaystyle r=1\\;,\\;C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{2\\left(k+1\\right)(k+1-1)-\\left(k+1\\right)+1}}\\;,\\;k=2,3,4,\\ldots } \\) <br />\n \\( \\displaystyle \\Rightarrow \\;C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k+1\\right)}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>And then using our values for  \\( k\\;,\\;k=2,3,4,\\ldots  \\)  we can find the series solutions for the differential equation.<br /><br />\n</p>\n<table align=\"center\" style=\"width: 85%; height: 300px\" border=\"1\">\n<tr>\n<th> \\( \\displaystyle k \\)   </th>\n<th>  (4)   \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k-1\\right)}} \\)   </th>\n<th>  (5)  \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k}}={\\frac  {-C_{{k-2}}}{k\\left(2k+1\\right)}} \\) \n</th></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle 2 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}={\\frac  {-C_{{0}}}{6}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}={\\frac  {-C_{{0}}}{10}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td> \\( \\displaystyle 3 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}=0 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}=0 \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td> \\( \\displaystyle 4 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{4}}={\\frac  {-C_{{2}}}{28}}={\\frac  {C_{0}}{168}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{4}}={\\frac  {-C_{{2}}}{36}}={\\frac  {C_{0}}{360}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td> \\( \\displaystyle 5 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{5}}=0 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C{5}=0 \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td> \\( \\displaystyle 6 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{6}}={\\frac  {-C_{{4}}}{66}}={\\frac  {-C_{0}}{11088}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{6}}={\\frac  {-C_{{4}}}{78}}={\\frac  {-C_{0}}{28080}} \\) \n</td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>And so on...\n</p><p>This gives us the terms for our infinite sum and from that we have the solutions to the differential equation.\n</p><p>For (4) where  \\( \\displaystyle r={\\frac  {1}{2}} \\)  let  \\( \\displaystyle C_{0}=1 \\)  so the sum is  \\( \\displaystyle y_{{1}}(x)=x^{{{\\frac  {1}{2}}}}\\left(1-{\\frac  {1}{6}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac  {1}{168}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac  {1}{11088}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>For (5) where  \\( \\displaystyle r=1 \\)  let  \\( \\displaystyle C_{0}=1 \\)  so the sum is  \\( \\displaystyle y_{{2}}(x)=x\\left(1-{\\frac  {1}{10}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac  {1}{360}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac  {1}{28080}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Which means the general solution  \\( \\displaystyle y=C_{{1}}y_{{1}}(x)+C_{{2}}y_{{2}}(x) \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle y=C_{{1}}x^{{{\\frac  {1}{2}}}}\\left(1-{\\frac  {1}{6}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac  {1}{168}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac  {1}{11088}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right)+C_{{2}}x\\left(1-{\\frac  {1}{10}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac  {1}{360}}x^{{4}}-{\\frac  {1}{28080}}x^{{6}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/ODE_RSP1", 
        "problem": " \\( 2x^{{2}}y&#39;&#39;-xy&#39;+\\left(x^{{2}}+1\\right)y=0\\, \\) \n"
    }, 
    {
        "title": "Ordinary Differential Equations Practice", 
        "tags": "Ordinary Differential Equations,Ordinary,Differential,Equations,About a regular singular point,About,regular,singular,point,Power Series,Power,Series", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>We use the method of Frobenius to obtain two linearly independent series solution. Where x=0 is a regular singular point of the differential equation. The general solution on  \\( (0,\\infty ) \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle 2xy&#39;&#39;-\\left(3+2x\\right)y&#39;+y=0 \\) \n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Problem_Setup\">Problem Setup</span></h2>\n<p>Let&#160;:<br /><br /> \\( \\displaystyle y=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}} \\)  ,\n \\( \\displaystyle y&#39;=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}} \\)  ,  and  \\( \\displaystyle y&#39;&#39;=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Substitute into DE:<br /><br />\n \\( \\displaystyle 2x\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-2}}-3\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}-2x\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}+\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Simplify:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}-\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}3\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}-\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}+\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>We want to have all the powers of x match.  In order to do this we will substitute k for the value of n:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)\\left(n+r-1\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}}}_{{k=n-1}}-\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}3\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r-1}}}}_{{k=n-1}}-\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(n+r\\right)C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k=n}}+\\underbrace {{\\sum _{{n=0}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{n}}x^{{n+r}}}}_{{k=n}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Which yields:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\sum _{{{\\color {red}k=-1}}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k+1}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}-\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k=-1}}}^{{\\infty }}3\\left(k+r+1\\right)C_{{k+1}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}-\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k=0}}}^{{\\infty }}2\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}+\\sum _{{{\\color {red}k=0}}}^{{\\infty }}C_{{k}}x^{{{\\color {red}k+r}}}=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now, in order to add together the sums we need to have the indexes for each sum match.  To do this we list the terms for the first and second sum at  \\( k=-1 \\) .  In this example we need to have the  \\( k=-1 \\)  indexes match the  \\( k=0 \\) . In order to reduce the amount of work required we will add together the sums where  \\( k=-1 \\)  and then factor out the  \\( C_{k}+1 \\)  term. At this point we can also factor out the  \\( x^{r} \\)  term.<br /><br />\n</p><p>The first two terms are:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle \\left[2r\\left(r-1\\right)C_{{0}}x^{{-1}}-3rC_{{0}}x^{{-1}}\\right]x^{{r}}=\\left[r\\left(2r-5\\right)C_{{0}}x^{{-1}}\\right]x^{{r}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>From the sum we have:\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle x^{{r}}\\left[\\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}\\left[2\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k+1}}-3\\left(k+r+1\\right)C_{{k+1}}-2\\left(k+r\\right)C_{{k}}+C_{{k}}\\right]x^{k}\\right]=x^{{r}}\\left[\\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}[C_{{k+1}}\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(2k+2r-3\\right)-C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)]x^{k}\\right] \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Finally we now have:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle x^{{r}}\\left[r\\left(2r-5\\right)C_{{0}}x^{{-1}}+\\sum _{{k=0}}^{{\\infty }}[C_{{k+1}}\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(2k+2r-3\\right)-C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)]x^{k}\\right]=0 \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Solving\">Solving</span></h2>\n<p>Now we are ready to solve the equation.  We start by equating the terms on the left hand side with the terms on the right hand side (which are all equal to zero).  Which gives us the following implications:<br /><br />\n</p><p>(1)    \\( \\displaystyle r\\left(2r-5\\right)C_{{0}}=0\\rightarrow  \\)  the indicial roots are:   \\( \\displaystyle \\;r=0\\; \\)  and  \\( \\displaystyle \\;r={\\frac  {5}{2}}\\; \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n(2)    \\( \\displaystyle C_{{k+1}}\\left(k+r+1\\right)\\left(2k+2r-3\\right)-C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)=0,\\;k=0,1,2,\\ldots  \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The recurrence relation is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\;\\Rightarrow C_{{k+1}}={\\frac  {C_{{k}}\\left(2k+2r-1\\right)}{\\left(k+r+1\\right)(2k+2r-3)}}\\;,\\;k=0,1,2,\\ldots  \\) \n<br /><br />\n</p><p>We can now substitute the values for  \\( \\displaystyle r \\)  that satisfy (1) into (2) to yield two different recurrence relations:\n</p><p>(4)    \\( r=0\\;,\\;C_{{k+1}}={\\frac  {C_{{k}}\\left(2k-1\\right)}{\\left(k+1\\right)(2k-3)}}\\;,\\;k=0,1,2,\\ldots  \\) <br />\n</p><p>(5)    \\( r={\\frac  {5}{2}}\\;,\\;C_{{k+1}}={\\frac  {C_{{k}}\\left(2k+4\\right)}{\\left(2k+7\\right)(k+1)}}\\;,\\;k=0,1,2,\\ldots  \\) <br />\n</p><p><br />\nNow we can let  \\( \\;k=0,1,2,\\ldots  \\)  on equations (4) and (5) for the first 3 terms:<br /><br />\n</p>\n<table align=\"center\" style=\"width: 85%; height: 300px\" border=\"1\">\n<tr>\n<th> \\( \\displaystyle k \\)   </th>\n<th>  (4)   \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k+1}}={\\frac  {C_{{k}}\\left(2k-1\\right)}{\\left(k+1\\right)(2k-3)}} \\)   </th>\n<th>  (5)  \\( \\displaystyle \\;\\;C_{{k+1}}={\\frac  {C_{{k}}\\left(2k+4\\right)}{\\left(2k+7\\right)(k+1)}} \\) \n</th></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle 0 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{1}}={\\frac  {C_{{0}}}{3}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{1}}={\\frac  {4}{7}}C_{{0}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td> \\( \\displaystyle 1 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}={\\frac  {-C_{{0}}}{6}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{2}}={\\frac  {4}{21}}C_{{0}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"center\">\n<td> \\( \\displaystyle 2 \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}={\\frac  {-C_{{0}}}{6}} \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( \\displaystyle C_{{3}}={\\frac  {32}{693}}C_{{0}} \\) \n</td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>And so on ... <br /><br />\nFor simplification purposes we let   \\( \\displaystyle C_{0}=1 \\) <br />  \nso we get the general solution to the differential equation on  \\( (0,\\infty ) \\) &#160;:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\displaystyle y(x)=C_{{1}}\\left(1+{\\frac  {1}{3}}x-{\\frac  {1}{6}}x^{{2}}-{\\frac  {1}{6}}x^{{3}}+\\ldots \\right)+C_{{2}}x^{{{\\frac  {5}{2}}}}\\left(1+{\\frac  {4}{7}}x+{\\frac  {4}{21}}x^{{2}}+{\\frac  {32}{693}}x^{{3}}+\\ldots \\right) \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.196 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.857 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 241/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 852/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33295-0!*!*!!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034153 and revision id 45475\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p> \\( y&#39;&#39;-y=e^{{-t}},\\,\\,\\,y(0)=1,y&#39;(0)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathcal  {L}}[y&#39;&#39;-y]={\\mathcal  {L}}[e^{{-t}}]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( Y={\\mathcal  {L}}[y]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathcal  {L}}[y&#39;&#39;-y]={\\mathcal  {L}}[y&#39;&#39;]-{\\mathcal  {L}}[y]=s^{2}Y-sf(0)-f&#39;(0)-Y\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =s^{2}Y-s-Y={\\frac  {1}{s+1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>At this point all the information from the IC's are encoded into the transform. Solve for  \\( Y \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y={\\frac  {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>Find the partial fraction decomposition of  \\( {\\frac  {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}={\\frac  {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)^{2}(s-1)}}={\\frac  {A}{(s+1)^{2}}}+{\\frac  {B}{s+1}}+{\\frac  {C}{s-1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Multiply both sides by the common denominator.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( s^{2}+s+1=A(s-1)+B(s+1)(s-1)+C(s+1)^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( s^{2}+s+1=s^{2}(B+C)+s(A+2C)+(-A-B+C)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Compare coefficients.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( B+C=1,\\,\\,\\,A+2C=1,\\,\\,\\,-A-B+C=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Solve this system of equations. The augmented matrix has equations as rows and variables as columns. The last column is the value of each equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\begin{bmatrix}A&amp;B&amp;C&amp;{}\\\\0&amp;1&amp;1&amp;1\\\\1&amp;0&amp;2&amp;1\\\\-1&amp;-1&amp;1&amp;1\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}A&amp;B&amp;C&amp;{}\\\\1&amp;0&amp;2&amp;1\\\\-1&amp;-1&amp;1&amp;1\\\\0&amp;1&amp;1&amp;1\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}A&amp;B&amp;C&amp;{}\\\\1&amp;0&amp;2&amp;1\\\\0&amp;-1&amp;3&amp;2\\\\0&amp;1&amp;1&amp;1\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}={\\begin{bmatrix}A&amp;B&amp;C&amp;{}\\\\1&amp;0&amp;2&amp;1\\\\0&amp;-1&amp;3&amp;2\\\\0&amp;0&amp;4&amp;3\\\\\\end{bmatrix}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So  \\( C=3/4,\\,\\,\\,B=1/4,\\,\\,\\,A=-1/2\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {s^{2}+s+1}{(s+1)(s^{2}-1)}}={\\frac  {-1/2}{(s+1)^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1/4}{s+1}}+{\\frac  {-1/2}{s-1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<hr />\n<p>So  \\( Y={\\frac  {-1/2}{(s+1)^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1/4}{s+1}}+{\\frac  {-1/2}{s-1}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the tables <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laplace_transform\">here</a> to find the inverse Laplace transforms.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( y(t)={\\mathcal  {L}}^{{-1}}[Y]={\\frac  {-1}{2}}(te^{{-t}})+{\\frac  {1}{4}}e^{{-t}}+{\\frac  {3}{4}}e^{t}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential Equations\">Ordinary Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Functional Analysis Practice", 
        "tags": "Functional Analysis,Functional,Analysis", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Let  \\( X\\, \\)  and  \\( Y\\, \\)  be <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Metric_spaces\" title=\"Metric spaces\" class=\"mw-redirect\">metric spaces</a>, and  \\( f:X\\to Y\\, \\)  be a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Mapping\" title=\"Mapping\" class=\"mw-redirect\">mapping</a>.\n</p><p>(i) Prove that if  \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  is <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Open\" title=\"Open\" class=\"mw-redirect\">open</a> whenever  \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\)  is open, then  \\( f\\, \\)  is <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Continuous\" title=\"Continuous\" class=\"mw-redirect\">continuous</a>.\n</p><p>(ii) Prove that  \\( f\\, \\)  is continuous <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/If_and_only_if\" title=\"If and only if\">if and only if</a>  \\( f^{{-1}}(F)\\, \\)  is <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Closed\" title=\"Closed\" class=\"mw-redirect\">closed</a> whenever  \\( F\\subset Y\\, \\)  is closed.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\".28i.29\">(i)</span></h2>\n<p><font size=\"3\">\nSuppose  \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  is open whenever  \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\)  is open. Let  \\( x_{0}\\in X\\, \\)  and  \\( \\epsilon &gt;0\\, \\) . Since the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ball\" title=\"Ball\" class=\"mw-redirect\">ball</a>  \\( B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\, \\)  is open, so is  \\( f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon ))\\right]\\, \\) . Since  \\( f(x_{0})\\in B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon ),x_{0}\\in f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\right]\\, \\) . Since  \\( f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\right] \\)  is open there exists a  \\( \\delta &gt;0\\, \\)  such that  \\( B(x_{0},\\delta )\\subset f^{{-1}}\\left[B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\right]\\, \\) . This implies  \\( f(B(x_{0},\\delta ))\\subset B(f(x_{0}),\\epsilon )\\, \\)  making  \\( f\\, \\)  continuous at  \\( x_{0}\\, \\) . Since  \\( x_{0}\\, \\)  was arbitrary,  \\( f\\, \\)  is continuous.\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\".28ii.29\">(ii)</span></h2>\n<p>Suppose  \\( f^{{-1}}(F)\\, \\)  is closed whenever  \\( F\\in Y\\, \\)  is closed. Let  \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\)  be open. Then  \\( G^{c}\\, \\)  is closed. By the hypothesis,  \\( f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\\, \\)  is closed. \n</p><p>If  \\( x\\in f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\\, \\) , then  \\( f(x)\\in G^{c},f(x)\\notin G,x\\notin f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  and  \\( x\\in \\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\) . Similarly, if  \\( x\\in \\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\)  then  \\( x\\notin f^{{-1}}(G),f(x)\\notin G,f(x)\\in G^{c}\\, \\) , and  \\( x\\in f^{{-1}}(G^{c})\\, \\) . Therefore  \\( f^{{-1}}(G^{c})=\\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Now,  \\( f^{{-1}}(G^{c})=\\left[f^{{-1}}(G)\\right]^{c}\\, \\)  is closed, so  \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  is open. So  \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  is open whenever  \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\)  is open. From part (i),  \\( f\\, \\)  is continuous.\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Suppose  \\( f\\, \\)  is continuous. Let  \\( G\\subset Y\\, \\)  be closed. Let  \\( \\{x_{n}\\}\\subset f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  converge to  \\( x\\in X\\, \\) . Since  \\( f\\, \\)  is continuous  \\( \\{f(x_{n})\\}\\subset G\\, \\)  converges to  \\( f(x)\\in Y\\, \\) . Since  \\( G\\, \\)  is closed,  \\( f(x)\\in G\\, \\)  and so  \\( x\\in f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  which means  \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  is closed (since this is the limit of the arbitrary sequence chosen above). Therefore  \\( f^{{-1}}(G)\\, \\)  is closed whenever  \\( G\\, \\)  is closed.\n</p><p><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/FA1",

        "solution": "<p>(i) Let  \\( X=C[0,1]\\, \\)  with maximum <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Metric\" title=\"Metric\" class=\"mw-redirect\">metric</a>  \\( d(f,g)=\\max\\{|f(t)-g(t)|:t\\in [0,1]\\}\\, \\) . Prove that  \\( C[0,1]\\, \\)  is <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Seperable\" title=\"Seperable\" class=\"mw-redirect\">separable</a>.\n</p><p>(ii) Use (i) to prove that  \\( X=C[0,1]\\, \\)  is also separable with respect to the metric  \\( \\rho (f,g)=\\left(\\int _{0}^{1}|f(t)-g(t)|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\, \\) .\n</p>\n<div id=\"toc\" class=\"toc\"><div id=\"toctitle\"><h2>Contents</h2>",

    }, 
    {
        "title": "Functional Analysis Practice", 
        "tags": "Functional Analysis,Functional,Analysis", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Assume  \\( \\sup \\left\\{|x_{n}(t)-x(t)|:t\\in [0,1]\\right\\}\\to 0\\, \\)  as  \\( n\\to \\infty \\, \\) . Prove that  \\( x(t)\\, \\)  is <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Continuous\" title=\"Continuous\" class=\"mw-redirect\">continuous</a> when  \\( x_{n}(t)\\, \\)  is continuous for all  \\( n\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n<font size=\"3\">\n</p><p>Suppose  \\( x_{n}(t)\\, \\)  is continuous for all  \\( t\\in [0,1]\\, \\) , and all  \\( n\\, \\) . Let  \\( t_{0}\\in [0,1]\\, \\) . Then  \\( |x_{0}(t)-x_{n}(t_{0})|\\to 0\\, \\)  as  \\( t\\to t_{0}\\, \\)  for all  \\( n\\, \\) . Let  \\( \\epsilon &gt;0\\, \\) . There exists an  \\( N\\, \\)  such that whenever  \\( n&gt;N\\, \\) ,  \\( \\sup _{{t\\in [0,1]}}|x_{n}(t)-x(t)|&lt;{\\frac  {\\epsilon }{3}}\\, \\) . Let  \\( n=N+1\\, \\)  so that there is no dependence on  \\( n\\, \\) . There exists a  \\( \\delta \\, \\)  such that  \\( |x_{{N+1}}(t)-x_{{N+1}}(t_{0})|&lt;{\\frac  {\\epsilon }{3}}\\, \\)  whenever  \\( |t-t_{0}|&lt;\\delta ,t\\in [0,1]\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( |t-t_{0}|&lt;\\delta ,t\\in [0,1],n&gt;N\\, \\) . Then by the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Triangle_inequality\" title=\"Triangle inequality\">triangle inequality</a>,\n</p><p> \\( |x(t)-x(t_{0})|\\leq |x(t)-x_{{N+1}}(t)|+|x_{{N+1}}(t)-x_{{N+1}}(t_{0})|+|x_{{N+1}}(t_{0})-x(t_{0})|\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\leq {\\frac  {\\epsilon }{3}}+{\\frac  {\\epsilon }{3}}+{\\frac  {\\epsilon }{3}}=\\epsilon \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nSince  \\( t_{0}\\, \\)  was arbitrary,  \\( x\\, \\)  is continuous whenever  \\( x_{n}\\, \\)  is continuous for all  \\( n\\, \\) .\n</font>\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Show that any <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Cauchy_sequence\" title=\"Cauchy sequence\">Cauchy sequence</a> in a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Metric_space\" title=\"Metric space\">metric space</a> is always <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Bounded\" title=\"Bounded\" class=\"mw-redirect\">bounded</a>.\n</p><p><br />\n<font size=\"3\">\nLet  \\( \\{x_{j}\\}_{{j=1}}^{\\infty }\\, \\)  be a Cauchy sequence in the metric space  \\( (X,d)\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nSince  \\( \\{x_{j}\\}\\, \\)  is Cauchy, there exists an  \\( M\\, \\)  such that  \\( d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})&lt;1\\, \\)  for all  \\( j&gt;M\\, \\) . For  \\( 1\\leq j\\leq M\\, \\) , let  \\( \\delta _{j}=d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})\\, \\) . \n</p><p><br />\nNow choose  \\( \\delta &gt;\\max _{{j\\in (1,...,M)}}\\{1,\\delta _{j}\\}\\, \\) . Let  \\( B=B(x_{{M+1}},\\delta )\\subset X\\, \\) . Notice for  \\( 1\\leq j\\leq M,d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})=\\delta _{j}&lt;\\delta \\, \\) , so  \\( x_{j}\\in B\\, \\) . For  \\( j&gt;M,d(x_{{M+1}},x_{j})&lt;1&lt;\\delta \\, \\) , so  \\( x_{j}\\in B\\, \\) . \n</p><p><br />\nWe have  \\( \\{x_{j}\\}\\subset B\\, \\)  making  \\( \\{x_{j}\\}\\, \\)  bounded.\n</p><p><br />\nIn general, any Cauchy sequence in a metric space is bounded.\n</font>\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

    {
        "title": "Functional Analysis Practice", 
        "tags": "Functional Analysis,Functional,Analysis", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Let  \\( x_{j},y_{j}\\in {\\mathbb  {R}}\\, \\)  for  \\( j=1,2,...,n\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\".28i.29\">(i)</span></h2>\n<p>Show that  \\( \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( f(t)\\, \\)  be a <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Quadratic_function\" title=\"Quadratic function\">quadratic function</a>  \\( f(t)=t^{2}\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}+2t\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}+\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( f(t)=\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}(t^{2}x_{j}^{2}+2tx_{j}y_{j}+y_{j}^{2})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}(tx_{j}+y_{j})^{2}\\geq 0\\, \\)  for  \\( t,x_{j},y_{j}\\in {\\mathbb  {R}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Since the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Parabola\" title=\"Parabola\">parabola</a>  \\( f(t):{\\mathbb  {R}}\\to {\\mathbb  {R}}\\, \\)  has at most one zero, its <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Discriminant\" title=\"Discriminant\">discriminant</a> is less than or equal to zero.\n</p><p> \\( 4\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}\\right)^{2}-4\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}\\cdot \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\leq 0\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nAnd therefore\n</p><p> \\( \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}\\leq |\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}y_{j}|\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}x_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}y_{j}^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\".28ii.29\">(ii)</span></h2>\n<p>Use (i) to prove that  \\( \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}y_{j}|\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>In the result (i), replace  \\( x_{j} \\)  by  \\( |x_{j}| \\)  and  \\( y_{j} \\)  by  \\( |y_{j}| \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}y_{j}|=\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}||y_{j}|\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\".28iii.29\">(iii)</span></h2>\n<p>Use (ii) to get  \\( \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}+y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Notice  \\( \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}+y_{j}|^{2}\\leq \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}\\left(|x_{j}|+|y_{j}|\\right)^{2}\\, \\)  by the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Triangle_inequality\" title=\"Triangle inequality\">triangle inequality</a>.\n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}+2\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}y_{j}|+\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\leq \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}+2\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\, \\)  from (ii).\n</p><p> \\( =\\left[\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\right]^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Since  \\( \\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}+y_{j}|^{2}\\geq 0\\, \\) , we conclude,\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}+y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\leq \\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|x_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}+\\left(\\sum _{{j=1}}^{n}|y_{j}|^{2}\\right)^{{1/2}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "problem": "Let  \\( x_{j},y_{j}\\in {\\mathbb  {R}}\\, \\)  for  \\( j=1,2,...,n\\, \\) .\n"

        "title": "Functional Analysis Practice", 
        "tags": "Functional Analysis,Functional,Analysis", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Use the inequality  \\( \\alpha \\beta \\leq {\\frac  {\\alpha ^{p}}{p}}+{\\frac  {\\beta ^{q}}{q}}\\, \\)  for  \\( \\alpha ,\\beta \\geq 0,{\\frac  {1}{p}}+{\\frac  {1}{q}}=1\\, \\)  to prove that\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)g(t)\\right|dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)\\right|^{p}\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|g(t)\\right|^{q}\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nfor  \\( p&gt;1\\, \\)  and  \\( {\\frac  {1}{p}}+{\\frac  {1}{q}}=1\\, \\) , and then use this to prove the triangular inequality:\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)+g(t)\\right|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|f(t)\\right|^{p}\\right)^{{1/p}}+\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}\\left|g(t)\\right|^{p}\\right)^{{1/p}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"First_Part\">First Part</span></h2>\n<p>Let  \\( {\\hat  {f}}\\, \\)  and  \\( {\\hat  {g}}\\, \\)  be such that  \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|{\\hat  {f}}|^{p}dt=\\int _{a}^{b}|{\\hat  {g}}|dt=1\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( \\alpha =|{\\hat  {f}}|\\, \\)  and  \\( \\beta =|{\\hat  {g}}|\\, \\) . \n</p><p><br />\nUsing the inequality,  \\( |{\\hat  {f}}{\\hat  {g}}|\\leq |{\\hat  {f}}||{\\hat  {g}}|\\leq {\\frac  {|{\\hat  {f}}|^{p}}{p}}+{\\frac  {|{\\hat  {g}}|^{q}}{q}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Now integrate from  \\( a\\, \\)  to  \\( b\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|{\\hat  {f}}{\\hat  {g}}|dt\\leq \\int _{a}^{b}{\\frac  {|{\\hat  {f}}|^{p}}{p}}dt+\\int _{a}^{b}{\\frac  {|{\\hat  {g}}|^{q}}{q}}dt={\\frac  {1}{p}}+{\\frac  {1}{q}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Set  \\( {\\hat  {f}}={\\frac  {f}{\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}}}\\, \\)  and  \\( {\\hat  {g}}={\\frac  {g}{\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{q}dt\\right)^{{1/q}}}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Plug these into the previous equation and multiply by the denominator:\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|fg|dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{q}dt\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"Second_Part\">Second Part</span></h2>\n<p> \\( |f+g|^{p}=|f+g||f+g|^{{p-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\leq (|f|+|g|)|f+g|^{{p-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( |f||f+g|^{{p-1}}+|g||f+g|^{{p-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Therefore\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\leq \\int _{a}^{b}|f||f+g|^{{p+1}}dt+\\int _{a}^{b}|g||f+g|^{{(p-1)q}}dt\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>From the first part,\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|f||f+g|^{{p-1}}dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{{(p-1)q}}\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|g||f+g|^{{p-1}}dt\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{{(p-1)q}}\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {1}{p}}+{\\frac  {1}{q}}=1\\implies q+p=pq\\implies (p-1)q=p\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nAdding these two integrals,\n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\leq \\left[\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}+\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\right]\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/q}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nMultiply both sides by the inverse of the last term and use  \\( 1-{\\frac  {1}{q}}={\\frac  {1}{p}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f+g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\leq \\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|f|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}+\\left(\\int _{a}^{b}|g|^{p}dt\\right)^{{1/p}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

Prove that  \\( M\\, \\)  is compact in  \\( (X,||\\cdot ||_{1})\\, \\)  if and only if  \\( M\\, \\)  is compact in  \\( (X,||\\cdot ||_{2})\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Since  \\( M\\, \\)  is compact in  \\( (X,||\\cdot ||_{1})\\, \\) , every sequence  \\( \\{x_{n}\\}\\, \\)  in  \\( M\\, \\)  has a convergent subsequence  \\( \\{x_{{n_{k}}}\\}\\, \\)  that converges to  \\( x\\in M\\, \\) . This means  \\( \\forall \\epsilon &gt;0,\\exists K\\, \\)  s.t.  \\( ||x-x_{{n_{k}}}||_{1}&lt;\\epsilon \\forall k&gt;K\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p> \\( ||\\cdot ||_{1}\\, \\)  and  \\( ||\\cdot ||_{2}\\, \\)  are equivalent norms iff  \\( \\exists a,b\\, \\)  s.t.  \\( a||\\cdot ||_{1}\\leq ||\\cdot ||_{2}\\leq b||\\cdot ||_{1}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nSo  \\( b||\\cdot ||_{1}&lt;b\\epsilon \\, \\) .         "solution": "<p>Show that the four points in the Argand plane represented by the complex numbers are the vertices of a square  \\( 2+i,4+3i,2+5i,3i\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>From the given complex numbers,we can derive the points in the plane as \n \\( (2,1)(4,3)(2,5)(0,3)\\, \\) <br /><br />\nLet the points represent the four sides of a squate respectively  \\( A,B,C,D\\, \\) <br /><br />\nNow writing the line equation  \\( AB\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {AB}}=(y-1)=({\\frac  {3-1}{4-2}})(x-2)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {AB}}=(y-1)=(x-2)\\, \\) <br /><br />\nSimplifying further we get\n \\( {\\bar  {AB}}=x-y-1=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\nNow writing the line equation  \\( BC\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {BC}}=(y-3)=({\\frac  {5-3}{2-4}})(x-4)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {BC}}=(y-3)=(4-x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {BC}}=x+y-7=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\nNow writing the line equation  \\( CD\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {CD}}=(y-5)=({\\frac  {3-5}{0-2}})(x-2)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {CD}}=(y-5)=(x-2)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {CD}}=-x+y-3=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\nNow writing the line equation  \\( DA\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {DA}}=(y-3)=({\\frac  {1-3}{2-0}})(x-0)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {DA}}=(y-3)=(-1)(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( {\\bar  {DA}}=x+y-3)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThe slope of  \\( {\\bar  {AB}}=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThe slope of  \\( {\\bar  {BC}}=-1\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThe slope of  \\( {\\bar  {CD}}=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThe slope of  \\( {\\bar  {DA}}=-1\\, \\) <br /><br />\nFrom these slopes,the slopes of opposite sides are equal,which means they are parallel to each other and product of the one to the next is -1,which means they are perpendicular.\nThe lenth of  \\( AB={\\sqrt  {(2-4)^{2}+(1-3)^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br /> \n \\( AB={\\sqrt  {8}}\\, \\) <br /><br /> \nThe lenth of  \\( BC={\\sqrt  {(4-2)^{2}+(3-5)^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br /> \n \\( BC={\\sqrt  {8}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThe lenth of  \\( CD={\\sqrt  {(2-0)^{2}+(5-3)^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br /> \n \\( CD={\\sqrt  {8}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\nThe lenth of  \\( DA={\\sqrt  {(2-0)^{2}+(1-3)^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br /> \n \\( DA={\\sqrt  {8}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\nFrom the above all the sides are equal.\nHence all these conditions prove that the numbers form the vertices of a square.\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Evaluate  \\( {\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[(a+bi)^{p}\\right]\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"with_complex_variables\">with complex variables</span></h2>\n<p>Write  \\( (a+bi)^{p}=e^{{\\tan ^{{-1}}p{\\frac  {b}{a}}}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Now  \\( {\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[e^{{\\tan ^{{-1}}p{\\frac  {b}{a}}}}\\right]=\\cos(p\\tan ^{{-1}}{\\frac  {b}{a}})\\, \\) .\n</p>\n<h2><span class=\"mw-headline\" id=\"with_regular_calculus\">with regular calculus</span></h2>\n<p>The binomial theorem and Pochhammer symbols give another way to write the quantity<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( (a+b)^{p}=\\sum _{{j=0}}^{\\infty }{p \\choose j}a^{j}b^{{p-j}}=\\sum _{{j=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {(-1)^{j}}{j!}}(-p)_{j}a^{j}b^{{p-j}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So,\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[(a+bi)^{p}\\right]={\\mathrm  {Re}}\\sum _{{j=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {(-1)^{j}}{j!}}(-p)_{j}a^{j}(bi)^{{p-j}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{j=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {(-1)^{j}}{j!}}(-p)_{j}a^{j}b^{{p-j}}{\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[i^{{p-j}}\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =b^{p}\\sum _{{j=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {\\left(-{\\frac  {a}{b}}\\right)^{j}}{j!}}(-p)_{j}{\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[i^{{p-j}}\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Write  \\( i=\\exp \\left(i{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}+2\\pi ik\\right),k\\in {\\mathbb  {Z}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( i^{{p-j}}=\\exp \\left(i{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}(p-j)+2\\pi ik(p-j)\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[i^{{p-j}}\\right]=\\cos \\left[{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}(p-j)+2\\pi k(p-j)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Finally,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Re}}\\left[(a+bi)^{p}\\right]=b^{p}\\sum _{{j=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {\\left(-{\\frac  {a}{b}}\\right)^{j}}{j!}}(-p)_{j}\\cos \\left[{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}(p-j)+2\\pi k(p-j)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>If  \\( u(x,y)=e^{x}\\sin y\\, \\)  find  \\( f(x,y)=u(x,y)+iv(x,y)\\, \\)  and check if it satisfies the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Cauchy-Riemann_equations\" title=\"Cauchy-Riemann equations\">Cauchy-Riemann equations</a>.<br /><br />\n</p><p>The Cauchy-Riemann equations are  \\( u_{x}=v_{y},v_{x}=-u_{y}\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{x}=e^{x}\\sin y\\, \\) ,  \\( u_{y}=e^{x}\\cos y\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( v_{y}=e^{x}\\sin y\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( v=-e^{x}\\cos y+g(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( v_{x}=-e^{x}\\cos y+g&#39;(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>For the CR equations to hold, we must have  \\( g&#39;(x)=0\\, \\)  so that  \\( g(x)=c\\in {\\mathbb  {R}}\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x,y)=e^{x}\\sin y+i(-e^{x}\\cos y+c)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =e^{x}(\\sin y-i\\cos y)+ic\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =-ie^{x}(\\cos y+{\\frac  {1}{-i}}\\sin y)+ic\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( =-ie^{x}e^{{iy}}+ic=-ie^{z}+ic\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>",

If  \\( \\Delta y=0\\, \\)  then  \\( \\lim =1 \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>But the limit should be the same no matter which direction the limit takes to zero. So the function is non-analytic everywhere because the derivative does not exist.<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Complex_Variables\" title=\"Complex Variables\">Complex Variables</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the domain of analyticity for  \\( f(z)={\\mathrm  {Log}}(3z-i)\\, \\) \n</p><p>The principal valued  \\( {\\mathrm  {Log}}\\, \\)  is analytic everywhere except the ray in the complex plane  \\( x\\leq 0,y=0\\, \\) . In this case,\n</p><p> \\( 3z-i=3(x+iy)-i=3x+i(3y-1)\\, \\)  so this function is not analytic when  \\( x\\leq 0\\, \\)  and  \\( y=1/3\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Now, in this slit plane the derivative can be computed:\n</p><p> \\( f&#39;(z)={\\frac  {1}{3z-i}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}(3z-i)={\\frac  {3}{3z-i}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Complex Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "Complex Variables,Complex,Variables,Series", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the Laurent series for  \\( {\\frac  {1}{z^{2}(z-1)}}\\, \\)  about all its singular points.\n</p><p>The singularities are  \\( z=0,1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Centered at the singular point  \\( z_{0}=0\\, \\)  there are two possible Laurent series. One valid for  \\( 0&lt;|z|&lt;1\\, \\)  and one for  \\( |z|&gt;1\\, \\) . \n</p><p>In the domain  \\( 0&lt;|z|&lt;1\\, \\) ,  \\( {\\frac  {1}{z^{2}(z-1)}}=-{\\frac  {1}{z^{2}}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }z^{n}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =-\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }z^{{n-2}}=-\\sum _{{n=-2}}^{\\infty }z^{n}\\, \\) \n</p><p>For the domain  \\( |z|&gt;1\\, \\) , \\( {\\frac  {1}{z^{2}(z-1)}}={\\frac  {1/z}{z^{2}(1-1/z)}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{z^{3}}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)^{n}=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)^{{n+3}}=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }\\left({\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)^{{n+3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( n\\to -n-3\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{n=-\\infty }}^{{-3}}z^{{n}},|z|&gt;1\\, \\) \n</p><p>For the singular point  \\( z=1\\, \\)  make a change of variables  \\( u=z-1\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{z^{2}(z-1)}}={\\frac  {1}{(u+1)^{2}u}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now when  \\( 0&lt;|u|&lt;1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{(u+1)^{2}u}}={\\frac  {1}{u}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{n}(n+1)u^{n}{\\Bigg |}_{{u=z-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{z-1}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{n}(n+1)(z-1)^{{n-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{n}(n+1)(z-1)^{{n-2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>With a change of index  \\( n\\to n+1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\sum _{{n=-1}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{{n+1}}(n+2)(z-1)^{n},0&lt;|z-1|&lt;z\\, \\) \n</p><p>When  \\( |u|&gt;1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{(u+1)^{2}u}}={\\frac  {1}{u^{3}(1+1/u)^{2}}}={\\frac  {1}{u^{3}}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{n}(n+1)u^{{-n}}{\\Bigg |}_{{u=z-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{(z-1)^{3}}}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{n}(n+1)(z-1)^{{-n}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }(-1)^{n}(n+1)(z-1)^{{-n-3}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\sum _{{n=-\\infty }}^{{-3}}(-1)^{n}(n+2)(z-1)^{n},|z-1|&gt;1\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/CVS3",

        "title": "Complex Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "Complex Variables,Complex,Variables,Series", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the Laurent series about  \\( z_{0}=1\\, \\)  for the function  \\( {\\frac  {e^{{2z}}}{(z-1)^{3}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The only singularity is at  \\( z=1\\, \\)  so the series will look like\n</p><p> \\( \\sum _{{n=-\\infty }}^{{\\infty }}A_{n}(z-1)^{n},0&lt;|z-1|&lt;\\infty \\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( A_{n}={\\frac  {1}{2\\pi i}}\\oint _{C}{\\frac  {f(z)}{(z-1)^{{n+1}}}}dz={\\frac  {1}{2\\pi i}}\\oint _{C}{\\frac  {e^{{2z}}}{(z-1)^{{n+4}}}}dz,n=0,\\pm 1,\\pm 2,...\\, \\) \n</p><p>where  \\( C\\, \\)  is any simple closed curve around the point  \\( z=1\\, \\) .\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Cauchy%27s_theorem\" title=\"Cauchy's theorem\">Cauchy's theorem</a> gives  \\( A_{n}=0,n=-4,-5,...\\, \\) \n</p><p>For  \\( n\\geq 3\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( A_{n}={\\frac  {1}{(n+3)!}}{\\frac  {d^{{n+3}}}{dz^{{n+3}}}}e^{{2z}}{\\Bigg |}_{{z=1}}={\\frac  {e^{2}2^{{n+3}}}{(n+3)!}},n\\geq 3\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The Laurent series is\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {e^{{2z}}}{(z-1)^{3}}}=8e^{2}\\sum _{{n=-3}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {2^{n}}{(n+3)!}}(z-1)^{n},0&lt;|z-1|&lt;\\infty \\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "tags": "Complex Variables,Complex,Variables,Residues", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is given by\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {1}{z^{3}-z^{5}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z^{3}-z^{5}=z^{3}(1-z^{2})\\, \\)  has roots at  \\( z=0,\\pm 1\\, \\)  with multiplicities  \\( k=3,1,1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Use the formula  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=z_{0}^{k}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac  {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=0^{3}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(3-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {d^{2}}{{dz}^{2}}}\\left[(z-0)^{3}f(z)\\right]={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {d^{2}}{{dz}^{2}}}{\\frac  {1}{1-z^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}\\left[{\\frac  {2z}{(1-z^{2})^{2}}}\\right]={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {(1-z^{2})^{2}2-2z2(1-z^{2})(-2z)}{(1-z^{2})^{4}}}={\\frac  {1}{2}}{\\frac  {2}{1}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-1}}f(z)=\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}(z+1)f(z)=\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac  {1}{z^{3}(1-z)}}={\\frac  {-1}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=1}}f(z)=\\lim _{{z\\to 1}}(z-1)f(z)=-\\lim _{{z\\to 1}}{\\frac  {1}{z^{3}(1+z)}}={\\frac  {-1}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  equals 0.\n</p><p>So  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=0}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-1}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=1}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=1-{\\frac  {1}{2}}-{\\frac  {1}{2}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=0\\, \\)  and  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/CVR1", 
        "problem": " \\( {\\frac  {1}{z^{3}-z^{5}}}\\, \\) \n"

        "title": "Complex Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "Complex Variables,Complex,Variables,Residues", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is given by\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {z^{{2n}}}{(1+z)^{n}}},n\\in {\\mathbb  {Z^{+}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>This has a pole at  \\( z=-1\\, \\)  of multiplicity  \\( k=n\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Use the formula  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=z_{0}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac  {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-1}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(n-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac  {d^{{n-1}}}{{dz}^{{n-1}}}}(z+1)^{n}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(n-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac  {d^{{n-1}}}{{dz}^{{n-1}}}}z^{{2n}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The derivative can be computed like this:\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d^{{n-1}}}{{dz}^{{n-1}}}}z^{{2n}}=(2n)(2n-1)(2n-2)\\cdot \\cdot \\cdot (2n-n)z^{{2n-(n-1)}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>multiplicand numerador and denominador for  \\( (n-1)!\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {(2n)!}{(n-1)!}}z^{{n+1}}={\\frac  {(2n)!}{(n-1)!}}z^{{n+1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now,\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-1}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(n-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac  {(2n)!}{(n-1)!}}z^{{n+1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {(2n)!}{[(n-1)!]^{2}}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}z^{{n+1}}={\\frac  {(2n)!}{[(n-1)!]^{2}}}\\cos(n+1)\\pi \\, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  equals 0.\n</p><p>Therefore  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}f(z)={\\frac  {(2n)!}{[(n-1)!]^{2}}}\\cos(n+1)\\pi \\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/CVR3", 
        "problem": " \\( {\\frac  {z^{{2n}}}{(1+z)^{n}}},n\\in {\\mathbb  {Z^{+}}}\\, \\) \n"

        "tags": "Complex Variables,Complex,Variables,Residues", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is given by\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {z^{2}}{(z^{2}+1)^{2}}}={\\frac  {z^{2}}{(z-i)^{2}(z+i)^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>This has poles at  \\( z=\\pm i\\, \\)  of multiplicity  \\( k=2\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Use the formula  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=z_{0}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac  {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-i}}=\\lim _{{z\\to -i}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}(z+i)^{2}f(z)=\\lim _{{z\\to -i}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}{\\frac  {z^{2}}{(z-i)^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\lim _{{z\\to -i}}{\\frac  {(z-i)^{2}2z-z^{2}2(z-i)}{(z-i)^{4}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {(-2i)^{2}2(-i)-(-i)^{2}2(-2i)}{(-2i)^{4}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {8i-4i}{16}}={\\frac  {1}{4}}i\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=i}}=\\lim _{{z\\to i}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}(z-i)^{2}f(z)=\\lim _{{z\\to i}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}{\\frac  {z^{2}}{(z+i)^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\lim _{{z\\to i}}{\\frac  {(z+i)^{2}2z-z^{2}2(z+i)}{(z+i)^{4}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {(2i)^{2}2i-i^{2}2(2i)}{(2i)^{4}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {-8i+4i}{16}}={\\frac  {-1}{4}}i\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nIf  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  equals 0.\n</p><p>So  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-i}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=i}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}={\\frac  {1}{4}}i-{\\frac  {1}{4}}i+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}\\, \\) \nand  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is given by\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {\\sin 2z}{(z+1)^{3}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>This has poles at  \\( z=-1\\, \\)  of multiplicity  \\( k=3\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Use the formula  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=z_{0}^{k}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac  {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-1}}=\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac  {d^{2}}{{dz}^{2}}}(z+1)^{3}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}{\\frac  {d^{2}}{{dz}^{2}}}\\sin 2z\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\lim _{{z\\to -1}}(-4)\\sin 2z=-2\\sin(-2)=2\\sin 2\\, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  equals 0.\n</p><p>So  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-1}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=2\\sin 2+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=0\\, \\)  and  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=-2\\sin 2\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is given by\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {e^{z}}{z^{2}(z^{2}+9)}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>This has poles at  \\( z=0\\, \\)  of multiplicity  \\( k=2\\, \\)  and at  \\( z=\\pm 3i\\, \\)  of multiplicity  \\( k=1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>For the simple roots, the residue is the numerator divided by the first derivative of the denominator when both are evaluated at the root.\n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-3i}}f(z)={\\frac  {e^{z}}{4z^{3}+18z}}{\\Big |}_{{z=-3i}}={\\frac  {e^{{-3i}}}{4(27i)+18(-3i)}}={\\frac  {e^{{-3i}}}{54i}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=3i}}f(z)={\\frac  {e^{z}}{4z^{3}+18z}}{\\Big |}_{{z=3i}}={\\frac  {e^{{3i}}}{4(27(-i))+18(3i)}}={\\frac  {-e^{{3i}}}{54i}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>For 0, use the formula  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=z_{0}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac  {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=0}}=\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}z^{2}f(z)=\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}{\\frac  {e^{z}}{z^{2}+9}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {(z^{2}+9)e^{z}-e^{z}2z}{(z^{2}+9)^{2}}}={\\frac  {9}{9^{2}}}={\\frac  {1}{9}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  equals 0.\n</p><p>So  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-3i}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=3i}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=0}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}={\\frac  {e^{{-3i}}}{54i}}-{\\frac  {e^{{3i}}}{54i}}+{\\frac  {1}{9}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=0\\, \\) \n</p>",

Take a look that the multiplication of u^3 with [(1/u)^4]/4! and 12u with - [(1/u)^2]/2! will result the coeff of u^-1.\n</p><p>so that \n</p><p>Residu(f,2) = 1/4! + 12*(-1/2!) = 1/24 - 12(1/2) = 1/24 - 6 = -5 23/24\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.004 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.004 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 1/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 4/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 1/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:32925-0!*!*!*!*!*!* and timestamp 20150128034356 and revision id 38053\n -->\n",

A reputable source thinks the given function is not representable by a Laurent series and so the residue is not defined. Investigation is proceeding.</font></center>\n<p>Note that\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( {\\frac  {e^{{iz}}}{{\\sqrt  {z}}}}={\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {z}}e^{{iz}}}{z}}\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Thus\n</p>\n<center>\n<table>\n\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> Residue at  \\( z=0\\, \\)  </td>\n<td>  \\( =\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}(z-0)f(z)\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\sqrt  {z}}e^{{iz}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( ={\\sqrt  {0}}e^{{i0}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =0\\, \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n</center>\n",

        "solution": "<p>Find the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  at all its isolated singular points and at infinity (if infinity is not a limit point of singular points), where  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is given by\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {e^{{tz}}}{(z+2)^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>This has a pole at  \\( z=-2\\, \\)  of multiplicity  \\( k=2\\, \\) \n</p><p>Use the formula  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=z_{0}}}f(z)={\\frac  {1}{(k-1)!}}\\lim _{{z\\to z_{0}}}{\\frac  {d^{{k-1}}}{{dz}^{{k-1}}}}\\left[(z-z_{0})^{k}f(z)\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-2}}=\\lim _{{z\\to -2}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}\\left[(z+2)^{2}f(z)\\right]=\\lim _{{z\\to -2}}{\\frac  {d}{dz}}\\left[e^{{tz}}\\right]=\\lim _{{z\\to -2}}te^{{tz}}=-2e^{{-2t}}, \\) \n</p><p>If  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  is analytic except at isolated singular points, then the sum of all the residues of  \\( f(z)\\, \\)  equals 0.\n</p><p>So  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-2}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=-2e^{{-2t}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>so  \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=\\infty }}=2e^{{-2t}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

Only 0 and 1 are within the contour, so\n</p><p> \\( \\oint _{{|z|=2}}{\\frac  {1-2z}{z(z-1)(z-3)}}dz=2\\pi i({\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=0}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=1}})\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =2\\pi i\\left({\\frac  {1-2z}{3z^{2}-8z+3}}{\\Big |}_{{z=0}}+{\\frac  {1-2z}{3z^{2}-8z+3}}{\\Big |}_{{z=1}}\\right)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =2\\pi i\\left({\\frac  {1}{3}}+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\right)={\\frac  {5}{3}}\\pi i\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( \\oint _{{|z|=1}}e^{{1/z}}\\sin {\\frac  {1}{z}}dz\\, \\) \n</p><p>In taylor series,\n</p><p> \\( e^{{1/z}}=1+{\\frac  {1}{z}}+{\\frac  {1}{2!z}}+...\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\sin {\\frac  {1}{z}}={\\frac  {1}{z}}-{\\frac  {1}{3!z^{3}}}+...\\, \\) \n</p><p>There is an essential singularity at  \\( z=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>The residue at  \\( z=0 \\)  is the coefficient of  \\( 1/z \\)  in the Laurent series of the integrand, which is 1.\n</p><p>So  \\( \\oint =2\\pi i \\) .\n</p>",

        "title": "Complex Variables Practice",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Evaluate  \\( \\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {d\\theta }{a^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta +b^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta }}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Since  \\( [0,2\\pi ] \\)  is a complete period of the integrand, we may take it as  \\( [\\pi /2,5\\pi /2] \\)  and then replace  \\( \\theta  \\)  by  \\( \\theta +2\\pi  \\) . This shows that there is no loss of generality in assuming  \\( b&gt;a \\) . Use double angle formulas to see that\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{a^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta +b^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta }}={\\frac  {2}{a^{2}(1-\\cos 2\\theta )+b^{2}(1+\\cos 2\\theta )}}={\\frac  {2}{a^{2}+b^{2}+(b^{2}-a^{2})\\cos 2\\theta }}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Let  \\( 2\\theta =\\phi \\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {d\\theta }{a^{2}\\sin ^{2}\\theta +b^{2}\\cos ^{2}\\theta }}=\\int _{0}^{{4\\pi }}{\\frac  {d\\phi }{a^{2}+b^{2}+(b^{2}-a^{2})\\cos \\phi }}=2\\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {d\\phi }{a^{2}+b^{2}+(b^{2}-a^{2})\\cos \\phi }}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {4}{i}}\\int _{{|z|=1}}{\\frac  {dz}{2(a^{2}+b^{2})z+(b^{2}-a^{2})(1+z^{2})}}={\\frac  {4}{i}}\\int _{{|z|=1}}{\\frac  {dz}{(z-z_{1})(z-z_{2})(b^{2}-a^{2})}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z_{1},z_{2}={\\frac  {-(a^{2}+b^{2})\\pm {\\sqrt  {(a^{2}+b^{2})^{2}-(b^{2}-a^{2})^{2}}}}{b^{2}-a^{2}}}={\\frac  {(a\\mp b)^{2}}{a^{2}-b^{2}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {a-b}{a+b}},{\\frac  {a+b}{a-b}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>It is true that  \\( |z_{1}|&lt;1,|z_{2}|&gt;1\\, \\) . \n</p><p>The residue at  \\( z_{1}\\, \\)  is\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {4}{i(b^{2}-a^{2})(z_{1}-z_{2})}}={\\frac  {4}{i(b^{2}-a^{2}){\\frac  {-4ab}{a^{2}-b^{2}}}}}={\\frac  {1}{abi}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The solution is  \\( 2\\pi i{\\frac  {1}{abi}}={\\frac  {2\\pi }{ab}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Evaluate  \\( \\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {x^{\\alpha }}{1+2x\\cos \\phi +x^{2}}}dx,-1&lt;\\alpha &lt;1,\\alpha \\phi \\neq 0,-\\pi &lt;\\phi &lt;\\pi \\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Factor the bottom.\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {x^{\\alpha }}{(x+e^{{i\\phi }})(x+e^{{-i\\phi }})}}dx\\, \\) \n</p><p>Use a keyhole shaped contour- two concentric circles with radii  \\( \\epsilon  \\)  and  \\( \\rho  \\) . Eventually  \\( \\epsilon \\to 0 \\)  and  \\( \\rho \\to \\infty  \\) . The integral around the contour is\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{C}dz=\\int _{\\epsilon }^{\\rho }dx+\\int _{{C_{\\rho }}}dz+\\int _{\\rho }^{\\epsilon }dx+\\int _{{C_{\\epsilon }}}dz\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{C_{\\rho }}}\\to 0\\, \\)  by Jordan's Lemma.\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{C_{\\epsilon }}}=-2\\pi i(0)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>On  \\( \\int _{\\rho }^{\\epsilon }\\, \\) ,  \\( x\\cong xe^{{i\\alpha 2\\pi }}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So now,\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{\\rho }^{\\epsilon }=-e^{{i\\alpha 2\\pi }}\\int _{\\epsilon }^{\\rho }\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{C}=(1-e^{{i\\alpha 2\\pi }})\\int _{\\epsilon }^{\\rho }\\, \\) \n</p><p>And also from residue theory,\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{C}=2\\pi i\\left[{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-e^{{i\\phi }}}}+{\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-e^{{-i\\phi }}}}\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-e^{{i\\phi }}}}={\\frac  {e^{{i\\alpha (\\phi +\\pi )}}}{-2i\\sin \\phi }}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\mathrm  {Res}}_{{z=-e^{{-i\\phi }}}}={\\frac  {e^{{-i\\alpha (\\phi +\\pi )}}}{2i\\sin \\phi }}\\, \\) \n</p><p>So\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{C}=2\\pi i\\left[{\\frac  {-e^{{i\\alpha (\\phi +\\pi )}}+e^{{-i\\alpha (\\phi +\\pi )}}}{2i\\sin \\phi }}\\right]\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\lim _{{\\epsilon \\to 0,\\rho \\to \\infty }}={\\frac  {\\pi }{\\sin \\phi }}{\\frac  {-e^{{i\\alpha (\\phi +\\pi )}}+e^{{-i\\alpha (\\phi +\\pi )}}}{1-e^{{i\\alpha 2\\pi }}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{\\infty }={\\frac  {\\pi }{\\sin \\phi }}{\\frac  {\\sin {\\alpha \\phi }}{\\sin \\alpha \\pi }} \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Complex Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "Complex Variables,Complex,Variables,Residue Calculus,Residue,Calculus", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>A function  \\( \\phi (z)\\, \\)  is zero when  \\( z=0\\, \\) , and is real when  \\( x\\, \\) \nis real, and is analytic when  \\( |z|\\leq 1\\, \\) .  If  \\( f(x,y)\\, \\)  is the imaginary part of  \\( \\phi (x+iy)\\, \\)  prove that  \\( \\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {x\\sin \\theta }{1-2x\\cos \\theta +x^{2}}}f(\\cos \\theta ,\\sin \\theta )\\ d\\theta =\\pi \\phi (x) \\)  holds when  \\( -1&lt;x&lt;1\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Parametrizing with  \\( z=e^{{i\\theta }}\\, \\) , the function  \\( \\phi (z)=u(\\cos \\theta ,\\sin \\theta )+if(\\cos \\theta ,\\sin \\theta )\\, \\) .  Consider\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( \\int _{{\\Gamma }}{\\frac  {x\\left(z-{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right){\\frac  {1}{2i}}}{1-2x\\left(z+{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right){\\frac  {1}{2}}+x^{2}}}\\phi (z)\\ {\\frac  {dz}{iz}} \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>on the unit circle.  Then\n</p>\n<center>\n<table>\n\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int _{\\Gamma }{\\frac  {x\\left(z-{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)}{1-x\\left(z+{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)+x^{2}}}\\phi (z)\\ {\\frac  {dz}{-z}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int _{\\Gamma }{\\frac  {x\\left(z-{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)}{(x-z)\\left(x-{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)}}\\phi (z)\\ {\\frac  {dz}{-z}} \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int _{\\Gamma }{\\frac  {x\\left(z-{\\frac  {1}{z}}\\right)}{(z-x)(xz-1)}}\\phi (z)\\ dz \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\int _{\\Gamma }{\\frac  {x(z^{2}-1)}{z(z-x)(xz-1)}}\\phi (z)\\ dz \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n</center>\n<p>So the poles are at  \\( z=0\\, \\)  and  \\( z=x\\, \\) , since  \\( -1&lt;x&lt;1\\, \\) , and the other\nsingularity  \\( 1/x\\, \\)  is outside the unit circle.  Thus\n</p>\n<center>\n<table>\n\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\left(2\\pi i\\left[\\left({\\mathrm  {Residue\\ at\\ }}z=0\\right)+\\left({\\mathrm  {Residue\\ at\\ }}z=x\\right)\\right]\\right) \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( =\\pi i\\left[\\left(\\lim _{{z\\to 0}}{\\frac  {x(z^{2}-1)}{(z-x)(xz-1)}}\\phi (z)\\right)+\\left(\\lim _{{z\\to x}}{\\frac  {x(z^{2}-1)}{z(xz-1)}}\\phi (z)\\right)\\right] \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( =\\pi i\\left[\\left({\\frac  {x(-1)}{(-x)(-1)}}\\phi (0)\\right)+\\left({\\frac  {x(x^{2}-1)}{x(xx-1)}}\\phi (x)\\right)\\right] \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( =\\pi i\\left[0+1\\phi (x)\\right] \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( =\\pi i\\phi (x)\\, \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n</center>\n<p>Thus\n</p>\n<center>\n<table>\n\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( i\\pi \\phi (x)\\, \\)  </td>\n<td> \\( =\\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {x\\sin \\theta }{1-2x\\cos \\theta +x^{2}}}u(\\cos \\theta ,\\sin \\theta )\\ d\\theta  \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td>&#160;&#160;&#160; \\( +\\ i\\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {x\\sin \\theta }{1-2x\\cos \\theta +x^{2}}}f(\\cos \\theta ,\\sin \\theta )\\ d\\theta  \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n</center>\n<p>Therefore,\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( \\int _{0}^{{2\\pi }}{\\frac  {x\\sin \\theta }{1-2x\\cos \\theta +x^{2}}}f(\\cos \\theta ,\\sin \\theta )\\ d\\theta =\\pi \\phi (x) \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Evaluate  \\( \\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {dx}{x^{3}+1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nConsider the following four curves where  \\( R&gt;\\epsilon &gt;0 \\) :\n</p><p> \\( \\gamma _{1}:[0,R]\\to {\\mathbb  {C}} \\)  where  \\( \\gamma _{1}(t)=t \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\gamma _{2}:[0,{\\frac  {2\\pi }{3}}]\\to {\\mathbb  {C}} \\)  where  \\( \\gamma _{2}(t)=Re^{{it}} \\) \n</p><p>and\n</p><p> \\( \\gamma _{3}:[0,R]\\to {\\mathbb  {C}} \\)  where  \\( \\gamma _{3}(t)=te^{{{\\frac  {2\\pi i}{3}}}} \\) \n</p><p>We want to integrate  \\( {\\frac  {1}{z^{3}+1}} \\)  over the closed contour  \\( C=\\gamma _{1}+\\gamma _{2}-\\gamma _{3} \\) .\n</p><p>By the residue theorem we know that\n</p>\n<pre> \\( \\int _{C}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=2\\pi \\;res_{{z=e^{{{\\frac  {\\pi i}{3}}}}}}\\left({\\frac  {1}{z^{3}+1}}\\right) \\) \n</pre>\n<p>A very useful lemma is if  \\( f\\,g \\)  are holomorphic functions defined on an open set that contains the point  \\( z_{0} \\) , and\n \\( z_{0} \\)  is a simple zero of  \\( g \\)  then \n \\( res_{{z=z_{0}}}{\\frac  {f}{g}}={\\frac  {f(z_{0})}{g^{\\prime }(z_{0})}} \\) .\n</p><p>So we have\n \\( \\int _{C}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=2\\pi i{\\frac  {1}{3{\\left(e^{{{\\frac  {\\pi i}{3}}}}\\right)}^{2}+0}}={\\frac  {2\\pi i}{3}}e^{{-{\\frac  {2\\pi i}{3}}}} \\) \n</p><p>Now we integrate over each part of the contour, and then take the limit as  \\( R \\)  goes to infinity.\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{\\gamma _{1}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=\\int _{0}^{R}{\\frac  {dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) \n</p><p>The  \\( p \\) -test from single variable calculus tells us that this integral converges as  \\( R \\)  goes to infinity. Therefore we simply have\n</p><p> \\( \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\int _{{\\gamma _{1}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=\\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) .\n</p><p>Next we see that\n</p><p> \\( \\left|\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\\right|=\\left|\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac  {2\\pi }{3}}}}{\\frac  {Rie^{{it}}dt}{{\\left(Re^{{it}}\\right)}^{3}+1}}\\right|\\leq \\int _{0}^{{{\\frac  {2\\pi }{3}}}}\\left|{\\frac  {Rie^{{it}}}{R^{3}e^{{3it}}+1}}\\right|dt \\) \n</p><p>For all  \\( R \\)  large enough we have  \\( R^{3}-1&gt;{\\frac  {1}{2}}R^{3} \\) . Then for a  \\( R \\)  large enough\nit's easy to see  \\( |R^{3}e^{{3it}}+1|=|R^{3}+e^{{-3it}}|\\geq |R^{3}-1|&gt;{\\frac  {1}{2}}R^{3} \\) . Then getting back to out integral we have\n</p><p> \\( \\left|\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\\right|\\leq \\int _{0}^{{{\\frac  {2\\pi }{3}}}}{\\frac  {|Ri||e^{{it}}|dt}{|R^{3}e^{{3it}}+1|}}&lt;\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac  {2\\pi }{3}}}}{\\frac  {Rdt}{{\\frac  {1}{2}}R^{3}}}={\\frac  {2}{R^{2}}}\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac  {2\\pi }{3}}}}dt={\\frac  {4\\pi }{3R^{2}}} \\) \n</p><p>Taking the limit as both as  \\( R \\)  tend to infinity\n</p><p> \\( \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\left|\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}\\right|\\leq 0\\Rightarrow \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\int _{{\\gamma _{2}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=0 \\) \n</p><p>Now we have just one more curve to integrate.\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{\\gamma _{3}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=\\int _{0}^{R}{\\frac  {e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}\\pi i}}\\ dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) \n</p><p>Again taking the limit as  \\( R \\)  goes to infinity we get \n</p><p> \\( \\lim _{{R\\to \\infty }}\\int _{{\\gamma _{3}}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}\\pi i}}\\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {dt}{t^{3}+1}} \\) .\n</p><p>i.e.  \\( \\ e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}\\pi i}}\\  \\)  times the original integral\n</p><p>Therefore \n</p><p> \\( \\int _{{C}}{\\frac  {dz}{z^{3}+1}}=(1-e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}\\pi i}})\\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {dx}{x^{3}+1}}=(1-e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}\\pi i}})I \\) \n</p><p>inserting the result of the integral on the left hand side we get\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {2\\pi i}{3}}e^{{-{\\frac  {2\\pi i}{3}}}}=(1-e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}\\pi i}})I=e^{{{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\pi i}}(e^{{-{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\pi i}}-e^{{{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\pi i}})I=e^{{{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\pi i}}\\ 2i\\ \\sin(-{\\frac  {\\pi }{3}})I \\) \n</p><p>so that\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\pi }{3}}e^{{-{\\frac  {2\\pi i}{3}}}}=e^{{{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\pi i}}\\ \\sin(-{\\frac  {\\pi }{3}})I \\) \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\pi }{3}}e^{{-\\pi i}}=-{\\frac  {{\\sqrt  {3}}}{2}}I \\) \n</p><p><br />\nEventually,\n</p><p> \\( I=\\int _{0}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {dx}{x^{3}+1}}={\\frac  {2\\pi }{3{\\sqrt  {3}}}} \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.164 seconds\nReal time usage: Then  \\( q \\)  is not divisible by any prime less than or equal to  \\( p \\) . Now either  \\( q \\)  is prime or it is divisible by primes greater than  \\( p \\)  and less than  \\( q \\) .         "title": "Number Theory Practice", 
        "tags": "Number Theory,Number,Theory,Prime Numbers,Prime,Numbers", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Prove that there are infinitely many primes of the form  \\( p=6k-1\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Suppose on the contrary that there are just a finite number of these primes, say <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>, ..., <i>p</i><sub><i>n</i></sub>. Let <i>a</i> = <i>p</i><sub>1</sub>...<i>p</i><sub><i>n</i></sub>. Obviously, <i>a</i> = (\u20131)<sup><i>n</i></sup> modulo 6. If <i>n</i> is even, let <i>b</i> = <i>a</i> + 4 and otherwise let <i>b</i> = <i>a</i> + 6. Then <i>b</i> = 5 modulo 6 = \u20131 modulo 6. Moreover, any prime number <i>q</i> dividing both <i>a</i> and <i>b</i> will also divide either 4 or 6, hence such a <i>q</i> will equal 2 or 3. In particular, none of the <i>p</i><sub><i>j</i></sub> will divide <i>b</i>. Now write <i>b</i> as a product of prime numbers. Since <i>b</i> is odd, every prime factor <i>q</i> of <i>b</i> can be written as <i>q</i> = 6<i>r</i> + 1, <i>q</i> = 6<i>r</i> + 3 or <i>q</i> = 6<i>r</i> + 5. However, the last type (which is \u20131 modulo 6) is already ruled out, since none of the <i>p</i><sub><i>j</i></sub> divides <i>b</i>. The second type only permits <i>q</i> = 3. Therefore <i>b</i>, being the product of all its prime factors, is either 1 or 3 modulo 6 (since 3<sup><i>m</i></sup> = 3 modulo 6), a contradiction which completes the proof.\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.020 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.032 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 4/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 24/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:33161-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034445 and revision id 38673\n -->\n",

Consider the sequence of  \\( n\\, \\)  numbers\n</p>\n<center>\n<p> \\( m!+2,m!+3,\\ldots ,m!+m\\, \\) \n</p>\n</center>\n<p>Then for any  \\( k\\, \\)  such that  \\( 2\\leq k\\leq m\\, \\) \n</p>\n<center>\n<table>\n\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> \\( m!+k\\, \\)  </td>\n<td> \\( =\\left(1\\cdot 2\\cdot \\ldots \\cdot (k-1)\\cdot k\\cdot (k+1)\\cdot \\ldots \\cdot m\\right)+k\\, \\) \n</td></tr>\n<tr align=\"LEFT\">\n<td> </td>\n<td> \\( =k\\left[\\left(1\\cdot 2\\cdot \\ldots \\cdot (k-1)\\cdot (k+1)\\cdot \\ldots \\cdot m\\right)+1\\right]\\, \\) \n</td></tr></table>\n</center>\n<p>Therefore,  \\( m!+k\\, \\)  is composite, and since  \\( k\\, \\)  was arbitrary, every number in the\nsequence is composite.<br />\n</p><p>As an interesting side note, now consider taking  \\( n\\to \\infty \\, \\) .\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the remainder when  \\( 37^{{100}} \\)  is divided by 29.\n</p><p><br />\n \\( 37^{{100}}\\equiv 8^{{100}}({\\mathrm  {mod}}29) \\) \n</p><p> \\( =(8^{2})^{{50}}=64^{{50}}\\equiv 6^{{50}}=(6^{2})^{{25}}=36^{{25}}({\\mathrm  {mod}}29) \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\equiv 7^{{25}}=(7^{5})^{5}\\equiv 16^{5}=2^{{20}}=(2^{5})^{4}=32^{4}\\equiv 3^{4}\\equiv 23({\\mathrm  {mod}}29) \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Prove that  \\( n^{3}-n \\)  is divisible by 6. <br /><br />\n</p><p>Evaluate  \\( n^{3}-n({\\mbox{mod}}\\ 2) \\)  for  \\( n={0,1} \\) \n</p><p> \\( 0^{3}-0\\equiv 0 \\) <br />\n \\( 1^{3}-1\\equiv 0 \\) <br />\n</p><p>Evaluate  \\( n^{3}-n({\\mbox{mod}}\\ 3) \\)  for  \\( n={0,1,2} \\) \n</p><p> \\( 0^{3}-0\\equiv 0 \\) <br />\n \\( 1^{3}-1\\equiv 0 \\) <br />\n \\( 2^{3}-2\\equiv 0 \\) <br />\n</p><p>Thus  \\( n^{3}-n\\equiv 0({\\mbox{mod}}\\ 2) \\)  and <br /> \n \\( n^{3}-n\\equiv 0({\\mbox{mod}}\\ 3) \\)  <br />\nso  \\( n^{3}-n\\equiv 0({\\mbox{mod}}\\ (2\\cdot 3)) \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p><p>Alternatively,  \\( n^{3}-n=n(n^{2}-1)=n(n-1)(n+1)=(n-1)n(n+1) \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( (n-1)n(n+1)\\equiv 0({\\mbox{mod}}\\ 2) \\)  since it is a product of more than two consecutive integers <br />\n \\( (n-1)n(n+1)\\equiv 0({\\mbox{mod}}\\ 3) \\)  since it is a product of three consecutive integers <br />\nHence as above\n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.072 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.232 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 49/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 324/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:32973-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034451 and revision id 38369\n -->\n",

        "title": "PDE Coordinate Transformations Practice",

        "solution": "<p>Change to polar (and cylindrical) coordinates:  \\( \\nabla ^{2}u(x,y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\nabla ^{2}u(x,y)=u_{{xx}}+u_{{yy}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The transformation is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x=r\\cos \\theta ,y=r\\sin \\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( r=+{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}},\\theta =\\tan ^{{-1}}{\\frac  {y}{x}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Remember the derivatives  \\( {\\frac  {d}{dx}}\\left[\\tan ^{{-1}}{\\frac  {y}{x}}\\right]={\\frac  {-y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}},{\\frac  {d}{dy}}\\left[\\tan ^{{-1}}{\\frac  {y}{x}}\\right]={\\frac  {x}{x^{2}+y^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug back into the original DE.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\nabla ^{2}u(r,\\theta )=u_{{rr}}+{\\frac  {1}{r}}u_{r}+{\\frac  {1}{r^{2}}}u_{{\\theta \\theta }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{x}=u_{r}r_{x}+u_{\\theta }\\theta _{x}={\\frac  {1}{2}}(x^{2}+y^{2})^{{-1/2}}\\,2x\\,u_{r}-{\\frac  {y}{x^{2}+y^{2}}}u_{\\theta }\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {x{\\sqrt  {x^{2}+y^{2}}}\\,u_{r}-yu_{\\theta }}{x^{2}+y^{2}}}={\\frac  {x\\,r\\,u_{r}-y\\,u_{\\theta }}{r^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {r^{2}\\cos \\theta \\,u_{r}-r\\sin \\theta \\,u_{\\theta }}{r^{2}}}=\\cos \\theta \\,u_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin _{\\theta }\\,u_{\\theta }\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let this derivative be the differential operator  \\( D_{x}\\, \\) . Then, <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( D_{x}u=(\\cos \\theta \\,D_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,D_{\\theta })u\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Therefore<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( D_{x}D_{x}u=(\\cos \\theta \\,D_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,D_{\\theta })(\\cos \\theta \\,D_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,D_{\\theta })u\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\cos \\theta \\,D_{r}(\\cos \\theta \\,u_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,u_{\\theta })-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,D_{\\theta }(\\cos \\theta \\,u_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,u_{\\theta })\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\,u_{{rr}}-\\cos \\theta \\,\\sin \\theta \\,(r^{{-1}}u_{{\\theta r}}-r^{{-2}}u_{\\theta })-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,(\\cos \\theta \\,u_{{r\\theta }}-\\sin \\theta \\,u_{r}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,u_{{\\theta \\theta }}-r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,u_{\\theta })\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( =\\cos ^{2}\\theta \\,u_{{rr}}+\\cos \\theta \\,\\sin \\theta \\,(-r^{{-1}}u_{{\\theta r}}+r^{{-2}}u_{\\theta }-r^{{-1}}u_{{r\\theta }}+r^{{-2}}u_{\\theta })+\\sin ^{2}\\theta \\,(r^{{-1}}u_{r}+r^{{-2}}u_{{\\theta \\theta }})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p> \\( u_{y}=u_{r}\\,r_{y}+u_{\\theta }\\theta _{y}={\\frac  {1}{2}}(x^{2}+y^{2})^{{-1/2}}\\,2y\\,u_{r}+{\\frac  {xu_{\\theta }}{x^{2}+y^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {y\\,r\\,u_{r}+xu_{\\theta }}{r^{2}}}={\\frac  {r^{2}\\sin \\theta u_{r}+r\\cos \\theta u_{\\theta }}{r^{2}}}=\\sin \\theta \\,u_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta u_{\\theta }\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( D_{y}u=(\\sin \\theta \\,D_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,D_{\\theta })u\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( D_{y}D_{y}u=(\\sin \\theta \\,D_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,D_{\\theta })(\\sin \\theta \\,D_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,D_{\\theta })u\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\sin \\theta D_{r}(\\sin \\theta \\,u_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,u_{\\theta })+(r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta D_{\\theta }(\\sin \\theta u_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta u_{\\theta })\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\sin ^{2}\\theta u_{{rr}}+\\cos \\theta \\,\\sin \\theta \\,(r^{{-1}}u_{{\\theta r}}-r^{{-2}}u_{\\theta })+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,(\\sin \\theta \\,u_{{r\\theta }}+\\cos \\theta u_{r}+r^{{-1}}\\cos \\theta \\,u_{{\\theta \\theta }}-r^{{-1}}\\sin \\theta \\,u_{\\theta })\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( =\\sin ^{2}\\theta \\,u_{{rr}}+\\cos \\theta \\,\\sin \\theta \\,(r^{{-1}}u_{{\\theta r}}-r^{{-2}}u_{\\theta }+r^{{-1}}u_{{r\\theta }}-r^{{-2}}u_{\\theta })+\\cos ^{2}\\theta (r^{{-1}}u_{r}+r^{{-2}}u_{{\\theta \\theta }})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Summing the two starred lines, it is concluded that<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{{xx}}+u_{{yy}}=u_{{rr}}+r^{{-1}}u_{r}+r^{{-2}}u_{{\\theta \\theta }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To make the transformation to cylindrical coordinates, add the transformation  \\( z=z\\, \\)  at the top and the term  \\( +u_{{zz}}\\, \\)  to the last equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

Then  \\( u=u(x(t),t)\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( u_{t}=u_{x}x&#39;(t)+u_{t}\\, \\)  by the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Chain_rule\" title=\"Chain rule\">chain rule</a>.\n</p><p><br />\nIf  \\( u_{t}=u_{x}x&#39;(t)+u_{t}=u_{t}+au_{x}=0\\, \\)  then  \\( u\\, \\)  is constant with respect to  \\( t\\, \\)  and we have the equation  \\( x&#39;(t)=a\\, \\)  which implies  \\( x(t)=at+x_{0}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Since  \\( u\\, \\)  is constant with respect to  \\( t\\, \\) ,  \\( u(x(t),t)=u(x(0),0)=f(x_{0})\\, \\) .\n</p><p>From above,  \\( x_{0}=x(t)-at=x-at\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nThe solution is  \\( u(x,t)=f(x-at)\\, \\) \n</p>",

This comes from the symbols  \\( x,0,h(x)\\, \\)  in the IC.\n</p><p>The characteristics are  \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=1\\, \\) ,  \\( {\\frac  {dy}{dt}}=2\\, \\) ,  \\( {\\frac  {dz}{dt}}=z^{2}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nThese differential equations give  \\( x(s,t)=t+c_{1}(s)\\, \\) ,  \\( y(s,t)=2t+c_{2}(s)\\, \\) ,  \\( -z(s,t)^{{-1}}=t-c_{3}(s)^{{-1}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>At  \\( t=0\\, \\) ,  \\( x=c_{1}(s)=s\\, \\) ,  \\( y=c_{2}(s)=0\\, \\) , and  \\( z=-c_{3}(s)^{{-1}}=h(s)\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So the solutions are  \\( x=t+s\\, \\) ,  \\( y=2t\\, \\) , and  \\( z=-1/(t-h(s)^{{-1}})\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nTherefore  \\( s=x-t\\, \\) ,  \\( t=y/2\\, \\) , and  \\( z=u(x,y)={\\frac  {h(x-y/2)}{1-{\\frac  {1}{2}}yh(x-y/2)}}\\, \\) .\n</p>",
