        "solution": "<p> \\( u_{x}+xu_{y}=u^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Characteristics\" title=\"Characteristics\" class=\"mw-redirect\">characteristics</a> are:\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=1\\, \\) ,  \\( {\\frac  {dy}{dt}}=x\\, \\) ,  \\( {\\frac  {dz}{dt}}=z^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The intial curve was not given so assume  \\( \\Gamma =(0,0,z_{0})\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nThe solution to the first DE is:\n</p><p> \\( x(s,t)=t+c_{1}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(s,0)=c_{1}(s)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x=t\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nThe second DE is:\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dy}{dt}}=x=t\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y(s,t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}+c_{2}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y(s,0)=c_{2}(s)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y={\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}={\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nThe solution to the third DE is:\n</p><p> \\( z(s,t)={\\frac  {-1}{t+c_{3}(s)}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z(s,0)={\\frac  {-1}{c_{3}(s)}}=z_{0}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( c_{3}(s)=-z_{0}^{{-1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z={\\frac  {z_{0}}{1-z_{0}x}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nWe now must find two new functions of x,y,z that are constant along gamma.\n</p><p>Let  \\( \\phi (x,y,z)=y-{\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\, \\)  and  \\( \\psi (x,y,z)=z^{{-1}}+x\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So the solution is  \\( y-{\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}=f(x+{\\frac  {1}{z}})\\, \\)  where  \\( f\\, \\)  is an arbitrary function as long as  \\( f({\\frac  {1}{z_{0}}})=0\\, \\)  because those are the values along  \\( \\Gamma \\, \\) .\n</p>",

        "title": "PDE Method of characteristics Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Method of characteristics,PDE,Method,of,characteristics", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p> \\( u_{x}+xu_{y}-u_{z}=u\\, \\) ,  \\( u(x,y,1)=x+y\\, \\) , \n</p><p>Let the initial curve be parameterized by  \\( \\Gamma (s_{1},s_{2},1)=s_{1}+s_{2}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nThe characteristics are:\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx_{1}}{dt}}=1,{\\frac  {dx_{2}}{dt}}=x,{\\frac  {dx_{3}}{dt}}=-1,{\\frac  {dz}{dt}}=z\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {dx_{1}}{dt}}=1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}(s,t)=t+c_{1}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}(s,0)=c_{1}(s)=s_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{1}=t+s_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( s_{1}=x_{1}-t\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {dx_{2}}{dt}}=x\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{2}(s,t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}+c_{1}(s)t+c_{2}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{2}(s,0)=c_{2}(s)=s_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{2}={\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}+s_{1}t+s_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( s_{2}=x_{2}-{\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}-(x_{1}-t)t\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {dx_{3}}{dt}}=-1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{3}(s,0)=c_{3}(s)=1\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x_{3}=1-t\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( t=1-x_{3}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {dz}{dt}}=z\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\ln z=t+c_{4}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z(s,t)=c_{5}(s)e^{t}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z(s,0)=c_{5}(s)=s_{1}+s_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z=(s_{1}+s_{2})e^{t}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nUse these equations to get:\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)=z=\\left[x_{1}+x_{2}+(x_{3}-1)\\left[{\\frac  {1}{2}}(x_{3}+1)+x_{1}\\right]\\right]e^{{1-x_{3}}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( xu_{x}+u_{y}=y,u(x,0)=x^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>The initial curve will be parameterized by  \\( \\Gamma (s,0,s^{2})\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Characteristics\" title=\"Characteristics\" class=\"mw-redirect\">characteristics</a> are \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=x,{\\frac  {dy}{dt}}=1,{\\frac  {dz}{dt}}=y\\, \\) \n</p><p>For  \\( x\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}=x\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x^{{-1}}dx=dt\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\ln x=t+c_{1}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(s,t)=c_{4}(s)e^{t}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( x(s,0)=c_{4}(s)=s\\, \\) \n</p><p>So  \\( x(s,t)=se^{t}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nFor  \\( y\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dy}{dt}}=1 \\) \n</p><p> \\( y(s,t)=t+c_{2}(s)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( y(s,0)=c_{2}(s)=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>So  \\( y(s,t)=t\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nFor  \\( z\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dz}{dt}}=y=t\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z(s,t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}+c_{s}(3)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z(s,0)=c_{s}(0)=s^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( z(s,t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}t^{2}+s^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nThe solution is \n</p><p> \\( z(s,t)=u(x,y)={\\frac  {1}{2}}y^{2}+(xe^{{-y}})^{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "PDE Method of characteristics Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Method of characteristics,PDE,Method,of,characteristics",

        "solution": "<p>Consider the problem  \\( u_{x}+u_{y}+u=e^{{x+2y}} \\)  with initial conditions:  \\( u(x,0)=0 \\) \n</p><p><br />\nWe may write this as  \\( (1,1)\\cdot \\nabla u=e^{{x+2y}}-u \\) , with the initial curve as  \\( \\Gamma (s_{1},0,0) \\) \n</p><p><br />\nSo...  \\( \\partial _{t}x=1 \\)  and  \\( \\partial _{t}y=1 \\)  \n</p><p><b>Note:</b> \\( \\partial _{t}\\equiv {\\frac  {\\partial }{\\partial t}} \\)  \n</p><p>This implies  \\( x=t+C_{1} \\)  and  \\( y=t+C_{2} \\) \n</p><p>Applying initial conditions:  \\( x(0)=C_{1}=s_{1} \\)  and  \\( y(0)=C_{2}=0 \\) \n</p><p>So, now  \\( x=t+s_{1} \\)  and  \\( y=t \\) \n</p><p>The characteristic curves are given by the following equation:  \\( x-y=s_{1} \\) \n</p><p>Now,\n \\( \\partial _{t}u+u=e^{{3t+s_{1}}} \\) , applying the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integrating_factor\" title=\"Integrating factor\">integrating factor</a>  \\( e^{t} \\) \n</p><p> \\( e^{t}\\partial _{t}u+e^{t}u=\\partial _{t}\\left(e^{t}u\\right)=e^{{4t+s_{1}}} \\) \n</p><p> \\( e^{t}u={\\frac  {1}{4}}e^{{4t+s_{1}}}+C \\)  \n</p><p>And now applying initial conditions...\n</p><p> \\( u(0)={\\frac  {1}{4}}e^{{s_{1}}}+C=0 \\) \n</p><p>So finally,\n</p><p> \\( u={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left(e^{{3t+s_{1}}}-e^{{s_{1}-t}}\\right) \\) \n</p><p>or  \\( u(x,y)={\\frac  {1}{4}}\\left(e^{{x+2y}}-e^{{x-2y}}\\right) \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.104 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.319 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 64/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 424/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:32794-0!*!0!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034505 and revision id 37769\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p>Show that if  \\( z=u(x,y)\\, \\)  is an <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integral_surface\" title=\"Integral surface\">integral surface</a> of  \\( V=&lt;a,b,c&gt;\\, \\)  containing a point  \\( P\\, \\) , then the surface contains the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Characteristic_curve\" title=\"Characteristic curve\" class=\"mw-redirect\">characteristic curve</a>  \\( \\chi \\, \\)  passing through  \\( P\\, \\) . (Assume the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Vector_field\" title=\"Vector field\">vector field</a>  \\( V\\, \\)  is  \\( C^{1}\\, \\) , which means that the first derivative exists everywhere).\n</p><p><br />\nIt is required to prove that  \\( \\chi \\subset u\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nLet  \\( \\chi :(f(t),g(t),h(t))\\, \\)  and  \\( P:(f(0),g(0),h(0))\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\nNow, show that  \\( u(f(t),g(t))=h(t)\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n \\( {\\frac  {d}{dt}}\\left[u(x(t),y(t))-h(t)\\right]=u_{x}x&#39;(t)+u_{y}y&#39;(t)-h&#39;(t)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( =u_{x}a+u_{y}b-c(x(t),y(t),z(t))=c(x(t),y(t),u)-c(x(t),y(t),z(t))\\, \\) \n</p><p>From the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Mean_value_theorem\" title=\"Mean value theorem\">mean value theorem</a>, at some point the last equation equals  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial c}{\\partial z}}(u-z)\\, \\) .\n</p><p>This is true iff  \\( {\\frac  {d(u-z)}{dt}}={\\frac  {\\partial c}{\\partial z}}(u-z)\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\implies (u-z)(t)=(u-z)(0)e^{{\\int _{0}^{t}{\\frac  {\\partial c}{\\partial z}}ds}}=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>since  \\( u(x(0),y(0))=z(0)\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

The shock line will determine where these regions meet and the constant solutions on either side of this line is the weak solution. \n</p><p>Find the shock condition \n</p><p> \\( \\xi &#39;(t)={\\frac  {G(u_{r})-G(u_{l})}{u_{r}-u_{l}}}={\\frac  {{\\frac  {-1}{2}}}{-1}}={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( \\xi (t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}t+c_{1}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Plug in the shock point found earlier and let  \\( x=\\xi \\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( 1={\\frac  {1}{2}}+c_{1}\\implies c_{1}={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>So now  \\( \\xi (t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}t+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The weak solution is  \\( u(x,t)={\\begin{cases}1,&amp;x\\leq \\xi (t)\\\\0,&amp;x&gt;\\xi (t)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "PDE Method of characteristics Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Method of characteristics,PDE,Method,of,characteristics", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Consider  \\( uu_{x}+u_{y}=0\\, \\)  with the IC  \\( u(x,0)=h(x)={\\begin{cases}u_{0}&gt;0,&amp;x\\leq 0\\\\u_{0}(1-x),&amp;0&lt;x&lt;1\\\\0,&amp;x\\geq 1\\end{cases}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Show that a shock develops at a finite time and describe the weak solution.\n</p><p>The chracteristic line is  \\( x=uy+x_{0}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>To see this, note that the characteristics are  \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dy}}=u\\, \\)  so  \\( x(y)=uy+c_{1},x(0)=c_{1}=x_{0}\\, \\)  and  \\( x=uy+x_{0}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>Examine the middle of the region.\n</p><p>For  \\( 0&lt;x_{0}&lt;1\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( u=u_{0}(1-x_{0})=u_{0}(1-x+uy)\\implies u={\\frac  {u_{0}(1-x)}{1-u_{0}y}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Now we know\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)={\\begin{cases}u_{0}&gt;0,&amp;x\\leq 0\\\\{\\frac  {u_{0}(1-x)}{1-u_{0}y}},&amp;0&lt;x&lt;1\\\\0,&amp;x\\geq 1\\end{cases}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>So  \\( y={\\frac  {1}{u_{0}}}\\, \\)  is the shock and the characteristics intersect at  \\( (1,{\\frac  {1}{u_{0}}})\\, \\) . Next we'd like to define  \\( G(u)={\\frac  {1}{2}}u^{2}\\, \\) (in this case) so that the pde is in the form  \\( [G(u)]_{x}+u_{y}=0\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The jump condition taken from the far left side to the far right side is:\n</p><p> \\( \\xi &#39;(y)={\\frac  {G(u_{r})-G(u_{l})}{u_{r}-u_{l}}}={\\frac  {u_{0}}{2}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( \\xi (y)={\\frac  {u_{0}}{2}}y+c_{2}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Plug in the shock  \\( (1,{\\frac  {1}{u_{0}}})\\, \\)  to get  \\( 1=\\xi (y)={\\frac  {1}{2}}+c_{2}\\implies c_{2}={\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) . \n</p><p>Finally,  \\( \\xi (y)={\\frac  {u_{0}}{2}}y+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p>The weak solution is  \\( u(x,y)={\\begin{cases}u_{0},&amp;x&lt;{\\frac  {u_{0}}{2}}y+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\\\0,&amp;x&gt;{\\frac  {u_{0}}{2}}y+{\\frac  {1}{2}}\\end{cases}}\\, \\) .\n</p><p><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Consider  \\( uu_{x}+u_{t}=0\\, \\)  with the IC  \\( u(x,0)=h(x)={\\begin{cases}0,&amp;x&lt;0\\\\u_{0}(x-1),&amp;x&gt;0\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Find the weak solution.\n</p><p>When  \\( y=0\\, \\) , if  \\( x&gt;0\\, \\)  then  \\( u=u_{0}(x-1)\\, \\)  but the characteristic line (see <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/PDEMOC14\" title=\"PDEMOC14\">PDEMOC14</a>) is  \\( x=ut+x_{0}\\, \\) . Now find the line where the shock occurs.\n</p><p>The jump condition is defined as in <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/PDEMOC14\" title=\"PDEMOC14\">PDEMOC14</a>.\n</p><p> \\( \\xi &#39;(t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}{\\frac  {u_{0}(x-1)}{u_{0}t+1}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>To integrate with respect to  \\( t\\, \\) , treat everything but  \\( u_{0}\\, \\)  as a constant and you'll see that it's a log:\n</p><p> \\( \\xi (t)={\\frac  {1}{2}}(x-1)\\ln(u_{0}t+1)\\, \\) \n</p><p>The weak solution is  \\( u={\\begin{cases}0,&amp;x&lt;\\xi (t)\\\\{\\frac  {u_{0}(x_{0}-1)}{u_{0}t+1}},&amp;x&gt;\\xi (t)\\end{cases}}\\, \\) \n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Solve  \\( u_{x}+u_{y}+u=1\\, \\)  with condition:  \\( u=\\sin(x)\\, \\)  on  \\( y=x^{2}+x\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nThe characteristic equations are \n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{1}}={\\frac  {dy}{1}}={\\frac  {du}{1-u}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>Using the first two equations,\n</p><p> \\( x=y+c_{1}\\implies c_{1}=x-y\\, \\) \n</p><p>Using the second two equations,\n</p><p> \\( y=-\\ln(1-u)+c_{2}\\implies c_{2}=y+\\ln(1-u)\\, \\) \n</p><p>So the general solution is an arbitrary function of these two constants.\n</p><p> \\( f(x-y,y+\\ln(1-u))=0\\, \\) \n</p><p>This can be equivalently written using another arbitrary function  \\( g\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( y+\\ln(1-u)=g(x-y)\\, \\) \n</p><p>The general solution is\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)=1-e^{{g(x-y)-y}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nNow using the condition that  \\( u=\\sin(x)\\, \\)  on  \\( y=x^{2}+x\\, \\) ,\n</p><p> \\( \\sin(x)=1-e^{{g(-x^{2})-x^{2}-x}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( g(-x^{2})=\\ln(1-\\sin(x))+x^{2}+x\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nBut we have an arbitrary function of  \\( x-y\\, \\)  in our solution, so set  \\( -x^{2}=x-y\\, \\) .\n</p><p> \\( x={\\sqrt  {y-x}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( g(-x^{2})=g(x-y)=\\ln(1-\\sin {\\sqrt  {y-x}})+y-x+{\\sqrt  {y-x}}\\, \\) \n</p><p>So now\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)=1-e^{{\\ln(1-\\sin {\\sqrt  {y-x}})+y-x+{\\sqrt  {y-x}}-y}}\\, \\) \n</p><p><br />\nThe final solution is\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)=1-(1-\\sin {\\sqrt  {y-x}})e^{{-x+{\\sqrt  {y-x}}}}\\, \\) \n</p>\n<!-- \nNewPP limit report\nCPU time usage: 0.092 seconds\nReal time usage: 0.438 seconds\nPreprocessor visited node count: 61/1000000\nPreprocessor generated node count: 404/1000000\nPost\u2010expand include size: 0/2097152 bytes\nTemplate argument size: 0/2097152 bytes\nHighest expansion depth: 2/40\nExpensive parser function count: 0/100\n-->\n\n<!-- Saved in parser cache with key exampleproblems-ep_:pcache:idhash:32911-0!*!*!*!*!*!*!math=0 and timestamp 20150128034514 and revision id 38018\n -->\n",

        "solution": "<p> \\( 3u_{x}+4u_{y}-2u=1,u(x,0)=e^{x}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Introduce the change of coordinates<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\xi =Ax+By\\, \\) <br />\n \\( \\eta =Cx+Dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So  \\( u\\, \\)  is now a function of  \\( (\\xi ,\\eta )\\, \\) . Recompute the derivatives with respect to these new coordinates.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial x}}={\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\xi }}{\\frac  {\\partial \\xi }{\\partial x}}+{\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\eta }}{\\frac  {\\partial \\eta }{\\partial x}}=Au_{\\xi }\\ +Cu_{\\eta }\\, \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial y}}={\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\xi }}{\\frac  {\\partial \\xi }{\\partial y}}+{\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\eta }}{\\frac  {\\partial \\eta }{\\partial y}}=Bu_{\\xi }+Du_{\\eta }\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug these derivatives into the original equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 3(Au_{\\xi }+Cu_{\\eta })+4(Bu_{\\xi }+Du_{\\eta })-2u=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{\\xi }(3A+4B)+u_{\\eta }(3C+4D)-2u=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Choose any values of  \\( A,B,C,D \\)  to make the problem easy to solve, with the caveat that  \\( AD-BC\\neq 0 \\) . For example, let  \\( C=1,D=-3/4 \\)  so that the  \\( u_{\\eta } \\)  term goes away. Then let  \\( A=1/3,B=0 \\)  so that the  \\( u_{\\xi } \\)  coefficient equals unity. Then,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{\\xi }-2u=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Integrating_factor\" title=\"Integrating factor\">integrating factor</a>  \\( e^{{\\int -2d\\xi }}=e^{{-2\\xi }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( e^{{-2\\xi }}u_{\\xi }-e^{{-2\\xi }}2u=e^{{-2\\xi }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial }{\\partial \\xi }}\\left[e^{{-2\\xi }}u\\right]=e^{{-2\\xi }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( e^{{-2\\xi }}u={\\frac  {-1}{2}}e^{{-2\\xi }}+f(\\eta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Here  \\( f(\\eta )\\, \\)  is an undetermined function of  \\( \\eta  \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(\\xi ,\\eta )={\\frac  {-1}{2}}+e^{{2\\xi }}f(\\eta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)={\\frac  {-1}{2}}+e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}x}}f(x-{\\frac  {3}{4}}y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now we determine the unique solution that corresponds to the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Inital_condition\" title=\"Inital condition\" class=\"mw-redirect\">inital condition</a>  \\( u(x,0)=e^{x}\\, \\) . Using the general solution above, set  \\( y=0 \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,0)={\\frac  {-1}{2}}+e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}x}}f(x)=e^{x}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {e^{x}+{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}x}}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>But in the general solution, we have  \\( f(x-{\\frac  {3}{4}}y) \\)  instead of  \\( f(x)\\, \\) . So making the appropriate substitutions, <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x-{\\frac  {3}{4}}y)={\\frac  {e^{{x-{\\frac  {3}{4}}y}}+{\\frac  {1}{2}}}{e^{{{\\frac  {2}{3}}(x-{\\frac  {3}{4}}y)}}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug this function into the general solution.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)={\\frac  {-1}{2}}+e^{{x-{\\frac  {1}{4}}y}}+{\\frac  {1}{2}}e^{{{\\frac  {1}{2}}y}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( z_{{xy}}=x^{2}y,\\,\\,z(x,0)=x^{2},\\,z(1,y)=\\cos(y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Write  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial ^{2}z}{\\partial x\\partial y}}=x^{2}y\\, \\)  as<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial }{\\partial x}}\\left({\\frac  {\\partial z}{\\partial y}}\\right)=x^{2}y\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate wrt the partial  \\( x \\)  to get:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\partial z}{\\partial y}}={\\frac  {1}{3}}x^{3}y+f(y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate wrt the partial  \\( y \\)  to get:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z(x,y)={\\frac  {1}{6}}x^{3}y^{2}+F(y)+g(x)\\, \\)  where  \\( {\\frac  {\\partial F}{\\partial y}}=f(y)\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Since the above formula for  \\( z(x,y) \\)  has two arbitrary and independent functions, it is the general solution to the PDE. Now match this to each IC, and solve for the most helpful term:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z(x,0)=F(0)+g(x)=x^{2},\\,\\,g(x)=x^{2}-F(0)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z(1,y)={\\frac  {1}{6}}y^{2}+F(y)+g(1)=\\cos(y),\\,\\,F(y)=\\cos(y)-{\\frac  {1}{6}}y^{2}-1+F(0)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now plug these function values into the general solution to find the unique solution for this set of IC's.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( z(x,y)={\\frac  {1}{6}}x^{3}y^{2}+\\cos(y)-{\\frac  {1}{6}}y^{2}-1+x^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p> \\( u_{{xx}}-u_{t}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>For this problem, guess that the solution is in the form  \\( e^{{ax+bt}}\\, \\) . Plug the guess into the original PDE to find that:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a^{2}-b=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( a=\\pm {\\sqrt  {b}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\nLet  \\( b=c_{1} \\) , a constant. Adding together the two cases for  \\( a \\) , the homogeneous solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=e^{{{\\sqrt  {c_{1}}}x+c_{1}t}}+e^{{-{\\sqrt  {c_{1}}}x+c_{1}t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

    }, 
    {
        "title": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables,PDE,Integration,and,Separation,of,Variables", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<table border=\"0\" cellspacing=\"20\" width=\"70%\"><tr><td align=\"right\" valign=\"top\">\n \\( u_{t}=ku_{{xx}}\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\"> \\( u(0,t)=0\\, \\) <br /> \\( u(l,t)=0\\, \\) <br /><br /> \\( u(x,0)=f(x)\\, \\) <br /></td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>First separate variables and plug back into the original equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=X(x)T(t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( XT&#39;=kX&#39;&#39;T\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Find the separated boundary conditions (worry about the initial condition later).<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(0)=X(l)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now seperate the two functions on either side of the equation. The reasoning is that if the left side is a function of  \\( t \\)  and it is equal to the right side, which is a function of  \\( x \\) , then both sides of the equation must be equal to a constant. It's good to keep higher derivatives on top of lower ones, and keep the  \\( k \\)  with  \\( T(t) \\) . When setting the next part equal to a constant,  \\( -\\lambda  \\)  works best.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {T&#39;}{kT}}={\\frac  {X&#39;&#39;}{X}}=-\\lambda \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This gives the two solutions to the ODEs:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( T(t)=c_{1}e^{{-\\lambda kt}}\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( X(x)=c_{2}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}x)+c_{3}{\\frac  {\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}x)}{{\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In the solution of  \\( X(x) \\)  the extra square root of  \\( \\lambda  \\)  was added in the denominator so that we won't have to make a special case for  \\( \\lambda =0\\, \\) , which does not give interesting solutions anyway.<br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the separated boundary conditions on the function  \\( X(x) \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(0)=c_{2}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(l)=c_{3}{\\frac  {\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}l)}{{\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}}}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Nothing interesting would come from letting  \\( c_{3}=0\\, \\) , so  \\( \\lambda _{n}={\\frac  {n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{l^{2}}},\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) .  \\( n\\neq 0\\, \\)  because  \\( \\lambda \\neq 0\\, \\) . These values of lambda are the eigenvalues. The eigenfunctions are  \\( \\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}}),\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>For each value of n, a solution is then<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{n}(x,t)=c_{1}e^{{-\\lambda _{n}kt}}c_{3}{\\frac  {\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{n}}}x)}{{\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{n}}}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Using the principle of superposition, the formal solution is the sum of all possible solutions:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }u_{n}(x,t)=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}e^{{-\\lambda _{n}kt}}\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}}),A_{n}={\\frac  {c_{1}c_{3}}{{\\frac  {n\\pi }{l}}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The initial condition gives<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,0)=f(x)=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This series is the Fourier sine series of  \\( f(x) \\) , so the coefficient is given by<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{n}={\\frac  {2}{l}}\\int _{0}^{l}f(x)\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}})\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the final answer is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}e^{{-\\left({\\frac  {n\\pi }{l}}\\right)^{2}kt}}\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}}),\\,\\,\\,A_{n}={\\frac  {2}{l}}\\int _{0}^{l}f(x)\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}})\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Or just for fun:\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)={\\frac  {2}{l}}\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[\\int _{0}^{l}f(\\xi )\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi \\xi }{l}})\\,d\\xi \\right]e^{{-\\left({\\frac  {n\\pi }{l}}\\right)^{2}kt}}\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{l}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDE5",

u_{t}=ku_{{xx}}\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\"> \\( u_{x}(0,t)=0\\, \\) <br /> \\( u_{x}(1,t)=0\\, \\) <br /><br /> \\( u(x,0)=\\phi (x)\\, \\) </td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>First separate variables and plug back into the original equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=X(x)T(t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( XT&#39;=X&#39;&#39;T\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Find the separated boundary conditions (worry about the initial condition later).<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;(0)=X&#39;(1)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>When seperating variables, it's good to keep higher derivatives on top of lower ones. When setting the next part equal to a constant,  \\( -\\lambda  \\)  works best.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {T&#39;}{T}}={\\frac  {X&#39;&#39;}{X}}=-\\lambda \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This gives the two solutions to the ODEs:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( T(t)=c_{1}e^{{-\\lambda t}}\\, \\)  and  \\( X(x)=c_{2}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}x)+c_{3}{\\frac  {\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}x)}{{\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In the solution of  \\( X(x)\\, \\)  the extra square root of  \\( \\lambda \\, \\)  was added in the denominator so that we won't have to make a special case for  \\( \\lambda =0\\, \\) , which does not give interesting solutions anyway. In this problem the sine term will disappear, but in general the extra part in the denominator is a good idea.<br /><br />\n</p><p>Use the separated boundary conditions on the function  \\( X(x)\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;(0)=c_{3}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;(1)=-c_{2}{\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }})=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Nothing interesting would come from setting  \\( c_{2}=0\\, \\) . So,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{n}}}=n\\pi ,\\,\\,\\,n=0,1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Then for each  \\( n \\) , a solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{n}(x,t)=A_{n}e^{{-\\lambda _{n}t}}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{n}}}x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the formal solution is the sum of all of these:<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( u(x,t)=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }A_{n}e^{{n\\pi t}}\\cos(n\\pi x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Now deal with the initial condition. <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,0)=\\phi (x)=\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }A_{n}\\cos(n\\pi x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The series on the RHS is the Fourier cosine series for  \\( \\phi (x) \\) . Therefore, the coefficients are:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{n}=2\\int _{0}^{1}\\phi (x)\\cos(n\\pi x)\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=0,1,2...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( u_{t}=ku_{{xx}}\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\"> \\( u_{x}(0,t)=0\\, \\) "

    {
        "title": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables,PDE,Integration,and,Separation,of,Variables", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Transform the BVP into one with homogeneous boundary conditions.<br />\n</p>\n<table border=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" width=\"70%\"><tr><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\"> \\( u_{t}=u_{{xx}}+w(x,t)\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\"> \\( u_{x}(0,t)=\\alpha (t)\\, \\) <br /> \\( u_{x}(1,t)=\\beta (t)\\, \\) <br /> \\( u(x,0)=\\phi (x)\\, \\) <br />\n<p> \\( 0&lt;x&lt;1\\, \\) <br />\n \\( t&gt;0\\, \\) <br />\n</p>\n</td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>Let  \\( v(x,t)=u(x,t)-{\\frac  {\\beta (t)}{2}}x^{2}-(x-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}})\\alpha (t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{x}=u_{x}-\\beta (t)x-\\alpha (t)+\\alpha (t)x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{{xx}}=u_{{xx}}-\\beta (t)+\\alpha (t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{t}=u_{t}-{\\frac  {\\beta &#39;(t)}{2}}x^{2}-(x-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}})\\alpha &#39;(t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now the new initial boundary value problem can be stated.<br /><br />\n</p><p>The new DE is  \\( v_{t}=v_{{xx}}+\\beta (t)-\\alpha (t)-{\\frac  {\\beta &#39;(t)}{2}}x^{2}-(x-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}})\\alpha &#39;(t)+w(x,t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The new IC is  \\( v(x,0)=u(x,0)-{\\frac  {\\beta (0)}{2}}x^{2}-(x-{\\frac  {x^{2}}{2}})\\alpha (0)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The new BCs are <br /><br />\n \\( v_{x}(0,t)=u_{x}(0,t)-\\alpha (t)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{x}(1,t)=u_{x}(1,t)-\\beta (t)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDE6.5", 
        "problem": "Transform this initial boundary value problem into one with homogeneous boundary conditions."
    }, 
    {
        "title": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables,PDE,Integration,and,Separation,of,Variables", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<table border=\"0\" cellspacing=\"20\" width=\"70%\"><tr><td valign=\"top\" align=\"right\" width=\"50%\">\n \\( u_{{tt}}=c^{2}(u_{{xx}}+u_{{yy}})\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\">\n<p> \\( u(x,0,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(x,b,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(0,y,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(a,y,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n<br />\n \\( u(x,y,0)=f(x,y)\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u_{t}(x,y,0)=g(x,y)\\, \\) <br />\n<br />\n \\( 0&lt;x&lt;a,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,0&lt;y&lt;b,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,t&gt;0\\, \\) <br />\n</p>\n</td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>First, notice that there are two derivates of  \\( u \\)  w.r.t  \\( t \\)  in the differential equation and two inital conditions. There are also two derivatives on  \\( x \\)  and  \\( y \\)  and two boundary conditions on each. Now, separate variables.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y,t)=\\psi (t)\\phi (x,y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The new boundary conditions are:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\phi (0,y)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( \\phi (a,y)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( \\phi (x,0)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( \\phi (x,b)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug back into the original DE.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\psi &#39;&#39;\\phi =c^{2}\\psi (\\phi _{{xx}}+\\phi _{{yy}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Separate variables. For simplicity, keep higher derivatives on top, keep the  \\( c^{2}\\, \\)  term with the psi function, and let the constant be  \\( -\\lambda \\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {\\psi &#39;&#39;}{c^{2}\\psi }}={\\frac  {\\phi _{{xx}}+\\phi _{{yy}}}{\\phi }}=-\\lambda \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The solution for the DE involving  \\( \\psi  \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\psi &#39;&#39;+\\lambda c^{2}\\psi =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( \\psi (t)=c_{1}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}\\,ct)+c_{2}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}\\,ct)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Don't worry about the inital conditions until later. Work is done on this function for now.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\phi _{{xx}}+\\phi _{{yy}}+\\lambda \\phi =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Separate variables. Keep higher derivatives on top.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\phi (x,y)=X(x)Y(y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;&#39;(x)Y(y)+X(x)Y&#39;&#39;(y)+\\lambda X(x)Y(y)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y(y)(X&#39;&#39;(x)+\\lambda X(x))=-X(x)Y&#39;&#39;(y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The choice of  \\( -\\mu \\, \\)  is for convenience.\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {X&#39;&#39;(x)+\\lambda X(x)}{-X(x)}}={\\frac  {Y&#39;&#39;(y)}{Y(y)}}=-\\mu \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Write the new ODEs and BCs.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y&#39;&#39;(y)+\\mu Y(y)=0,\\,\\,\\,Y(0)=0,\\,\\,\\,Y(b)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;&#39;(x)+(\\lambda -\\mu )X(x)=0,\\,\\,\\,X(0)=0,\\,\\,\\,X(a)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The solution of  \\( X \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(x)=c_{3}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda -\\mu }}\\,x)+c_{4}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda -\\mu }}\\,x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(0)=c_{3}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(a)=c_{4}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda -\\mu }}\\,a)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Letting  \\( c_{4}=0\\, \\)  would give no interesting solutions.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{m}-\\mu _{m}}}={\\frac  {m\\pi }{a}},\\,\\,\\,m=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The  \\( m=0 \\)  case would not add any information to the sum in the final answer.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(x)=c_{4}\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}}),\\,\\,\\,m=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y(y)=c_{5}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\mu }}\\,y)+c_{6}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\mu }}\\,y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y(0)=c_{5}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y(b)=c_{6}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\mu }}\\,b)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Letting  \\( c_{6}=0\\, \\)  would give no interesting solutions.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\sqrt  {\\mu _{n}}}={\\frac  {n\\pi }{b}},\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y(y)=c_{6}\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}}),\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li>The eigenvalues are  \\( \\lambda _{{m,n}}={\\frac  {m^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{b^{2}}},\\,\\,\\,m,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>The eigenfunctions  \\( \\phi (x,y)=X(x)Y(y)\\, \\)  are<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( \\phi (x,y)=\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>No coefficients are needed in the formula for the eigenfunctions. They are absorbed by the other constants  \\( A \\)  and  \\( B \\) . The solution is<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( u(x,y,t)=\\psi (t)\\phi (x,y)=\\sum _{{m,n=1}}^{\\infty }\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\left[A_{{m,n}}\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{{m,n}}}}\\,ct)+B_{{m,n}}\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{{m,n}}}}\\,ct)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>The first initial condition gives<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x,y)=u(x,y,0)=\\sum _{{m,n=1}}^{\\infty }A_{{m,n}}\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This is the sine-sine double Fourier series for f(x,y), so the coefficients are given by<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( A_{{m,n}}={\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int _{0}^{a}\\!\\!\\int _{0}^{b}f(x,y)\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\,dy\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p> \\( g(x,y)=u_{t}(x,y,0)=\\sum _{{m,n=1}}^{\\infty }B_{{m,n}}{\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{{m,n}}}}\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( B_{{m,n}}={\\frac  {4}{ab{\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{{m,n}}}}}}\\int _{0}^{a}\\!\\!\\int _{0}^{b}g(x,y)\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\,dy\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDE7", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( u_{{tt}}=c^{2}(u_{{xx}}+u_{{yy}})\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\">\n<p> \\( u(x,0,t)=0\\, \\) "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables,PDE,Integration,and,Separation,of,Variables", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<table border=\"0\" cellspacing=\"20\" width=\"70%\"><tr><td align=\"right\" valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\">\n \\( u_{{t}}=k(\\Delta u)+q(x,y,t)\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\">\n<p> \\( u(x,0,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(x,b,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(0,y,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(a,y,t)=0\\, \\) <br />\n<br />\n \\( u(x,y,0)=f(x,y)\\, \\) <br />\n<br />\n \\( 0&lt;x&lt;a,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,0&lt;y&lt;b,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,t&gt;0\\, \\) <br />\n</p>\n</td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>Seperating variables for the homogeneous version of this equation leads to the same eigenvalue problem as in <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/PDE7\" title=\"PDE7\">PDE7</a>. Those eigenvalues and eigenfunctions are:<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( \\lambda _{{m,n}}={\\frac  {m^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{b^{2}}},\\,\\,\\,m,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( \\phi (x,y)=\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Now, represent the function  \\( u(x,y,t)\\, \\)  in its eigenfunction expansion.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y,t)=\\sum _{{m,n=1}}^{\\infty }B_{{m,n}}(t)\\phi _{{m,n}}(x,y)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( B_{{m,n}}(t)={\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}u(x,y,t)\\phi _{{m,n}}(x,y)\\,dx\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( t\\rightarrow 0^{+}\\, \\)  in the formula for  \\( B_{{m,n}}(t)\\, \\)  above and use the inital condition to get<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{{m,n}}={\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}f(x,y)\\phi _{{m,n}}(x,y)\\,dx\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( D \\)  is the rectangular domain  \\( 0&lt;x&lt;a,\\,\\,\\,0&lt;y&lt;b\\, \\) , and  \\( C \\)  is its boundary.<br /><br />\n</p><p>To evaluate the coefficients, take the derivative of the last equation with respect to  \\( t\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dB_{{m,n}}}{dt}}={\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}u_{t}\\phi _{{m,n}}\\,dx\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Substitute the DE for  \\( u \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}k(\\Delta u)\\phi _{{m,n}}\\,dx\\,dy+{\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}q\\phi _{{m,n}}\\,dx\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Label the second integral  \\( Q\\, \\)  and save it for later. This is a known function of  \\( t \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Q_{{m,n}}(t)={\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}q(x,y,t)\\phi _{{m,n}}(x,y)\\,dx\\,dy\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Using Green's identities, <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}\\phi \\Delta u\\,dx\\,dy=-\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}\\nabla \\phi \\nabla u\\,dx\\,dy+\\int _{C}\\phi \\nabla u\\,ds\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =-\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}\\nabla \\phi \\nabla u\\,dx\\,dy+\\int _{C}\\phi {\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\nu }}\\,ds\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}\\phi \\Delta u\\ -u\\Delta \\phi \\,dx\\,dy=\\int _{C}\\phi {\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\nu }}-u{\\frac  {\\partial \\phi }{\\partial \\nu }}\\,ds\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>and the fact that  \\( \\Delta \\phi _{{m,n}}=-\\lambda _{{m,n}}\\phi _{{m,n}}\\, \\) , the first integral can be transformed:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}k(\\Delta u)\\phi _{{m,n}}\\,dx\\,dy\\,=\\,-\\lambda _{{m,n}}k{\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}u\\phi _{{m,n}}\\,dx\\,dy\\,\\,+\\,\\,{\\frac  {4k}{ab}}\\int _{C}\\left({\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial \\nu }}\\phi _{{m,n}}-u{\\frac  {\\partial \\phi _{{m,n}}}{\\partial \\nu }}\\right)\\,ds\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The first integral on the right is equal to  \\( -\\lambda _{{m,n}}kB_{{m,n}}(t)\\, \\) . The last integral around the curve is zero because the outward normal vector of  \\( u \\)  and  \\( \\phi  \\)  are zero because both functions are zero there by the boundary conditions. And so<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dB_{{m,n}}}{dt}}=-\\lambda _{{m,n}}kB_{{m,n}}+Q_{{m,n}}(t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So  \\( B_{{m,n}}\\, \\)  is determined and gives the coefficient in the Fourier expansion of  \\( u(x,y,t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( B_{{m,n}}(t)=A_{{m,n}}e^{{-\\lambda _{{m,n}}kt}}+\\int _{0}^{t}e^{{-\\lambda _{{m,n}}k(t-\\tau )}}Q_{{m,n}}(\\tau )\\,d\\tau \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>The problem is formally solved. But just for fun, the explicit solution is<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( u(x,y,t)=\\sum _{{m,n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}f(\\xi ,\\zeta )\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi \\xi }{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi \\zeta }{b}})\\,d\\xi \\,d\\zeta e^{{-\\left[{\\frac  {m^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{b^{2}}}\\right]kt}}+\\int _{0}^{t}\\left(e^{{-\\left[{\\frac  {m^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{a^{2}}}+{\\frac  {n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}{b^{2}}}\\right]k(t-\\tau )}}\\left[{\\frac  {4}{ab}}\\int \\!\\!\\!\\int _{D}q(\\xi ,\\zeta ,t)\\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi \\xi }{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi \\zeta }{b}})\\,d\\xi \\,d\\zeta \\right]\\right)\\,d\\tau \\sin({\\frac  {m\\pi x}{a}})\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi y}{b}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>Which can probably be simplified.<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDE8", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( u_{{t}}=k(\\Delta u)+q(x,y,t)\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\">\n<p> \\( u(x,0,t)=0\\, \\) "

        "solution": "<p>Transform this equation:  \\( u_{{t}}=\\nu u_{{xx}}+\\lambda u_{x}+\\mu u\\, \\)  into the standard heat equation:  \\( v_{t}=v_{{xx}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Assume a solution in the form  \\( u(x,t)=e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v(x,t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Find its derivatives and plug it into the orginal DE:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{t}=\\beta e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v+e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v_{t}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{x}=\\alpha e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v+e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v_{x}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{{xx}}=\\alpha ^{2}e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v+\\alpha e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v_{x}+\\alpha e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v_{x}+e^{{\\alpha x+\\beta t}}v_{{xx}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\beta v+v_{t}=\\nu (\\alpha ^{2}v+2\\alpha v_{x}+v_{{xx}})+\\lambda (\\alpha v+v_{x})+\\mu v\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Collect derivatives of  \\( v\\, \\)  and find the appropriate values of  \\( \\alpha \\, \\)  and  \\( \\beta \\, \\)  to make the equation look like the heat equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v(\\beta -\\nu \\alpha ^{2}-\\lambda \\alpha -\\mu )+v_{t}-v_{x}(2\\alpha \\nu +\\lambda )-v_{{xx}}(\\nu )=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\beta -\\nu \\alpha ^{2}-\\lambda \\alpha -\\mu =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 2\\alpha \\nu +\\lambda =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\lambda =-2\\alpha \\nu \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\alpha ={\\frac  {-\\lambda }{2\\nu }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\beta -\\nu \\left({\\frac  {-\\lambda }{2\\nu }}\\right)^{2}-\\lambda \\left({\\frac  {-\\lambda }{2\\nu }}\\right)-\\mu =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\beta -{\\frac  {-\\lambda ^{2}}{4\\nu }}+{\\frac  {2\\lambda ^{2}}{4\\nu }}-\\mu =0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\beta =\\mu -{\\frac  {\\lambda ^{2}}{4\\nu }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=e^{{{\\frac  {-\\lambda }{2\\nu }}x+\\left(\\mu -{\\frac  {\\lambda ^{2}}{4\\nu }}\\right)t}}v(x,t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Taking derivatives and plugging back in gives this equation:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{t}=\\nu v_{{xx}}\\, \\) <br /><br         "solution": "<p> \\( u_{x}+2u_{y}=0,\\,\\,\\,u(0,y)=3\\,e^{{-2y}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Make the seperation of variables  \\( u(x,y)=X(x)Y(y)\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Plug back into the DE.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;Y+2XY&#39;=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {X&#39;}{X}}={\\frac  {-2Y&#39;}{Y}}=\\lambda \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This gives two ODES:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;+\\lambda X=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X(x)=c_{1}\\,e^{{\\lambda x}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( -2Y&#39;+\\lambda Y=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( Y(y)=c_{2}\\,e^{{{\\frac  {\\lambda }{2}}y}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( A=c_{1}c_{2}\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)=A\\,e^{{\\lambda ({\\frac  {y}{2}}-x)}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Applying the boundary condition,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(0,y)=A\\,e^{{\\lambda {\\frac  {y}{2}}}}=3\\,e^{{-2y}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So  \\( A=3,\\,\\,\\,\\lambda =-4\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,y)=3\\,e^{{4(x-{\\frac  {y}{2}})}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

    {
        "title": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables,PDE,Integration,and,Separation,of,Variables", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<table border=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" width=\"70%\"><tr><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\"> \\( u_{{xx}}=a^{{-2}}u_{t}\\, \\) </td><td valign=\"top\" width=\"50%\">\n<p> \\( u(0,t)=10\\, \\) <br />\n \\( u(10,t)=30\\, \\) <br />\n<br />\n \\( u(x,0)=0\\, \\) <br />\n<br />\n \\( 0&lt;x&lt;10,\\,\\,\\,\\,\\,t&gt;0\\, \\) <br />\n</p>\n</td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>Write the solution as a sum of two functions, one independent of time.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(x,t)=s(x)+v(x,t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The new boundary conditions are:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( s(0)=10,\\,\\,\\,s(10)=30\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( v(0,t)=0,\\,\\,\\,v(10,t)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( u(x,0)=s(x)+v(x,0)=0,\\,\\,\\,v(x,0)=-s(x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Substituting the sum of functions into the DE gives a simple ODE and a PDE:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( s&#39;&#39;=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( s(x)=Ax+B\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( s(0)=B=10\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( s(10)=10A+10=30,\\,\\,\\,A=2\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( s(x)=2x+10\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>And the PDE<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{{xx}}=a^{{-2}}v_{t}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Seperate variables to get two ODEs. Set them equal to a constant that will simplify calculations later:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v(x,t)=X(x)T(t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;&#39;T=a^{{-2}}XT&#39;\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {X&#39;&#39; \\over X}=a^{{-2}}{T&#39; \\over T}=-\\lambda ^{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( X&#39;&#39;+\\lambda ^{2}X=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( X(x)=c_{1}\\cos(\\lambda x)+c_{2}\\sin(\\lambda x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( X(0)=c_{1}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( X(10)=c_{2}\\sin(\\lambda 10)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( \\lambda _{n}={n\\pi  \\over 10},\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>And<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( T&#39;+a^{2}\\lambda ^{2}T=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( T(t)=c_{3}e^{{-a^{2}\\lambda ^{2}t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( v(x,t)=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}\\sin(\\lambda _{n}x)e^{{-a^{2}\\lambda ^{2}t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p> \\( v(x,0)=\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }A_{n}\\sin({n\\pi x \\over 10})=-2x-10\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This is a Fourier sine series for the function on the right. The coefficients are then given by:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{n}={-1 \\over 5}\\int _{0}^{{10}}(2x+10)\\sin({n\\pi x \\over 10})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( ={20(3(-1)^{n}-1) \\over n\\pi }\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The solution is<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( u(x,t)=2x+10+{20 \\over \\pi }\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{3(-1)^{n}-1 \\over n}\\sin({n\\pi x \\over 10})e^{{-a^{2}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2} \\over 10^{2}}t}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDE11", 
        "problem": "Evaluate  \\( u_{{xx}}=a^{{-2}}u_{t}\\, \\) "
    }, 
    {
        "title": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Integration and Separation of Variables,PDE,Integration,and,Separation,of,Variables", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<table border=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" width=\"70%\"><tr><td colspan=\"2\" valign=\"top\">Solve Dirichlet's problem for a circular annulus. The domain  \\( D\\, \\)  is the space between two concentric circles,  \\( C_{1} \\)  being the innermost circle with radius  \\( a \\) , and  \\( C_{2} \\)  being the outermost circle with radius  \\( b \\) .</td></tr><tr><td width=\"50%\">&#160;</td><td> \\( \\Delta u=\\nabla ^{2}u=0\\, \\)  in  \\( D\\, \\) <br /><br /> \\( u=g\\, \\)  on  \\( C_{1}\\, \\) <br /> \\( u=f\\, \\)  on  \\( C_{2}\\, \\) </td></tr></table><br /><br />\n<p>First transform the Laplacian operator to polar coordinates, as explained in <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/PDECS1\" title=\"PDECS1\">this problem</a>.<br /><br />\n</p><p>Now the DE is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{r}}(ru_{r})_{r}+{\\frac  {1}{r^{2}}}u_{{\\theta \\theta }}=0,\\,\\,\\,a&lt;r&lt;b\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The BC's are<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(a,\\theta )=g(\\theta ),\\,\\,\\,\\theta \\in \\Re \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(b,\\theta )=f(\\theta ),\\,\\,\\,\\theta \\in \\Re \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>An auxiliary condition required from the nature of the problem and coordinate system is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(r,\\theta +2\\pi )=u(r,\\theta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Separate variables and plug back into the original equation, separate variables and set each side equal to a negative (for convenience) constant lambda.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(r,\\theta )=R(r)H(\\theta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {1}{r}}(rR&#39;(r))_{r}\\,H(\\theta )+{\\frac  {R(r)}{r^{2}}}H&#39;&#39;(\\theta )=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {r}{R(r)}}(rR&#39;(r))_{r}+{\\frac  {H&#39;&#39;(\\theta )}{H(\\theta )}}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {H&#39;&#39;(\\theta )}{H(\\theta )}}={\\frac  {-r}{R(r)}}(rR&#39;(r))_{r}=-\\lambda \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The first ODE is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( H&#39;&#39;+\\lambda H=0\\, \\)  with the auxiliary condition  \\( H(\\theta +2\\pi )=H(\\theta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( H(\\theta )=A\\cos({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}\\theta )+B\\sin({\\sqrt  {\\lambda }}\\theta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>In order for  \\( H(\\theta )=H(\\theta +2\\pi )\\, \\) , the square root of lambda must be an integer value.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{n}}}=n,\\,\\,\\,n=0,1,2,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The second ODE is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {-r}{R(r)}}(rR&#39;(r))_{r}=-\\lambda _{n}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>If  \\( n=0\\, \\)  so that  \\( \\lambda _{n}=0\\, \\) , the solution is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( r(rR&#39;(r))&#39;=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( rR&#39;(r)=c_{1}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( R&#39;(r)={\\frac  {c_{1}}{r}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( R(r)-R(0)=c_{1}\\log r+c_{2}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( R(r)=c_{1}\\log r+c_{3},\\,\\,\\,c_{3}=c_{2}+R(0)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>If  \\( \\lambda &gt;0\\, \\) , the solution is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {r}{R(r)}}(R&#39;(r)+rR&#39;&#39;(r))=\\lambda _{n}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( rR&#39;(r)+r^{2}R&#39;&#39;(r)-\\lambda _{n}R(r)=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This ODE is in Cauchy-Euler form, so guess the solution  \\( R(r)=r^{a}\\, \\)  and plug it back in.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( rar^{{a-1}}+r^{2}a(a-1)r^{{a-2}}-\\lambda _{n}r^{a}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a+a^{2}-a=\\lambda _{n}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a=\\pm {\\sqrt  {\\lambda _{n}}},\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( R(r)={\\begin{cases}c_{1}\\log r+c_{3}&amp;n=0\\\\c_{{4,n}}r^{n}+c_{{5,n}}r^{{-n}}&amp;n=1,2,...\\,\\end{cases}} \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p>The solution is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(r,\\theta )={\\frac  {1}{2}}(A_{0}+B_{0}\\log r)+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[(A_{n}r^{n}+B_{n}r^{{-n}})\\cos n\\theta +(C_{n}r^{n}+D_{n}r^{{-n}})\\sin n\\theta \\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The Fourier coefficients are given with the help of the boundary conditions.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(a,\\theta )={\\frac  {1}{2}}(A_{0}+B_{0}\\log a)+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[(A_{n}a^{n}+B_{n}a^{{-n}})\\cos n\\theta +(C_{n}a^{n}+D_{n}a^{{-n}})\\sin n\\theta \\right]=g(\\theta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u(b,\\theta )={\\frac  {1}{2}}(A_{0}+B_{0}\\log b)+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[(A_{n}b^{n}+B_{n}b^{{-n}})\\cos n\\theta +(C_{n}b^{n}+D_{n}b^{{-n}})\\sin n\\theta \\right]=f(\\theta )\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Now you have this system of equations to solve to determine the coefficients:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{0}+B_{0}\\log a={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }g(\\theta )\\,d\\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{0}+B_{0}\\log b={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }f(\\theta )\\,d\\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{n}a^{n}+B_{n}a^{{-n}}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }g(\\theta )\\cos n\\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( A_{n}b^{n}+B_{n}b^{{-n}}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }f(\\theta )\\cos n\\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( C_{n}a^{n}+D_{n}a^{{-n}}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }g(\\theta )\\sin n\\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( C_{n}b^{n}+D_{n}b^{{-n}}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }f(\\theta )\\sin n\\theta \\,d\\theta \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDE12",

        "solution": "<p>Find the <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_series\" title=\"Fourier series\">Fourier series</a> for  \\( |x|\\, \\) ,  \\( -\\pi &lt;x&lt;\\pi \\, \\) .\n</p><p>Following the rules from the link above, <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }(a_{n}\\cos(nx)+b_{n}\\sin(nx))\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }|x|\\,dx={\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{\\pi }x\\,dx=\\pi \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }|x|\\cos(nx)\\,dx={\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{\\pi }x\\cos(nx)\\,dx\\, \\) \n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\left(\\left[{\\frac  {x\\sin(nx)}{n}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }-\\int _{0}^{\\pi }{\\frac  {\\sin(nx)}{n}}\\,dx\\right)={\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\left[{\\frac  {\\cos(nx)}{n^{2}}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }\\, \\) \n<br /><br />\n<br />\n \\( ={\\frac  {2(-1)^{n}}{\\pi n^{2}}}-{\\frac  {2}{\\pi n^{2}}}={\\frac  {2((-1)^{n}-1)}{\\pi n^{2}}}\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }|x|\\sin(nx)\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{{0}}-x\\sin(nx)\\,dx+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{0}}^{{\\pi }}x\\sin(nx)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left[\\left[{\\frac  {x\\cos(nx)}{n}}\\right]_{{-\\pi }}^{0}-\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{0}{\\frac  {\\cos(nx)}{n}}\\,dx\\right]+{\\frac  {1}{n}}\\left[\\left[{\\frac  {-x\\cos(nx)}{n}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }+\\int _{0}^{\\pi }{\\frac  {\\cos(nx)}{n}}\\,dx\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left[{\\frac  {\\pi (-1)^{n}}{n}}-\\left[{\\frac  {\\sin(nx)}{n^{2}}}\\right]_{{-\\pi }}^{0}\\right]+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left[{\\frac  {-\\pi (-1)^{n}}{n}}+\\left[{\\frac  {\\sin(nx)}{n^{2}}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}{\\frac  {\\pi (-1)^{n}}{n}}+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}{\\frac  {-\\pi (-1)^{n}}{n}}=0\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>So,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( |x|={\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}+{\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}-1}{n^{2}}}\\cos(nx)={\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}+{\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {-2}{(2n+1)^{2}}}\\cos \\left((2n+1)x\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}-{\\frac  {4}{\\pi }}\\left(\\cos x+{\\frac  {1}{9}}\\cos(3x)+{\\frac  {1}{25}}\\cos(5x)+...\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the <a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_series\">Fourier series</a> for  \\( f(x)={\\begin{cases}0&amp;-\\pi &lt;x&lt;0,\\\\1&amp;0&lt;x&lt;\\pi \\end{cases}} \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }(a_{n}\\cos(nx)+b_{n}\\sin(nx))\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{0}0dx+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{\\pi }1dx=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{0}0dx+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{\\pi }\\cos(nx)dx={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left[{\\frac  {\\sin(nx)}{n}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n<br /><br />\n</p>\n<center><a rel=\"nofollow\" class=\"external text\" href=\"http://www.amazon.com/gp/search?ie=UTF8&amp;keywords=Fourier%20Series&amp;tag=wwwtoddbsmitc-20&amp;index=books&amp;linkCode=ur2&amp;camp=1789&amp;creative=9325\">FOURIER SERIES BOOKS</a></center>\n<p><br />\n \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{0}0dx+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{\\pi }\\sin(nx)dx=\\left[{\\frac  {-\\cos(nx)}{\\pi n}}\\right]_{0}^{\\pi }={\\frac  {-(-1)^{n}}{\\pi n}}+{\\frac  {1}{\\pi n}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {1}{2}}+\\sum _{{n=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {2}{\\pi (2n+1)}}\\sin((2n+1)x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{2}}+{\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\left(\\sin(x)+{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\sin(3x)+{\\frac  {1}{5}}\\sin(5x)+...\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Fourier Series Practice", 
        "tags": "Fourier Series,Fourier,Series", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for  \\( f(x)=1+x\\, \\)  on  \\( [-\\pi ,\\pi ]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The general Fourier series on  \\( [-L,L]\\, \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{k=1}}^{\\infty }a_{k}\\,\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{L}})+b_{k}\\,\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{L}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {1}{L}}\\int _{{-L}}^{L}f(x)\\cos({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{L}})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=0,1,2,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {1}{L}}\\int _{{-L}}^{L}f(x)\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{L}})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The  \\( n=0 \\)  case is not needed since the integrand in the formula for  \\( b_{0}\\, \\)  is  \\( \\sin(0)\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>In the present problem,  \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }(1+x)\\cos({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{\\pi }})\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left(\\left[{\\frac  {(1+x)\\sin(nx)}{n}}\\right]_{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }-\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }{\\frac  {(1+x)\\cos(nx)}{n^{2}}}\\,dx\\right)=0\\, \\)  <br /><br />\n</p><p>But since the right hand side is not defined if  \\( n=0 \\) , the  \\( 0 \\)  index for  \\( a \\)  will have to be calculated seperately.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }(1+x)\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left[x+{\\frac  {1}{2}}x^{2}\\right]_{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }=2,\\,\\,\\,\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }(1+x)\\sin(nx)\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left(-\\,{\\frac  {1}{n}}\\left[(1+x)\\cos(nx)\\right]_{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }+\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }{\\frac  {\\cos(nx)}{n}}\\,dx\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\left(-\\,{\\frac  {1}{n}}(1+\\pi -1+\\pi )\\cos(nx)+\\left[{\\frac  {\\sin(nx)}{n^{2}}}\\right]_{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }\\right)={\\frac  {2(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the Fourier series is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)=1+x\\sim 1+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {2(-1)^{{n+1}}}{n}}\\sin(nx)\\, \\)  for  \\( [-\\pi ,\\pi ]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/FS3",

        "title": "Fourier Series Practice",

        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for  \\( f(x)={\\begin{cases}1&amp;-1\\leq x&lt;0\\\\{\\frac  {1}{2}}&amp;x=0\\\\x&amp;0&lt;x\\leq 1\\end{cases}} \\)  on  \\( [-1,1]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The general Fourier series on  \\( [-L,L]\\, \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{k=1}}^{\\infty }a_{k}\\,\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{L}})+b_{k}\\,\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{L}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {1}{L}}\\int _{{-L}}^{L}f(x)\\cos({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{L}})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=0,1,2,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {1}{L}}\\int _{{-L}}^{L}f(x)\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{L}})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In the present problem,<br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( a_{n}=\\int _{{-1}}^{1}f(x)\\cos(n\\pi x)\\,dx=\\int _{{-1}}^{0}f(x)\\cos(n\\pi x)\\,dx+\\int _{0}^{1}f(x)\\cos(n\\pi x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p> \\( =\\int _{{-1}}^{0}\\cos(n\\pi x)\\,dx+\\int _{0}^{1}x\\cos(n\\pi x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\left[{\\frac  {\\sin(n\\pi x)}{n\\pi }}\\right]_{{-1}}^{0}+\\left[{\\frac  {x\\sin(n\\pi x)}{n\\pi }}+{\\frac  {\\cos(n\\pi x)}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\right]_{0}^{1}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {\\cos(n\\pi )-1}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}={\\frac  {(-1)^{n}-1}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( a_{0}=\\int _{{-1}}^{1}f(x)\\,dx=\\int _{{-1}}^{0}f(x)\\,dx+\\int _{0}^{1}f(x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p> \\( =\\int _{{-1}}^{0}\\,dx+\\int _{0}^{1}x\\,dx={\\frac  {3}{2}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p>\n<ul>\n<li> \\( b_{n}=\\int _{{-1}}^{1}f(x)\\sin(n\\pi x)\\,dx=\\int _{{-1}}^{0}f(x)\\sin(n\\pi x)\\,dx+\\int _{0}^{1}f(x)\\sin(n\\pi x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</li>\n</ul>\n<p> \\( =\\int _{{-1}}^{0}\\sin(n\\pi x)\\,dx+\\int _{0}^{1}x\\,\\sin(n\\pi x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =\\left[-\\,{\\frac  {\\cos(n\\pi x)}{n\\pi }}\\right]_{{-1}}^{0}+\\left[-\\,{\\frac  {x\\,\\cos(n\\pi x)}{n\\pi }}+{\\frac  {\\sin(n\\pi x)}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\right]_{0}^{1}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =-\\,{\\frac  {1}{n\\pi }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the Fourier series is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {3}{4}}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {(-1)^{n}-1}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\cos(n\\pi x)-{\\frac  {1}{n\\pi }}\\sin(n\\pi x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Setting  \\( x=0 \\)  gives  \\( {\\frac  {\\pi ^{2}}{8}}=1+{\\frac  {1}{3^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1}{5^{2}}}+{\\frac  {1}{7^{2}}}+...\\, \\) <br /><br         "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for  \\( f(x)={\\begin{cases}-1&amp;-3\\leq x&lt;0\\\\1&amp;0&lt;x\\leq 3\\end{cases}} \\)  on  \\( [-3,3]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{k}={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{{-3}}^{3}f(x)\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{{-3}}^{0}-\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\,dx+{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{0}^{3}\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{k\\pi }}\\left[\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\right]_{{-3}}^{0}-{\\frac  {1}{k\\pi }}\\left[\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\right]_{0}^{3}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{{-3}}^{0}-\\,dx+{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{0}^{3}\\,dx=-1+1=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{k}={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{{-3}}^{3}f(x)\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{{-3}}^{0}-\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\,dx+{\\frac  {1}{3}}\\int _{0}^{3}\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{k\\pi }}\\left[\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\right]_{{-3}}^{0}-{\\frac  {1}{k\\pi }}\\left[\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{3}})\\right]_{0}^{3}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {1}{k\\pi }}-{\\frac  {(-1)^{k}}{k\\pi }}-{\\frac  {(-1)^{k}}{k\\pi }}+{\\frac  {1}{k\\pi }}={\\frac  {2-2(-1)^{k}}{k\\pi }}\\,\\,\\,k=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {4}{(2k+1)\\pi }},\\,\\,\\,k=0,1,2,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the Fourier series is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)=\\sum _{{k=0}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {4}{(2k+1)\\pi }}\\sin \\left({\\frac  {(2k+1)\\pi x}{3}}\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for  \\( f(x)=x^{2}\\, \\)  on  \\( [-\\pi ,\\pi ]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The general Fourier series on  \\( [-L,L]\\, \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{k=1}}^{\\infty }a_{k}\\,\\cos({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{L}})+b_{k}\\,\\sin({\\frac  {k\\pi x}{L}})\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {1}{L}}\\int _{{-L}}^{L}f(x)\\cos({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{L}})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=0,1,2,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {1}{L}}\\int _{{-L}}^{L}f(x)\\sin({\\frac  {n\\pi x}{L}})\\,dx,\\,\\,\\,n=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In the present problem,  \\( L=\\pi \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{k}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }x^{2}\\cos(kx)\\,dx={\\frac  {4(-1)^{k}}{k^{2}}}\\,\\,\\,k=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }x^{2}\\,dx={\\frac  {1}{3\\pi }}[x^{3}]_{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }={\\frac  {2\\pi ^{2}}{3}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{k}={\\frac  {1}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi }}^{\\pi }x^{2}\\sin(kx)\\,dx=0\\,\\,\\,k=1,2,3,...\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the Fourier series is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x^{2}={\\frac  {\\pi ^{2}}{3}}+\\sum _{{k=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {4(-1)^{k}}{k^{2}}}\\cos(kx)\\, \\)  on  \\( [-\\pi ,\\pi ]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "title": "Fourier Series Practice", 
        "tags": "Fourier Series,Fourier,Series",

        "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for a function  \\( f(x)=f(x+2),f(x)=(x-1)(x-3)\\, \\)  on  \\( [1,3]\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Make the change of variables  \\( z=x-2\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Now, look for the Fourier series of the function  \\( f(z+2)=f(z+4),f(z+2)=(z+1)(z-1)\\, \\)  on  \\( -1\\leq z\\leq 1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(z)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{k=1}}^{\\infty }a_{k}\\cos(k\\pi x)+b_{k}\\sin(k\\pi x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{k}=\\int _{{-1}}^{1}(z+1)(z-1)\\cos(k\\pi (z+2))\\,dz={\\frac  {4(-1)^{k}}{k^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}=\\int _{{-1}}^{1}(z+1)(z-1)dz={\\frac  {-4}{3}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{k}=\\int _{{-1}}^{1}(z+1)(z-1)\\sin(k\\pi (z+2))\\,dz=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Since  \\( f(z)=f(x-2)=f(x)\\, \\) ,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {-2}{3}}+\\sum _{{k=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {4(-1)^{k}}{k^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\cos(k\\pi x)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for  \\( f(x)=x\\, \\)  on  \\( [0,1]\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>A general formula for the Fourier series of a function on an interval  \\( [c,c+T]\\, \\)  is:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }a_{n}\\cos \\left({\\frac  {2n\\pi x}{T}}\\right)+b_{n}\\sin \\left({\\frac  {2n\\pi x}{T}}\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {2}{T}}\\int _{c}^{{c+T}}f(x)\\cos \\left({\\frac  {2n\\pi x}{T}}\\right)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {2}{T}}\\int _{c}^{{c+T}}f(x)\\sin \\left({\\frac  {2n\\pi x}{T}}\\right)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>In the current problem,  \\( c=0\\, \\)  and  \\( T=1\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {a_{0}}{2}}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }a_{n}\\cos 2n\\pi x+b_{n}\\sin 2n\\pi x\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The function  \\( f(x)=x\\, \\)  is odd, so the cosine coefficients will all equal zero. Nevertheless,  \\( a_{0}\\, \\)  should still be calculated separately.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}=2\\int _{0}^{1}x\\,dx=1\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}=2\\int _{0}^{1}x\\sin(2n\\pi x)\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =2\\left(\\left[{\\frac  {-x\\cos 2n\\pi x}{2n\\pi }}\\right]_{0}^{1}+\\int _{0}^{1}{\\frac  {\\cos 2n\\pi x}{2n\\pi }}\\,dx\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( ={\\frac  {-1}{n\\pi }}+\\left[{\\frac  {\\sin 2n\\pi x}{(2n\\pi )^{2}}}\\right]_{0}^{1}={\\frac  {-1}{n\\pi }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the Fourier series for  \\( f(x)\\, \\)  is<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={\\frac  {1}{2}}-\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }{\\frac  {\\sin 2n\\pi x}{n\\pi }}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Fourier_Series\" title=\"Fourier Series\">Fourier Series</a><br /><br />\n</p>",

        "solution": "<p>Find the Fourier series for  \\( f(t)={\\begin{cases}{\\frac  {4}{\\pi }}t&amp;0\\leq t&lt;{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}},\\\\{\\frac  {-4}{\\pi }}t&amp;{\\frac  {-\\pi }{2}}\\leq t\\leq 0\\end{cases}} \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This is the general Fourier Series:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( f(x)={a_{0} \\over 2}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[a_{n}\\cos({2n\\pi x \\over T})+b_{n}\\sin({2n\\pi x \\over T})\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( a_{n}={2 \\over T}\\int _{c}^{{c+T}}f(x)\\cos({2n\\pi x \\over T})\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n \\( b_{n}={2 \\over T}\\int _{c}^{{c+T}}f(x)\\sin({2n\\pi x \\over T})\\,dx\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the given function can be replaced by its Fourier expansion:\n</p><p> \\( f(t)={a_{0} \\over 2}+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[a_{n}\\cos \\left({\\frac  {2n\\pi x}{\\pi }}\\right)+b_{n}\\sin \\left({\\frac  {2n\\pi x}{\\pi }}\\right)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{0}={2 \\over \\pi }\\int _{{{\\frac  {-\\pi }{2}}}}^{0}{\\frac  {-4}{\\pi }}t\\,dt+{2 \\over \\pi }\\int _{0}^{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}{\\frac  {4}{\\pi }}t\\,dt=2\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( a_{n}={\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\int _{{-\\pi  \\over 2}}^{0}{\\frac  {-4}{\\pi }}t\\cos(2nt)\\,dt+{\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}{\\frac  {4}{\\pi }}t\\cos(2nt)\\,dt={\\frac  {4((-1)^{n}-1)}{\\pi ^{2}n^{2}}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( b_{n}={\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\int _{{{\\frac  {-\\pi }{2}}}}^{0}{\\frac  {-4}{\\pi }}t\\sin(2nt)\\,dt+{\\frac  {2}{\\pi }}\\int _{0}^{{{\\frac  {\\pi }{2}}}}{\\frac  {4}{\\pi }}t\\sin(2nt)\\,dt=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the solution is\n</p><p> \\( f(t)=1+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[{\\frac  {4}{n^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}((-1)^{n}-1)\\cos(2nt)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =1+\\sum _{{n=1}}^{\\infty }\\left[{\\frac  {-4\\cdot 2}{(2n-1)^{2}\\pi ^{2}}}\\cos(2(2n-1)t)\\right]\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( =1-{\\frac  {8}{\\pi ^{2}}}\\sum     {
        "title": "PDE Mathematical Modeling Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Mathematical Modeling,PDE,Mathematical,Modeling,Mathematical Modeling,Mathematical,Modeling", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>Let the temperature  \\( u\\, \\)  inside a solid sphere be a function only of radial distance  \\( r\\, \\)  from the center and time  \\( t\\, \\) . Show that the equation for heat diffusion is now  \\( u_{t}=\\nu (u_{{rr}}+{\\frac  {2}{r}}u_{r})\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>solution:<br /><br />\n</p><p>Since the heat phenomenon is isotropic with respect to the center of the sphere, we can measure the temperature and examine the flux in a certain region from  \\( r=a\\, \\)  to  \\( r=b\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>The surface area of a sphere is  \\( 4\\pi r^{2}\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}u(r,t)4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The temperature flux in this region is the derivative with respect to time of the last integral and is also given by this right hand side for some function describing flux  \\( \\phi \\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dt}}\\int _{a}^{b}u(r,t)4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr=4\\pi a^{2}\\phi (a,t)-4\\pi b^{2}\\phi (b,t)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The time derivative can come into the integral since it is independent of the integration variable and the limits of the integral.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d}{dt}}\\int _{a}^{b}u(r,t)4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr=\\int _{a}^{b}{\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial t}}4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>These equations should be rewritten:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}{\\frac  {\\partial u}{\\partial t}}4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr=4\\pi (a^{2}\\phi (a,t)-b^{2}\\phi (b,t))\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Working backwords towards an integral, the right hand side of the last equation is equivalent to this new right hand side.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}u_{t}4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr=-4\\pi r^{2}\\phi (r,t){\\bigg |}_{a}^{b}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This is the value of a particular integral and so this equation is valid:<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{a}^{b}u_{t}4\\pi r^{2}\\,dr+4\\pi \\int _{a}^{b}(r^{2}\\phi _{r}+2\\phi r)\\,dr=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 4\\pi \\int _{a}^{b}u_{t}r^{2}+r^{2}\\phi _{r}+2\\phi r\\,dr=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Change of variables:  \\( \\phi =-\\nu u_{r}\\implies \\phi _{r}=-\\nu u_{{rr}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( 4\\pi \\int _{a}^{b}u_{t}r^{2}-r^{2}\\nu u_{{rr}}-2\\nu ru_{{r}}\\,dr=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>This implies<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{t}r^{2}-r^{2}\\nu u_{{rr}}-2\\nu ru_{r}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{t}-\\nu u_{{rr}}-{\\frac  {2\\nu }{r}}u_{r}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( u_{t}=\\nu \\left(u_{{rr}}+{\\frac  {2}{r}}u_{r}\\right)\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Partial_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Partial Differential Equations\">Partial Differential Equations</a><br /><br />\n</p>", 
        "solutionLink": "http://www.exampleproblems.com/wiki/index.php/PDEMM1",

    {
        "title": "PDE Mathematical Modeling Practice", 
        "tags": "PDE Mathematical Modeling,PDE,Mathematical,Modeling,Mathematical Modeling,Mathematical,Modeling", 
        "site": "www.exampleproblems.com", 
        "solution": "<p>A ball is thrown straight up from the ground. How high will it go?<br /><br />\n</p><p>The height of the ball at time  \\( t\\, \\)  is  \\( x(t)\\, \\) , and the force acting on the ball is  \\( -mg\\, \\) .<br /><br />\n</p><p>Newton's second law gives the relation<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( m{\\frac  {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+mg=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( m=1\\, \\)  for convenience.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {d^{2}x}{dt^{2}}}+g=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate the last equation.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx(t)}{dt}}+gt+C=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To get  \\( C\\, \\) , start with an initial velocity  \\( v_{0}\\, \\)  and set  \\( t=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( v_{0}+C=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So now,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( {\\frac  {dx}{dt}}+gt-v_{0}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Integrate again.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x(t)+{\\frac  {1}{2}}gt^{2}-v_{0}t+D=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Since we have set  \\( x(0)=0\\, \\) ,  \\( D=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>The equation of position is <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x(t)=-{\\frac  {1}{2}}gt^{2}+v_{0}t\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>To find the maximum, set the first derivative equal to 0.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( -gt+v_{0}=0\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( t_{{max}}={\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Check that the second derivative at this point is negative.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x&#39;&#39;\\left({\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)=-g\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>So the answer is this point  \\( t_{{max}}\\, \\)  evaluated in the position function.<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( x_{{max}}=x\\left({\\frac  {v_{0}}{g}}\\right)={\\frac  {v_{0}^{2}}{2g}}\\, \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p><br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Ordinary_Differential_Equations\" title=\"Ordinary Differential         "solution": "<p> \\( \\int _{0}^{1}{\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {-\\ln x}}}}\\,dx \\) <br /><br />\n</p><p>Let  \\( -\\ln x=t\\, \\) ; then  \\( x=e^{{-t}},dx=-e^{{-t}}\\,dt \\) <br /><br />\nLimits: as  \\( x\\to 0^{+},t=-\\ln x\\to \\infty  \\) ;  \\( x=1\\implies t=\\,-\\ln 1=0 \\) <br /><br />\nThus,<br /><br />\n</p><p> \\( \\int _{0}^{1}{\\frac  {1}{{\\sqrt  {-\\ln x}}}}\\,dx=-\\int _{\\infty }^{0}{\\frac  {e^{{-t}}}{{\\sqrt  {t}}}}\\,dt=\\int _{0}^{\\infty }e^{{-t}}\\,t^{{-1/2}}\\,dt=\\Gamma (1/2)={\\sqrt  {\\pi }} \\) <br /> (see <a href=\"/wiki/index.php/SF8\" title=\"SF8\">SF8</a> for the last result)<br /><br />\n</p><p><a href=\"/wiki/index.php/Special_Functions\" title=\"Special Functions\">Special Functions</a><br /><br />\n</p>",
